title: Review: Its All Mirth and Taxes in Love & Taxes
description: Likability goes a long way in Love & Taxes, a comedy that relies on the friendly style of its star to carry a rambling story. If there arent many big laughs here, there are enough smiles to make the time pass pleasantly enough.

title: Matthew Weiner Shares Details About His Amazon Series
description: Russia, a daily fixture in the nations headlines these days, will also figure prominently in Matthew Weiners new series for Amazon.

title: From AOL to Snapchat
description: Major I.P.O.s of Internet technology company since AOL in 1992.

title: Review: Junction 48: An Arab Rappers Refuge Amid Charged Politics
description: Familiar genre trappings do little to dispel the groove of Junction 48, which does for the Israeli city of Lod what 8 Mile aimed to do for the suburbs of Detroit. This energetic drama from the Israeli-American director Udi Aloni casts the real-life rapper Tamer Nafar as Kareem, an aspiring musician from the mixed-population city (also Mr. Nafars hometown), where Kareem, one of Israels Arab citizens, faces regular discrimination and the feeling of a dead end.

title: Ancient City of Palmyra Swings Back to Syrian Government Control
description: Palmyra, the storied ancient city that was among prewar Syrias leading tourist attractions, swung back under government control on Thursday, state media reported, as soldiers and their allies evicted Islamic State militants who had made a sport out of pilfering the citys antiquities.

title: The 12 Lives of Mike White, Hollywood Screenwriter
description: SANTA MONICA  Mike White was once a poor Cuban waitress, a Maori tribesman, a Qing dynasty noble and a doting Japanese wife. Hes lived a dozen incarnations, each depicted in paintings throughout his Spanish-colonial-style home here.

title: Review: Pursuing (Cyber) Connections in The Human Surge
description: The director Eduardo Williams is quite aggressive about pushing at the boundaries between documentary and fiction film in his debut feature, The Human Surge.  His camera follows its subjects, initially young people in impoverished areas around Buenos Aires, from a respectful distance and records, it seems, the most quotidian details of their lives. (It was shot in two formats, Super 16-millimeter film and digital.)

title: Ben Martin, Time Photographer Who Captured the 1960s, Dies at 86
description: Ben Martin, who as a Time magazine senior photographer immortalized Richard M. Nixons haggard 5 oclock shadow, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s march to Montgomery, Ala., and John F. Kennedys grieving widow and children  evocative images that defined the 1960s  died on Feb. 10 at his home in Salisbury, N.C. He was 86.

title: Cherry Blossoms in Washington Could Peak Early
description: WASHINGTON  The iconic blossoming cherry trees that ring the Tidal Basin here have symbolized the arrival of spring for nearly a century. This year, they will be one more sign of wacky and warming weather.

title: How to Get the Rosy Cheeks From the Isabel Marant Show
description: They dont like makeup here, joked the makeup artist Lisa Butler backstage at Isabel Marants fall/winter 2017 show. Her point: The beauty look for this seasons collection was meant to seem as though the models fresh, glowing complexions and rosy pinched cheeks were effortlessly, makeup free.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through June 18. Metropolitan Museum of Art; 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.

title: Review: Israel Is the Focus of The Settlers and Ben-Gurion: Epilogue
description: The Israeli settlement movement is always in the news. It was central to the diplomatic dance surrounding Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus recent visit with President Trump. Now the issues of Israeli sovereignty are revisited in two new films.

title: Review: Shirley MacLaine Wants The Last Word? She Should Have It
description: Shirley MacLaine enters beautiful scowl first in The Last Word, a sweet-and-sour dramatic comedy that would be unbearable without her. She plays Harriet Lauler, a retired advertising executive who has effectively walled herself up in a grand, immaculate house thats a testament to her former glory but so quiet it might as well be her mausoleum. Frankly, its a wonder no one has strangled her yet. Unapologetically domineering, Harriet all but grabs the garden clippers from her exasperated gardener and pushes her blissfully patient cook out of the kitchen. She knows better, does better, always has, always will. Her elbows arent sharp; theyre lethal.

title: Review: Reunited, and It Feels So Awkward in Donald Cried
description: Observing the reunion of two former high school friends in Kris Avedisians squirm-inducing comedy Donald Cried is like watching an ostensibly friendly game of catch in which the players tossing a baseball throw it so hard that it becomes a potentially lethal weapon. At first you root for one side to knock out the other, but the balance of sympathy slowly shifts.

title: Review: In Apprentice, Teaching the Fine Art of Execution
description: The trick is to place the knot just behind the left ear and above the jaw. Those instructions on how to carry out a humane hanging are given early in the Singaporean film Apprentice by Rahim (Wan Hanafi Su), the chief executioner at a high-security prison, to his new assistant, Aiman (Fir Rahman). Rahim takes enormous pride in his work, which he has been doing for 30 years, and he, at least outwardly, exhibits no qualms about his profession. When their time comes, he boasts, the death-row prisoners feel no pain because they die instantly. Rahim assures one man before hes hanged that he is being sent to a better place.

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: This week, weve got a number of books on our list that are certain to get people talking. Cordelia Fines latest, Testosterone Rex, addresses head on some of the sexism that poses as neuroscience. Barry Friedmans important new book, Unwarranted, takes on the volatile question of how to address abusive policing. And Angie Thomass The Hate U Give offers teenage readers a way to look at the Black Lives Matter movement. For sheer fun and entertainment? I recommend Bill Schutts Cannibalism. As readers will discover, thats not as strange as it sounds. Bon appetit.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: Jeff Sessions, Snapchat, Palmyra: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Feud: Bette and Joan, a Clash of the Gossip Girls
description: Feud: Bette and Joan, about the combustible, alchemic collaboration between Bette Davis and Joan Crawford in What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?, is a love letter to hate.

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: What to See at New Yorks Art Fairs This Week
description: Theyve all come to town, the dealers and the collectors and the curators and the freeloaders: Its Armory Week in New York, a saturnalia of art and air kissing. So dive in! Art fairs are, at their core, commercial enterprises  and, as the market undergoes a violent course correction after years of helium-inflated prices, revenues from fairs constitute a growing fraction of galleries yearly takes. But fairs, even for those of us who dont collect, have their uses. They condense the sprawling art world to just about manageable size, and bring to Manhattan dealers from locales as distant as Tokyo, Cape Town, So Paulo  and Brooklyn. Theyre prime people-watching territory, too, and increasingly good places to snag a drink.

title: N.H.L. Clubs, Meet Your Toughest Foe: The Schedule
description: With the trade deadline having come and gone Wednesday, N.H.L. teams are spending the next five weeks battling for playoff positions. But many coaches and players do not see opposing teams as the only adversaries in their quest for a postseason berth. They are also contending with a schedule that offers little rest between games.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: Not needed
description: Articles in this series will look at steps being taken in the New York area to resist floods, surges, high winds and heavy rains.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Rethinking Our Immigration System
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: I Came to America Legally
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Jeff Sessions, Trump and the Russia Connection
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Flood Barrier in Brooklyn: A 7-Foot Wall, Erected in Hours
description: The next time the floodwaters come to Empire Stores on the Brooklyn waterfront  and there will almost surely be a next time  the medieval-looking landmark will be defended by a wall.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: Under Trump, an Already Depleted I.R.S. Could Face Deep Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has a rocky history with the Internal Revenue Service, which he has complained audits him with unfair ferocity. Now he wants to significantly cut the tax agencys funding at a time when it has already been bleeding staff and struggling to keep up with a flood of returns ahead of Tax Day.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: One Way G.O.P. Hopes to Beat de Blasio: Avoid a Primary
description: With campaigns by Democratic challengers to Mayor Bill de Blasio stuck in a larval stage, Republicans in New York City have begun jostling over who will be their partys standard-bearer in the general election  and quietly trying to avoid a primary.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: Welcome Refugees, Churches Say in a Public Challenge to Trump
description: The fight against President Trumps executive orders to turn away refugees, deport undocumented immigrants and build a wall along the Mexican border is about to escalate in many American churches.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: Bob Mankoff to Step Down as Cartoon Editor of The New Yorker
description: Bob Mankoff is stepping down from his post as the cartoon editor of The New Yorker after a 20-year run.

title: A Mediterranean Escape on the Upper East Side
description: On a snowy evening in January, Korali, a Greek restaurant on the Upper East Side, seemed capable of transporting diners from the cold, uncaring city streets to a sunny, cheery island in the Mediterranean. The whitewashed wood tables and chairs, stone walls and high ceilings evoked a taverna in an old coastal village, and the upbeat Greek music playing in the background gave the place a relaxed, festive feel.

title: Marian Javits, Proto-Feminist and Widow of New York Senator, Dies at 92
description: Marian Javits, the arts patron, bon vivant and proto-feminist who cut a singular figure in New York while her husband, Jacob, devoted long years in Washington as the states long-serving United States senator, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: Fighting for New Yorks Homeless: Whats Fair?
description: After a long, lagging period of resistance, Mayor Bill de Blasio recently announced a plan to develop 90 shelters across New York, to mitigate the soaring rate of homelessness, which has characterized life in the city as profoundly as luxury-condominium construction in recent years. The plan is part of a broader strategy, outlined in a 128-page paper released by the city, to reduce the number of homeless people living in primary shelters by 2,500 over the next five years, employing prevention  fighting illegal evictions, for instance  and rehousing efforts.

title: Justin Verlander and the Detroit Tigers Are Back for More
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Justin Verlander gave up two home runs here on Thursday. One was hit well, and the other was carried away by a steady wind to center field.

title: David Rubinger, 92, Photographer Who Chronicled Israeli History, Dies
description: JERUSALEM  His first camera, an Argus, was a parting gift from a French girlfriend he met while serving with the British Army in Europe in 1945. She gave it to him as he boarded a train on his way back to his adopted home in Palestine. That, he said later, was when his lifelong love affair with photography began.

title: Four Cups of Coffee by Noon
description: Dear Diary:

title: Its Called Broomball. And, Yes, Its Grueling.
description: You might want to make fun of it. Just the name alone: broomball. It sounds like the quintessential hipster-baiting pastime  the perfect pseudo-sport for certain twee, bubble-dwelling Brooklynites.

title: Five Boroughs? More Like Five Cities for Mayor de Blasio
description: If youre looking for Mayor Bill de Blasio, dont call City Hall. He leaves for Chicago on Friday morning, goes to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Saturday, then heads to Los Angeles on Sunday.

title: U.S. Agents Raid Caterpillar Over Offshore Tax Practices
description: Federal agents raided three Caterpillar buildings near its Illinois headquarters on Thursday, company and law enforcement officials said, in an escalation of an inquiry into the heavy equipment manufacturers offshore tax practices.

title: Quotation of the Day: Across the Country, a Republican Push to Rein In Protesters
description: Theres a First Amendment right of access to sidewalks, public squares and even public streets. Heckling is a well-protected First Amendment right.

title: Marine Le Pen Loses Parliamentary Immunity Over Twitter Case
description: PARIS  In a clear show of its disapproval, the European Parliament voted Thursday to lift the parliamentary immunity of Marine Le Pen, the leader of the French far-right National Front, in a criminal case involving graphic photographs she posted on Twitter of acts of violence by the Islamic State.

title: Trendy Shanghai District Has Soccer Team With Glitter of Its Own
description: SHANGHAI  The Chinese Super League season kicks off Friday, and ticket scalpers working Shanghai S.I.P.G. matches cant wait.

title: Canadas Immigration System, Lauded by Trump, Is More Complex Than Advertised
description: TORONTO  Canadas merit-based immigration system received a loving mention by President Trump this week in his speech to Congress. Mr. Trump, who has railed against illegal immigration and talked tough about tightening borders, said adopting that kind of system would cost American taxpayers less and help increase wages for poor workers.

title: G.O.P. Accused of Playing Hide-and-Seek With Obamacare Replacement Bill
description: WASHINGTON  It was find the Affordable Care Act replacement day on Thursday as publicity-seeking Democrats  and one frustrated Republican  scampered through Capitol corridors, hunting for an elusive copy of a bill that Republican leaders have withheld from the public as they search for party unity.

title: How to Tell a Secret in the Digital Age
description: At first glance, theres nothing unusual about the stack of mail on Gabriel Dances desk: a handful of envelopes, variously sized, addressed to Tips at The New York Times, no listed return addresses. (Anonymously submitted letters and documents, after all, have long played a part in The Timess news gathering, as was recently seen in The Timess publication of Donald J. Trumps  tax records.)

title: Jeff Sessions Had No Choice
description: Its no great credit to Attorney General Jeff Sessions that he finally recused himself from all Justice Department investigations relating to the 2016 presidential campaign  and specifically from all current or future inquiries into Russian attempts to influence the election. Short of tendering his resignation, he had no other real choice.

title: Healing Rory McIlroy, and Others, Start Fast in Mexico
description: NAUCALPAN DE JUREZ, Mexico  By the time March rolls around, Rory McIlroy is typically weary of questions about the Masters, the last major title he needs to complete a career Grand Slam. In the lead-up to his past two competitive forays to the Masters at Augusta National, McIlroy has endured an endless loop of questions about his preparedness, his confidence and his putting.

title: Military Expects More Shopping Money, if Not All Trump Seeks
description: Over the next two weeks, the military services will be scrambling to get their wish lists in front of top defense officials, hoping their requests for more troops, planes, ships and missiles will be stuffed into President Trumps proposed $54 billion increase in the Pentagon budget.

title: Paul Kangas, 79, Anchor Who Brought Stocks Into Living Rooms, Dies
description: Paul Kangas, a stockbroker who helped pioneer televisions first daily business news show, died on Tuesday in Miami. He was 79.

title: McMaster Was Rebuked in 2015 Over Handling of 2 Officers Accused of Sexual Assault
description: WASHINGTON  A two-year-old report by the Armys inspector general concluded that Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, now President Trumps national security adviser, violated the services regulations in a case that involved two junior officers accused of sexual assault.

title: Melania Trump Reads Dr. Seuss to Children in First Solo Outing as First Lady
description: WASHINGTON  Melania Trump made her first solo foray in public as first lady on Thursday, visiting a hospital pediatric wing to read to sick children.

title: Jeff Sessions Has Stepped Aside on Russia. Heres Who Could Step In.
description: WASHINGTON  The disclosure that Russias ambassador to the United States spoke twice with Attorney General Jeff Sessions last year, even though Mr. Sessions testified at his January confirmation hearing that he did not have communications with the Russians, has set off a new round of political furor in Washington, this time with legal overtones.

title: Sergey Kislyak, Russian Envoy, Cultivated Powerful Network in U.S.
description: Sergey I. Kislyak, the longtime Russian ambassador to the United States, hosted a dazzling dinner in his three-story, Beaux-Arts mansion four blocks north of the White House to toast Michael A. McFaul just weeks before he took up his post as the American envoy to Russia.

title: Boaz Vaadia, Sculptor Who Worked in Street Stone, Dies at 65
description: Boaz Vaadia, an Israeli-born sculptor who mined the streets of New York City for material and became internationally known for figurative pieces made from carefully stacked, carved stone, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

title: Next Stop, 1984
description: Images from Brian Youngs recent book, The Train NYC 1984.

title: Use of Nerve Agent in Kim Jong-nam Killing Is Condemned by Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian Foreign Ministry said Friday that it was greatly concerned by the use of a banned chemical weapon in a public place to assassinate Kim Jong-nam, the half brother of North Koreas leader, and has asked for international help in responding to the episode.

title: Next Stop, 1984: Scenes From the Subway
description: In 1984, Ronald Reagan was president, Arnold Schwarzenegger was still an actor, Bruce Springsteen released Born in the U.S.A. and McDonalds served its 50 billionth hamburger. That same year, a novice photographer from Montreal, Brian Young, landed in New York City and began documenting the insides of the graffiti-covered subway system.

title: Leon Ware, Producer Who Worked With Marvin Gaye, Dies at 77
description: Leon Ware, a writer and producer of sensual R&B songs who was best known for a memorable collaboration with Marvin Gaye on the 1976 album I Want You, died on Feb. 23 in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 77.

title: Takes the Edge Off
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  When you see someone refer to a puzzle as crunchy, it usually means that there is a good helping of fresh or lively entries and a buffet of tough cluing, and that it is generally a grid into which you can really sink your teeth. You know when youve solved a crunchy puzzle. You might have broken a slight sweat, youre smiling and you might even quietly utter the word Wow.

title: Review: In Significant Other, the Gay Best Friend Is the Odd Man Out
description: The familiar and (you thought) anachronistic plaint, Always a bridesmaid, never a bride, assumes an extra degree of pain in Joshua Harmons Significant Other, the bubbly, teary comedy that opened on Thursday night at the Booth Theater. Its bad enough that Jordan Bermans closest buddies, all women, are getting married.

title: Anti-Black Slur in Stamford Is Painted Over After Two Months
description: As mysteriously as an anti-black slur appeared on a house in Stamford, Conn., in January, it was covered over this week, officials said.

title: Amid de Blasios Modest Goals on Homelessness, State Proposal Gains Support
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios declaration that the best New York City could do to reduce the ranks of homeless people in its shelters was to move 2,500 out over five years is rallying advocates and some elected officials behind a plan now working its way through the State Legislature.

title: Rangers Edge Bruins in Boston as Henrik Lundqvist Shines in Goal
description: BOSTON (AP)  Henrik Lundqvist made 32 saves on his 35th birthday, and the Rangers got third-period goals from Pavel Buchnevich and Oscar Lindberg as they beat the Boston Bruins, 2-1, on Thursday night.

title: Editors Note: March 3, 2017
description: OPINION

title: Mike Pence Used Private Email as Governor, News Report Says
description: Vice President Mike Pence used a private email account to conduct public business when he was governor of Indiana, a practice that was legal but raised questions about the security of the communications, some of which addressed sensitive topics.

title: Brandon Marshall Is Expected to Join Growing List of Jets Castoffs
description: The Jets are set to release the veteran wide receiver Brandon Marshall, continuing their off-season roster purge.

title: This Weeks Movies: March 3, 2017
description: The New York Times film critics review Logan, The Last Word and Before I Fall."

title: A Wild and Winding Stairway to a Portuguese River
description: The Paiva Walkways, which opened in 2015 on the left bank of the Paiva River in Aveiro, Portugal, immerse you in nature. Many people consider the Paiva to be the most beautiful river in the country.

title: Word + Quiz: quotidian
Jeff Sessions, Palmyra, Snapchat: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Fire at Sea and Vice: Trans Youth
description: In Fire at Sea, Gianfranco Rosi chronicles the horror and hope found on a Mediterranean island that has become a primary European entry point for refugees. And Vice looks at transgender youths who are opting to transition before puberty.

title: The Week in Pictures: March 3, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: Answers to an Open-Ended Question
description: Since the presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1935, the Gallup polling organization has asked Americans the same open-ended question. This chart shows the answers they gave in February, 2017.

title: Questions for: Before Vaquitas Vanish, a Desperate Bid to Save Them
description: Article: Before Vaquitas Vanish, a Desperate Bid to Save Them

title: The Week in Pictures: March 3, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: Vladimir Putin Comes Half Clean on Olympic Doping
description: Russias abominable record of doping its athletes in international competitions finally forced President Vladimir Putin to concede some shortcomings this week  but not his governments basic culpability in the cheating.

title: A Sanctuary City Seizes the Moment, and the Name
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Cities of immigrants, its time. Time to declare yourselves sanctuaries. To wear the label proudly, defiantly, even if the White House and its allies threaten you and utter all kinds of falsehoods against you.

title: A Great New Accidental Renaissance
description: My friend Sam laughed when I told him I was going to spend my Saturday at a Search for Meaning festival at a Jesuit college in the heart of seriously secular Seattle. He assumed, as I did, that a bare handful of the usual search-for-meaning suspects would be straining minutiae while still clinging to the meaninglessness of it all.

title: Paul Ryans Misguided Sense of Freedom
description: In his first address to Congress, President Trump made many sweeping pledges, but one of them was familiar to anyone who listened to him campaign. He said that he was calling on this Congress to repeal and replace Obamacare and demanding reforms that expand choice, increase access, lower costs and, at the same time, provide better health care.

title: Goodbye Spin, Hello Raw Dishonesty
description: The latest big buzz is about Jeff Sessions, the attorney general. It turns out that he lied during his confirmation hearings, denying that he had met with Russian officials during the 2016 campaign. In fact, he met twice with the Russian ambassador, who is widely reported to also be a key spymaster.

title: Public Lands in Private Hands?
description: The Senates confirmation this week of the former Montana congressman Ryan Zinke as secretary of the interior has revived concerns about the future of public lands in the Trump administration. While Mr. Zinke has branded himself as a Teddy Roosevelt-style conservationist  and resigned as a delegate to the Republican National Convention last year to protest the partys support for transferring federal lands to states or private groups  his record is spotty.

title: Trumpism at Its Best, Straight Up
description: Donald Trump gave us Trumpism at its best on Tuesday night. And that was useful because it gave us a view of the political movement he represents, without the clownish behavior.

title: How Would You Change Your Favorite Sport?
description: Are you a sports fan fed up with the length of the games or matches, the expense to see the game in person, the changing rules, or the seemingly never-ending seasons?

title: Trumps Many Shades of Contempt
description: This is a column about contempt. Lets start with the utter contempt that President Trump has shown for the State Department since taking office six weeks ago. Some 70,000 American patriots across the globe, dedicated to the American idea as a force for good in the world, have been cast adrift.

title: The Fog Catchers
description: In Lima, Peru, where little rain falls, a community project is turning fog into water to irrigate 50 household gardens in the Eliseo Collazos neighborhood.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Dog Weddings
description: Timothy writes: My wife wants to hold a wedding for our dogs. One is a Chihuahua, and my wife wants to make sure she can stay in the country after President Trump builds the wall. I love my wife; I love our dogs. We hold a birthday party every year for one of them. But a dog wedding seems a step too far.

title: Self-Portrait as So Much Potential
description: In his debut collection, the poet Chen Chen writes from a position of colliding identities: Chinese, American, gay. He has said his poems are a way for those different experiences to come together, for them to be in the same room. Here, the poet uses metaphor to investigate his own hopes and familial disappointments. The poem has the feeling of genuine, uneasy discovery, as if only through writing could he come to know who he is and what he feels.

title: How to Start a Soccer Chant
description: Start with just a few words  chants that are easy to learn and that are repetitive, says Max Jack, an ethnomusicologist who specializes in music and sports at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Chants like the frequently heard ol, ol, ol catch on quickly because theyre simple and often stay within a five- or six-note range. But most of the time, chants are familiar songs that have been adapted: You might take a melody from a song you like, and you might just mess around with the words. For example, fans of the Shamrock Rovers, a soccer club in the League of Ireland Premier Division, changed the chorus of Lykke Lis song I Follow Rivers to I, I, follow/I follow you, Shamrock Rovers. (The same club has also been known to chant the lyrics to Build Me Up Buttercup without changing the lyrics at all. They didnt have their own home ground, the club went through all these hardships and the lyrics spoke to the hardships of the club, Jack says.)

title: Strangers on an 18-Hour Train
description: Many years ago, before my family immigrated to the United States from Pakistan, we used to travel frequently by train. During a more recent trip home, instead of flying back to Karachi from Lahore, I decided to go by train again. I was interested to see what it was like traveling in economy class. I got a seat in Car No. 3, and amid thunder and rain, the train hissed out of the station. Its pace was slow. The compartment was packed.

title: The 2.19.17 Issue
description: RE: RUDENESS

title: You May Want to Marry My Husband
description: Note: Amy Krouse Rosenthal died on March 13, 2017, 10 days after this essay was published. You can read her obituary here. In June, 2018, her husband published this response.

title: The Best and Latest in Crime Fiction
description: Hath not a serial killer eyes? Hath not a serial killer hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? If you prick him, does he not bleed? If you tickle him, does he not laugh? Well, lets see what the wife of a serial killer has to say about that in JoAnn Chaneys WHAT YOU DONT KNOW (Flatiron, $25.99).

title: M.L.S. Preview: Some New Crests, Some Younger Stars
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  If there is a single unifying theme at the dawn of another Major League Soccer season, it is expansion  in regard to Atlanta United and Minnesota United, the teams making their debuts this weekend, and for the young league as a whole, moving forward.

title: When Teachers Face the Task of Fixing Their Retirement Accounts
description: When the Greenwich Alliance for Education held its annual trivia challenge last week, Carol Sutton worried a bit when the topic turned to finance. Ms. Sutton, the president of the teachers union in Greenwich, Conn., and her table full of educators werent quite equipped for the question about debentures.

title: Majority Rule Means the Power to Stop, Not Just Start, an Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  When Richard J. Durbin joined the Senate in 1997, his junior status relegated him to an unenviable task: serving in the minority on the Governmental Affairs Committee as the Republican-led panel exhaustively examined claims of an insidious Chinese plot to help President Bill Clinton in the 1996 elections.

title: The Worlds Top Tech Investor Is Betting Big on Trump
description: The worlds largest technology investor is preparing to ramp up his bet on the Trump economy.

title: Friday Mailbag: Why Treat a First Author Like a Second Fiddle?
description: Last Friday two immigrants from India were shot at Austins Bar and Grill in Olathe, Kansas. The two friends were enjoying drinks after work when another patron, a white man, began showering them with ethnic slurs and suggesting that they did not belong in the United States. The man was thrown out of the bar, but returned soon after and shot the two men, killing one of them.

title: For 3 Indiana Brothers, America First Cuts 2 Ways
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind.  When Alcoa abruptly announced last year that its aluminum smelter near here would close, some longtime workers talked of burning the place down.

title: In Paris, the Two Women Who Are Colette
description: PARIS  In fashion, business is often a family affair. But even by that measure, Colette, the concept store based in Paris, is an exception.

title: Millennials Ask: Whats It Like to Retire?
description: We asked journalism students around the country to talk to seniors about retirement. This is what they recorded.

title: From the Elders to the Kids: What I Wish Id Known
description: When youre in college, retirement seems so far away. How do you even wrap your head around it? We asked journalism students from five colleges and universities to talk with retirees, and find out what they wish they had known when they were the students age. The conversations have been edited.

title: Affordable Housing Boom in the Bronx
description: Thousands of affordable rental apartments are planned or are under construction in the Bronx, some with perks like rooftop farms and concert halls.

title: The Bronx Is Building
description: On parking lots, rubbly plots and the occasional community garden, the Bronx seems awash in new apartments.

title: George W. Bush Isnt Mad at Will Ferrell, His TV Counterpart
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Teaching With: Ten Meter Tower
description: Would you jump from a 10-meter diving tower (about 33 feet)?

title: Obamacare Got Their Goat: An Illustrated Guide to Republicans Metaphors
description: Its a goat on a bridge eating a flaming rug pulled from a collapsing sand castle! Yes, of course, Im talking about the Affordable Care Act, which you may also know as Obamacare.

title: Jeff Sessions, Obamacare, Palmyra: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Daily: Normal Things Between Sessions and Russia
description: The Russian ambassador apparently sent a staffer to my office  I did not see him  and asked for a meeting, as so many of the ambassadors were doing.

title: New York Today: Weather Limbo
description: Updated 7:59 a.m.

title: Heres to the Good Times, and an Open Mind
description: Learn from your mistakes, my 11-year-old son remarked matter-of-factly as we walked past a wildly inebriated young woman throwing up in the bushes. We were heading to our seats at the Irvine Meadows Amphitheater, southeast of Los Angeles, where the country duo Florida Georgia Line was about to take the stage.

title: A Stylish Base in Paris for Exploring the Right Bank
description: From 190 euros a night, about $200.

title: Cruises Recruit a New Crowd: Millennials Who Like a Late Night
description: A confession: Until recently, the only time I spent a night on water was at age 8, when my parents booked our family of three on a cruise to Finland. I remember gaping at the ice cream selection and gazing into brightly lit boutique windows, and not much else. So when I boarded the Regent Seven Seas Explorer, the luxury cruise lines newest ship, on its recent voyage to Mexico, it was with limited expectations: copious food and stuff to buy.

title: In Portland, Middle Eastern Flavors Meet a California Vibe
description: Chefs name their restaurants after all sorts of things: obscure plants, childhood pets, villages on the Adriatic. But Tusk is most likely the only restaurant in Portland named for a Fleetwood Mac album. When you listen to Tusk or Rumours, thats the vibe we wanted to have, said Sam Smith, the restaurants executive chef and an owner. But, he added, Were not playing that music all the time.

title: Waiting for Her to Take the Lead
description: Samir Nurmohamed, an assistant professor known for his rap skills, wanted to date Salimah Nooruddin, but decided he could not ask her out. The couple were married on Feb. 19 in Texas.

title: A Muslim Romance, Soundtrack by Kanye and Drake
description: In fall 2013, Samir Nurmohamed wanted desperately to go out with Salimah Nooruddin. There was only one problem: He had decided that she had to ask him out first.

title: Morning Agenda: Snap, Caterpillars Tax, Masayoshi Son, Harvard Donor
description: Investors seem to think Snap Inc. will stick around for longer than the messages on its app, Snapchat.

title: Argentine Fiction
description: FEVER DREAMBy Samanta SchweblinTranslated by Megan McDowell183 pp. Riverhead, $25.

title: Nintendo Switch Reviews: Heres What the Critics Say
description: Early reviews of the Nintendo Switch were largely positive, but most of the enthusiasm was tempered by reviewers inability to test key aspects of the gaming console, including online play and game downloading.

title: 13 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times stories from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: Deryl McKissack on Drawing Boundaries for Millennials
description: This interview with Deryl McKissack, C.E.O. of McKissack &McKissack, an architectural, engineering and construction firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: In Times Square, Looking for Father Duffy
description: Q. In Duffy Square, why is there a statue of George M. Cohan and not Father Duffy? And why is it called a square when its actually a triangle?

title: PETA Condemns N.H.L.s Use of Real Penguins in Pittsburgh Pregame Show
description: For one of its signature events, the outdoor Stadium Series game featuring the Pittsburgh Penguins, the N.H.L. figured actual live penguins would be an entertaining addition to the pregame festivities.

title: A Painting Stolen First by the Nazis, Then by Persons Unknown
description: THE FORTUNATE ONESBy Ellen Umansky 324 pp. William Morrow/HarperCollins Publishers. $26.99.

title: Loewe: Fall 2017
description: Jonathan Anderson shows the labels fall looks.

title: Vanessa Seward: Fall 2017
description: Ms. Seward shows her fall looks.

title: California Today: Beloved Railway to Return in Los Angeles
description: Good morning.

title: Tony Blair: Against Populism, the Center Must Hold
description: LONDON  Outrage is easy; strategy is hard. Outrage provides necessary motivation. But only strategy can deliver victory.

title: Chinas Response to Reports of Torture: Fake News
description: BEIJING  FAKE NEWS, a Twitter post declared. Prejudice-based, another said. Cleverly orchestrated lies, a news article asserted.

title: How Dominique Ansel, Inventor of the Cronut, Spends His Sundays
description: Years before his Cronut inspired New Yorkers to line up around the block in SoHo, Dominique Ansel captured the attention of the French military. At 19, conscription sent the budding chef to French Guiana, where he provided culinary instruction and tore through ravines with a machete. Like Indiana Jones, he said. After stints at Fauchon in Paris and Daniel in New York, he invented the Cronut and started a global pastry empire, including bakeries in London and Tokyo and, later this year, his first full-fledged restaurant in Los Angeles. Mr. Ansel, 39, lives with his girlfriend and business partner, Amy Ma, in Columbus Circle.

title: Killing Jesus: Who Was the Real Pontius Pilate?
description: PONTIUS PILATEDeciphering a MemoryBy Aldo SchiavoneTranslated by Jeremy Carden238 pp. Liveright Publishing. $24.95.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Suzanne Vega
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the singer Suzanne Vega, whose seminal songs Toms Diner and My Name Is Luka turn 30 this year. She is performing at the Caf Carlyle in New York from March 14 to March 25  and shares her list exclusively with T.

title: A Physicists Crash Course in Unpeeling the Universe
description: REALITY IS NOT WHAT IT SEEMSThe Journey to Quantum GravityBy Carlo RovelliTranslated by Simon Carnell and Erica SegreIllustrated. 280 pp. Riverhead Books. $26.

title: Money Worries for Retired Women
description: Many women find it an uphill battle to save for retirement.

title: Once a School, Now a Showcase
description: Manhattans luxury market saw a flow of activity in townhouses. Topping the list of sales was a mansion owned by the investor Andrew L. Farkas.

title: East Side Mansion Tops February Home Sales
description: The Manhattan luxury market saw a flow of activity in townhouses last month, and topping the list of sales was a grand limestone mansion near Central Park that was owned for nearly a decade by the real estate investor Andrew L. Farkas.

title: First Seen 30 Years Ago, a Supernova Refuses to Be Ignored
description: On the morning of Feb. 23, 1987, a couple of dozen subatomic particles known as neutrinos zinged through specially instrumented underground sensors in Japan, Ohio and Russia. The particles had squirted from the core of a collapsing star 163,000 light years away in a small galaxy known as the Large Magellanic Cloud. They were the heralds of doom.

title: Jeff Sessions Violated His Oath
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Ex-Reporter Charged With Making Bomb Threats Against Jewish Sites
description: A former reporter for a news website was charged on Friday with making more than a half-dozen bomb threats against Jewish community centers, schools and a Jewish history museum, federal authorities said.

title: Nintendo Switch: Unconventional Hype for an Unusual Game Console
description: Every few years, one of the big video game companies comes out with a new box that it wants consumers to make space for in their living rooms.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Cancer, Alzheimer's and Vitamins Gone Gummy
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Alison Wright, Exiled From The Americans (Perhaps), Hits Broadway
description: It took Alison Wright 34 years to land her first big role, as poor Martha Hanson, the long-suffering F.B.I. secretary on FXs The Americans. And another four  after Martha made the shattering discovery that her marriage to Clark Westerfeld, an alias of the K.G.B. agent Philip Jennings (Matthew Rhys), was mostly a sham  to break viewers hearts and be jettisoned off the series (maybe to Moscow).

title: Stephin Merritt Finds 50 Ways to Sing His Life Story
description: Stephin Merritt sniffs at the idea of spilling his life story in song. I couldnt care less about pouring my heart out in public, he said over a recent afternoon tea near his apartment in Greenwich Village, dressed in his trademark brown.

title: SpaceX Plans to Send Tourists to the Moon
description: Ready for liftoff?

title: How Donald Trump Wins by Losing
description: It is impossible not to watch: Every day of the Trump administration seemingly brings another plot twist, a new initiative, outlandish attack or bizarre reversal. Not since wartime has news been so riveting  and with the president fighting so many enemies, it is actually not unlike war coverage. The nonstop media coverage cannot be faulted for being uncritical: It is, instead, a detailed assessment of the wins and losses of a wild presidency. Yet is it possible that the media, and many viewers, are using the wrong metrics of success?

title: The Three Different Flavors of Family Businesses
description: Each family that runs its own business also has its own culture, say two psychologists who work with wealthy families. And understanding those cultures  which these psychologists break down into three groups  can make it easier to resolve intergenerational or cross-cultural conflicts that arise as the business matures and expands.

title: How to Escape Your Political Bubble for a Clearer View
description: As the media class struggles to understand an election result few foresaw, some have blamed a quirk of modern technology.

title: Whats That Smell? Rare Books and Artifacts From a 1906 Library
description: Novelists have always known, maybe because their lives are so bound up in books.

title: Should I Take a Vitamin for Brittle Nails?
description: Q. Is there a vitamin or mineral one can take to prevent or cure splitting fingernails?

title: Morgan Stanley Goofed on Tax Information. But Not to Worry.
description: Some Morgan Stanley wealth management customers are getting news in the mail this week: They underpaid  or in some cases, overpaid  their taxes for several years because of incorrect information the firm provided to them about their investments.

title: Sundance Now, a Film Festival Built for This Screen
description: In its more than 30 years of existence, the Sundance Film Festival has obtained a name recognition unlike that of any other industry event besides Cannes. The biggest independent film festival in the United States, held in January in a town whose big business is skiing, its a rite of passage for both scrappy, small-budget filmmakers and Hollywood names seeking what was once called indie cred. Its frequently circuslike atmosphere is a well-known component of its notoriety.

title: Going From Bond Girl to a Normal Life
description: HAKONE, Japan  In 1967, Mie Hama was Hollywoods newest sex symbol. That year, the 23-year-old Japanese film star appeared alongside Sean Connery in the James Bond movie You Only Live Twice, playing 007s bikini-clad bride, Kissy Suzuki. She was also featured in Playboy, which proclaimed her the Brigitte Bardot of Japan.

title: Carson McCullers at 100
description: Feb. 19 was the centenary of the birth of Carson McCullers, one of the most distinctive and ill-fated writers in American history. McCullers died when she was 50, in 1967. She suffered a series of strokes before she was 30, and spent much of her life in pain.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: UConn-Stanford? It Would Have Nothing on This Sibling Rivalry
description: Karlie Samuelson used to be so shy that her younger sister, Katie Lou, would order for her when their family dined at restaurants.

title: The Secret to a Really Crisp Apple
description: Q. Why are some apples mealy while others are crisp?

title: Erased Onscreen: Where Are All the Interracial Couples?
description: The recent drama Loving is about an interracial marriage and takes place in midcentury rural Virginia, but there are no burning crosses, white hoods or Woolworth counters. Richard Loving and Mildred Jeter, a white man and a black Native American woman kiss in public at a drag race, and no one voices disapproval. A few white spectators stare and scowl. But the couple embrace and laugh, unsullied.

title: Merce Cunningham as Collaborator, Breaking Down Hierarchies in Art and Bodies
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Most Western visual art is about permanence, about objects as monuments, stays against time. A deep, defining feature of dance is that its materially unfixed. It exists in time; and then it doesnt. It may leave traces  photographs, notations, memories  but the thing itself is gone.

title: Finding a Roommate When Youre in Your 60s
description: When Beverly Tall, a retired office administrator, decided to get a long-term roommate to share her two-bedroom apartment in Morningside Heights, she didnt want to take her chances with Craigslist. So she turned to the home-sharing program run by the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens, a free service that matches older hosts with guests.

title: Christian Dior: Fall 2017
description: Maria Grazia Chiuri presents the labels fall designs.

title: Interior Design Risks Worth Taking
description: Its tempting to play it safe when it comes to decorating. That butterfly-print wallpaper is appealing, but it isnt cheap, and you may hate it once its up on the wall. Whereas, beige paint  who could object to that?

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Review: Beauty and the Beast Revels in Joy and Enchantment
description: To quote a lyric from one of the songs in Beauty and the Beast, there may be something there that wasnt there before. The familiar elements are all in place, of course. Its Beauty and the Beast, for goodness sake: a tale as old as time, a song as old as rhyme and all that. And there are inspired flights of nostalgia as well, visual evocations of the predigital glory of Busby Berkeley, Ray Harryhausen and other masters of fantastical craft.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: Not Yet 30, This Fantasy Writer Is an Old Pro
description: History of Magic: The fantasy writer V.E. Schwab  whose new novel, A Conjuring of Light, concludes a trilogy about multiple, magical Londons and debuts at No.6 in hardcover fiction  also writes young adult books as Victoria Schwab; last summer, her novel This Savage Song hit No.1 on the Y.A. hardcover list. A lot of people assume that my adult books are darker, Schwab said on a recent visit to The New York Times, when really the reverse is true. My Y.A. books are way darker than my adult books. Kids can handle it. Adults want their escapism and their whimsy, and kids are like, Hit me with the dark stuff.

title: Interfaith Healer: The Surprising Role of Jesus in Islam
description: THE ISLAMIC JESUSHow the King of the Jews Became a Prophet of the MuslimsBy Mustafa Akyol275 pp. St Martins Press. $26.99.

title: E.U. Lawmakers Call for End to Visa-Free Travel for Americans
description: BRUSSELS  The European Parliament has passed a nonbinding resolution calling for the reintroduction of visa requirements for American citizens, raising the stakes in a long-running battle over the United States refusal to grant visa-free access to citizens of five European Union countries.

title: Jonas Kaufmann Withdraws From Met Operas Tosca
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced on Friday that the elusive star tenor Jonas Kaufmann would not appear in its highly anticipated new production of Puccinis Tosca next season.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: Daily Report: Snaps I.P.O. Went Well. Now What?
description: Snap faced down its skeptics, at least on its first day of trading.

title: Womens Fashion Shows: Rick Owens, Chlo, Balmain
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2017 collections presented in Paris on Thursday.

title: How to Get the Soft, Day-After Beauty from the Dior Show
description: There was a toughened-up, rebellious vibe to Diors fall/winter 2017 collection, which was presented in Paris on Friday. Each model wore a black leather beret on the runway  a styling decision that informed both the hair and the makeup direction. Backstage, the makeup artist Peter Philips explained that he gave models natural, fresh-looking faces, with the exception of a residual, day-after-a-night-out effect around the eyes. After evening out the skin tone with foundation, Philips highlighted the upper sides of the face with a powder foundation (using Diorskin Nude Air Glow Powder in Fresh Tan for its versatility with most complexions).

title: Movies and Television New on Netflix in March
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: State I.R.A. Plans Are Ready, if Congress Doesnt Interfere
description: Thirty-nine million Americans work for an employer without a payroll-deduction retirement savings plan, and many of them are saving little or nothing. In the absence of a federal plan for this problem, states including California, Connecticut, Illinois, Maryland and Oregon have taken it upon themselves to create their own solutions.

title: How to Use a Hearing Aid with Your Smartphone
description: Q. What hearing aids work best with the iPhone?

title: Brazils Leaders Tout Austerity (Just Not for Them)
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazils sickly economy is hemorrhaging thousands of jobs a day, states are scrambling to pay police officers and teachers, and money for subsidized meals is in such short supply that one legislator suggested that the poor could eat every other day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Reading the Bible

title: Catch of the Year. No Ball Involved.
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The most memorable play of spring training across all of baseball  and, by now, the most watched  involved a low level Mets prospect named Luis Guillorme. And he was not even on the diamond at the time.

title: Set to Lift Interest Rate, Fed Embraces Investors Optimism
description: The Federal Reserve is poised to raise its benchmark interest rate in mid-March, significantly sooner than investors had expected, as it moves to keep pace with a wave of economic optimism that started with the election of President Trump.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Hulu and More in March
description: Here are the titles we think are most interesting, broken down by service.

title: A Buffy Family Tree: Bones and Demons and Rabid Fans
description: Twenty years ago this month, the Hellmouth opened, and television hasnt been the same since.

title: Frank Gehry and Daniel Barenboim on Their New Concert Hall in Berlin
description: BERLIN  It started with the scribble of an oval. Several years ago the architect Frank Gehry, known to begin his building projects with expressive and curvy sketches, drew the crude shape for Daniel Barenboim, the conductor and pianist who had enlisted him to design a new chamber music hall here.

title: Arkansas Rushes to Execute 8 Men in the Space of 10 Days
description: The state of Arkansas plans to put to death eight inmates over a span of 10 days next month, a pace of executions unequaled in recent American history and brought about by a looming expiration date for a drug used by the state for lethal injections.

title: Signet Jewelers Balance Sheet Gets Extra Sparkle
description: In the world of business, bad news often surfaces serially: You see a cockroach in your kitchen; as the days go by, you meet his relatives.

title: Backstage Portfolio: The Faces of Maison Margiela
description: The houses fall/winter 2017 show, which was presented in Paris this week, featured electric eye makeup and embroidered strands of hair.

title: Transgender Models Find a Home
description: As one of the fashion industrys increasing numbers of a transgender models, Yasmine Petty has reached great success. Her sprawling penthouse in Lower Manhattan, with a terrace so large it has a pool and cabana, is full of magazines like Elle, W and Hercules that feature multiple-page spreads on her wearing clothing by brands like Marc Jacobs and Louis Vuitton.

title: After Kansas Shooting, a Community in Fear
description: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

title: How Cooking Dinner Can Be a Dance
description: One of my most thrilling moments of culinary discovery was when, at age 16, a friend and I went to dinner at a fancy restaurant using our babysitting money.

title: Inside Sara Bermans Closet at the Met Museum
description: There are 21 period rooms in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ranging from a 17th-century colonial interior to an enormous Prairie-style living room by Frank Lloyd Wright, each designed to transport the viewer back in time.

title: Banksy Puts Mark on Bethlehem Hotel With Worst View in the World
description: Welcome to the hotel with the worst view in the world. Please be mindful of the million-dollar art on the walls.

title: Trump and Big Coal
description: To the Editor:

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a three-bedroom cottage in Ocean Grove, N.J., and a six-bedroom 1905 house in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: A Relative of Couscous Finds a Wider Fan Base
description: Fregola, or fregola sarda, as it is known in Sardinia, has been around for a long, long time, a culinary gift from nearby Tunisia. A sturdy, spherical relative of couscous, it is hand-rolled from a mixture of semolina and water, then dried and toasted before it is ready to be steamed or simmered. Beautifully burnished and speckled, it has an alluring comfort-food appeal.

title: What Future and Migos Tell Us About Atlantas Rap Dominance
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: South Bronx Rent Increases Greatest in the City
description: Our Feb. 17 report on dropping rents in cities across the country may have left some New Yorkers scratching their heads. Although one-bedroom rents dropped 9.1 percent overall in the city over the course of 2016, they increased substantially in many neighborhoods, according to data gathered for us by Zumper.com.

title: Racial Justice at Ole Miss
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Read Proust in the Original
With a Trail of Smoke, a Leisurely Flight Turned Deadly
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y.  It was a clear morning when an Army National Guard crew aboard a Black Hawk helicopter flew above the woods along the edge of the airport here as part of its regular weekend duty. One of the crew members works during the week painting stripes on highways, and another sits behind a desk on Wall Street. Some are New York City firefighters accustomed to springing into action.

title: Review: Little Miss Sunshine Trips Into a Slasher Film in All the Fine Boys
description: Its a Friday night in the South Carolina suburbs, late in the 1980s, and Jenny and Emily have a pile of VHS tapes fresh from the video store: A Stranger Is Watching, Bloody Birthday, Dead Ringers and more. For horror fans, this is slice-and-dice nirvana.

title: Spring Amphibians, on the Move, Could Use Some Crossing Guards
description: Blood laced with a natural antifreeze pumps through the veins of wood frogs. They rest suspended, somewhere between life and death, awaiting springs arrival in frozen winter forests. Beneath a blanket of decaying leaves, salamanders are waiting, too.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in March
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site.

title: How Uber Deceives the Authorities Worldwide
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Uber has for years engaged in a worldwide program to deceive the authorities in markets where its low-cost ride-hailing service was resisted by law enforcement or, in some instances, had been banned.

title: In Red-State Utah, a Surge Toward Obamacare
description: SALT LAKE CITY  From the moment the Affordable Care Act passed in 2010, most elected officials in this sturdily Republican state have been eager to squash it.

title: Trump Derides Schwarzenegger for Leaving Celebrity Apprentice
description: Arnold Schwarzeneggers time as host of NBCs The Celebrity Apprentice will be a short one.

title: Street Style: Paris Fashion Week
description: The best looks around Paris.

title: Heres Your Chance to Buy Joan Riverss Seder Plate
description: Typically a piece of china for the Passover table from the 1980s would be worth little, if anything, at auction. But this one  of bone china by Spode  belonged to the comedian Joan Rivers and is coming up for sale in April at an auction of seder plates.

title: Secret Life of Tweets Undoes Celebrated Voice of French Suburbs
description: PARIS  He and his writing partner were the toast of the Left Bank, published and celebrated by the prestigious and chic. They were praised as authentic voices from Frances troubled suburbs, articulate and poetic chroniclers of the immigrant youth experience.

title: Heirs Sue for Return of a Kandinsky, Saying It Was Looted by Nazis
description: For more than 40 years, Colorful Life, an important painting by Wassily Kandinsky, has hung in Stdtische Galerie im Lenbachhaus, a Munich museum where visitors have been able to appreciate the swirl of colors in a work that many experts view as a marker in this renowned Russian artists development from figuration to abstraction.

title: Undercover: Fall 2017
description: Jun Takahashi presents the labels fall looks.

title: An Alabama Drive-In Bans Beauty and the Beast Over Gay Character
description: LOS ANGELES  A human-beast love story? Thats perfectly fine. But a comedic sidekick with a subtle romantic interest in the same sex? Hold everything.

title: Street Style: Paris Fashion Week
description: Between the runway and the street, theres more fashion to see in Paris than any one person could. We had our photographers give it their best shot.

title: The Playlist: Lorde Flips Heartbreak Into Catharsis
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

title: Happy Trails
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: A Battle Over the Military Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Why We Believe Obvious Untruths
description: How can so many people believe things that are demonstrably false? The question has taken on new urgency as the Trump administration propagates falsehoods about voter fraud, climate change and crime statistics that large swaths of the population have bought into. But collective delusion is not new, nor is it the sole province of the political right. Plenty of liberals believe, counter to scientific consensus, that G.M.O.s are poisonous, and that vaccines cause autism.

title: The G.O.P. and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Real About the Fantasy of a Fresh Start
description: My husband and I work in high-paying jobs in the tech field in New York City. We are in our early 30s and want to prepare for a family. We are also exhausted by our jobs. So we want to take the drastic step of moving upstate to a small town near the Catskills, and abandoning our corporate careers. What are realistic job opportunities for us? How can we predictably make this decision not knowing how the transition will work out? D. K.

title: Review: The Boston Symphonys Radiant Precision
description: After a preposterous week that saw three major orchestras converge on New York  eight concerts; 22,000 seats; nearly 13 hours of music  the Boston Symphony had the final note.

description: To the Editor:

description: This weeks properties are on the Upper East Side, in Murray Hill and in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: How the Amazons Cashews and Cacao Point to Cultivation by the Ancients
description: Scientists studying the Amazon rain forest are tangled in a debate of nature versus nurture.

title: Paula Fox, Novelist Who Chronicled Dislocation, Dies at 93
description: Paula Fox, a distinguished writer for children and adults whose work illuminated lives filled with loss, dislocation and abandonment, conditions she knew firsthand from a very early age, died on Wednesday in Brooklyn. She was 93.

title: Art Week and Civic Museums
description: Galas were held last week for the Armory Show, the Childrens Defense FundNew York, the Bronx Museum and the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Art Week and Childrens Defense Fund Galas
description: In an unofficial kickoff to New York Art Week, the Armory Party was held at the Museum of Modern Art on March 1. The Childrens Defense Fund-New York held its annual benefit at the Pierre on Feb. 28. The Bronx Museum held a gala at the Conrad New York hotel on Feb. 27. And the Museum of the City of New York held its Winter Ball at Cipriani 42nd Street on Feb. 23.

title: Calling Out Sexism
description: To the Editor:

title: College Student Suffers Severe Reaction After Hazing Involving Peanut Butter
description: A Michigan college student with a deadly peanut allergy was the victim of a hazing ritual in which he was daubed in the face with peanut butter at an off-campus party, spurring a severe reaction that left him with swollen eyes, officials and the mans mother said.

title: Payroll Card Regulations in New York Are Struck Down
description: A New York State effort to more tightly regulate the prepaid cards on which many employees receive their wages was struck down by a review board, which ruled that the states Labor Department exceeded its authority in imposing fee limits and other restrictions on the cards.

title: Voyeur: The Color Red
description: so much depends

title: Until the Daffodils Bloom, We Depend on Red
description: Finding glimpses of red in unexpected places.

title: Driven Nuts by Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Uber Said to Consider Changes to Employee Stock Compensation
description: Uber has lurched from one blow to its reputation after another. Now it is trying to contain some of the damage to employees.

title: New Homeless Shelters in New York
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Three Trump Associates Who Changed Their Story on Russia
description: Their statements changed after news reports emerged of their conversations.

title: Working Longer May Benefit Your Health
description: Are there health benefits to staying in the work force longer?

title: Its Hard to Be Excited About World Baseball Classic When U.S. Players Arent
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Imagine a star-spangled outfield of Mike Trout, Mookie Betts and Bryce Harper. Imagine a red-white-and-blue pitching staff of Clayton Kershaw, Madison Bumgarner and Corey Kluber at the start and Zach Britton at the end.

title: Why Do Comics Laugh at Their Own Jokes? Its No Accident
description: Does Donald Trump laugh?

title: Indian State Says Itll Require Study of Sanskrit, Raising Eyebrows
description: MUMBAI, India  The government of the northeastern Indian state of Assam announced this week that Sanskrit, the ancient Hindu language of the Brahmin priesthood, would now be mandatory for students in the upper grades of all public high schools.

title: For Trump and DeVos, a Florida Private School Is a Model for Choice
description: ORANGE COUNTY, Fla.  President Trump on Friday hailed a Florida school tuition assistance program as the future of education, joining Betsy DeVos, his education secretary, at a Catholic elementary classroom to kick off an intense political battle on behalf of school choice in America.

title: Hell Gate Bridge, a Good Place to Hide From Zombies, Turns 100
description: Allan Renz laughed at the question: Would people care as much about one of the bridges his grandfather designed if the word Heck were in its name, instead of Hell?

title: Review: TV Does the Time Warp (Again) on Time After Time and Making History
description: Its getting crowded on televisions time-travel highway. Between Timeless, Frequency, 12 Monkeys, DCs Legends of Tomorrow and The Flash  not to mention the original traveler, Doctor Who  theres a small army of people moving between or talking across the years. Pretty soon theyll start running into each other. (Actually they already do, on Legends and The Flash.)

title: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2017
description: Mr. Yamamoto presents his fall looks.

title: Transforming Dior Into a House of Blues
description: PARIS  The good news: This time, there were no fencing outfits. The bad news: They have been replaced by a meditation on the uniform, in its various guises, from schoolgirl to WAC to policewoman. In her second ready-to-wear collection for Christian Dior, Maria Grazia Chiuri took her feminism further out of the realm of the literal  but not quite far enough.

title: In Downtown Brooklyn, New Rentals Go Head to Head
description: As rents in Brooklyn slip but inventory continues to mount, landlords are locked in a fight to fill their apartments.

title: Jim Rogers, Intrepid Investor, Finds Bumpy Road to North Korea
description: HONG KONG  China was an economic backwater when Jim Rogers began traveling its dusty byways more than three decades ago. Still, Mr. Rogers, a former partner of George Soros, saw its promise.

title: Laurie Anderson on Lou Reeds Love, Work and Retirement Plan
description: Last week, I sat down with the artist Laurie Anderson at her office in TriBeCa for what I expected would be a fairly short interview to discuss the  archive of her late husband, Lou Reed, who died in 2013. We wound up speaking for almost two hours; with Will, her latest dog, sitting next to me, I heard the little robotic voice on her laptop first announce 4 oclock, then 5 oclock.

title: For Migrants Headed North, the Things They Carried to the End
description: Strong political art is hard to make. So when it turns up, its worth a look. In an era of great, great walls and bad hombres, an exhibition called State of Exception/Estado de Excepcin at Parsons School of Design fills the bill. It starts with a kind of special-effects installation, a video of what looks like fast-flowing river projected across the gallery floor and surging toward you. You walk over it to enter the show, and the shuddering current makes you feel woozy, as if you dont quite know what your feet are doing.

title: Ingrid LaFleur, Artist and Curator, Enters Detroits Mayoral Race
description: Actors have been mayors (Clint Eastwood). So have singers (Sonny Bono),  high school football coaches (Rob Ford) and media moguls (Michael Bloomberg). Why not somebody from the art world?

title: A Sputtering Violin: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments This Week
description: In addition to reviews, features and news published during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what theyve been hearing: the notes that sent shivers down their spines, the memorable voices, the quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

title: Federal Complaint in Bomb Threat Case
description: A federal complaint unsealed on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan charged Juan Thompson, a former reporter, with making more than a half-dozen bomb threats against Jewish community centers, schools and a museum, partly in an effort to intimidate a former girlfriend.

title: Share Your Buffy the Vampire Slayer Fan Fiction
description: The New York Times would like readers to share their own stories about Buffy and the Scooby Gang.

title: European Union, Nintendo Switch, Logan: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Infant and Fetus Remains Are Found at Ex-Home for Unwed Mothers in Ireland
description: DUBLIN  The local historian had been telling the authorities for years that dead infants might have been buried in an old sewage system on the grounds of a former home for unmarried mothers and their children in the west of Ireland.

title: Gay Histories, Close Enough to Touch. (But Dont.)
description: On most nights, the subterranean sex club Paddles in Chelsea is home to patrons  straight or gay, depending on the hour  absorbed in threesomes and other adventurous behavior. But on a recent afternoon, as dozens of men and women explored its low-lit rooms, the only sex was in the storytelling.

title: Review: Giselle Bounds With Experience
description: Where does a ballerina go when she quits ballerinadom? When Julie Kent retired from American Ballet Theater in 2015, after 29 years, she had become a company figurehead: a beloved emblem of stylishness and sensitivity onstage across a wide repertory, charmingly natural in nondancing appearances. What happens to all that experience?

title: For NBCUniversal, Snap Is Fountain of Youth
description: NBCUniversals hottest new mini-series stars its boss, Steve Burke, as the explorer Juan Ponce de Len in his epic quest for the Fountain of Youth. The New York media conglomerate, housed inside the cable colossus Comcast, plunked $500 million into the supercharged stock debut of Snap on Thursday. The investment follows similar ones in a multitude of other millennial hunters.

title: Canada Today: Border Anxiety, Homelessness and Prehistoric Life
description: In many Canadian cities, winter provides a grim reminder of the civic shame of homelessness. Wherever theres a vent providing even tepid heat, homeless people often gather.

title: Protesters Disrupt Speech by Bell Curve Author at Vermont College
description: BOSTON  Hundreds of students at Middlebury College in Vermont shouted down a controversial speaker on Thursday night, disrupting a program and confronting the speaker in an encounter that turned violent and left a faculty member injured.

title: Against Protests, Republicans Must Stand Strong
description: MADISON, Wis.  Over the last few weeks, angry voters have greeted Republican congressmen in districts around the country. As someone who has confronted similar crowds before  and lived to tell about it  I have a simple message for those lawmakers: Its put-up or shut-up time.

title: U.N. Syria Mediator Reports Some Progress in Peace Talks
description: The top United Nations diplomat working to resolve the civil war in Syria reported some progress Friday after nearly 10 days of talks, saying both sides finally had agreed on what he described as a clear agenda for further negotiations.

title: The Feud That Sank Saigon
description: Buddhists against Catholics. Northerners against southerners. Civilians against the military. Capital against periphery. Ethnic Vietnamese against ethnic minorities. In 1967, anti-Communist South Vietnam was a caldron of overlapping rivalries, precipitating and reinforcing the political chaos consuming the country after President Ngo Dinh Diems 1963 assassination during a military coup.

title: Race in America: Racial Progress or Racist Progress?
description: Welcome to Times Insider Events  live programming for Times Insiders and their guests. Times Insider offers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

title: Why Our Champions Are Getting Older
description: I recently strained my rotator cuff, and I blame a pair of Olympic swimmers and Cirque du Soleil for the pain. I have been inspired of late by several sports-comeback heroes in their mid- to late 30s: Tom Brady leading the Patriots to an improbable Super Bowl win; Roger Federer overcoming Rafael Nadal in a decisive fifth set in the Australian Open to secure his 18th Grand Slam title. Others have remained dominant well into their 30s  Serena Williams won her 23rd Grand Slam singles championship at 35, also at the Australian Open, defeating her 36-year-old sister in the final.

title: In Quest to Sound European, M.L.S. Displays a United Front
description: There are two new teams in Major League Soccer, which opened its 22nd season on Friday night. One of them is Minnesota United. And the other is Atlanta, er, United.

title: Ever Heard of Bill Cosby?
description: The comedian Bill Cosby needs a jury. Under the Constitution, he is entitled to an impartial and local jury trial. The problem is that after decades in public life everyone knows him, and from months of news coverage almost everyone knows he has been accused of sexual assault by many women. How can a court find fair jurors in an age of media overload?

title: Ren Hang, Provocative Chinese Photographer, Dies at 29
description: BEIJING  Ren Hang, a Chinese photographer whose erotic images of naked young models arranged in provocative poses offered an unfiltered glimpse into the intimate lives of Chinese youth, died on Feb. 24 in Beijing. He was 29.

title: How Gorsuch the Clerk Met Kennedy the Justice: A Tale of Luck
description: WASHINGTON  It was a stroke of luck that landed Neil M. Gorsuch in the chambers of Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on a summer day nearly a quarter-century ago.

title: Nicholas Mosley, Novelist and Biographer, Dies at 93
description: Nicholas Mosley, an experimental writer whose 1965 novel Accident became the basis for a Joseph Losey film with a screenplay by Harold Pinter, and who wrote an unsparing two-volume biography of his father, the fascist leader Sir Oswald Mosley, died on Feb. 28 at his home in London. He was 93.

title: Spencer Hays, Business Magnate and Art Collector, Dies at 80
description: Spencer Hays, an apparel and publishing magnate, art collector and former Bible salesman who, with his wife, Marlene, donated more than 600 paintings by Matisse, Bonnard, Vuillard and other masters to the French government last fall, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: The Eyes of San Francisco in a Texas Courtroom: The Sequel
description: A few weeks after a security officer nearly booted him from a federal courthouse in Dallas for live-tweeting Mark Zuckerbergs testimony there, Mike Isaac, a technology reporter at The Times, got an unexpected message on LinkedIn.

title: Mets Prospect Took to Pitching After the Troubles Were Left Behind
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  P. J. Conlon is an undersized pitching prospect for the Mets who has yet to get above Class A in the minor leagues. But across the Atlantic Ocean, he is already gaining fame.

title: Quotation of the Day: North Korea Is Alluring But Murky For Investors
description: The country is like an El Dorado that lures people in. Theyre willing to risk everything because the payout is so high.

title: United States Ramps Up Airstrikes Against Al Qaeda in Yemen
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military on Friday carried out a second night of airstrikes against suspected Qaeda terrorists in Yemen in what Pentagon officials said was part of a larger campaign to roll back territorial gains the group has made in the past two years.

title: Trump Got Nearly $1 Million in Energy-Efficiency Subsidies in 2012
description: The Trump White House has wasted no time in targeting pro-climate policies, freezing energy-efficiency standards finalized during the last days of the Obama administration. Its America First Energy Plan makes no mention of renewable energy or energy efficiency, and it is focused on fossil fuels.

title: Notre Dames Hockey Helmets Sure Look Familiar
description: Almost immediately after Jeff Jackson became coach of the Notre Dame mens hockey team in 2005, he decided that his players should wear gold helmets, just as the Fighting Irish football team does.
