title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Two Hollywood classics released just a decade apart, two superlative poets joined in friendship and legacy  how often do books about cultural pillars of the American 20th century arrive so neatly paired? Our selections this week feature satisfying studies of High Noon and Casablanca, and innovative biographies of Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Lowell. Fiction lovers will welcome new work by Jim Shepard, David Grossman and Mohsin Hamid. When youve finished reading, go out and take a walk: in the city (Flneuse: Women Walk the City in Paris, New York, Tokyo, Venice and London) or in the country (The Nature Fix: Why Nature Makes Us Happier, Healthier and More Creative). Itll do you good, we promise.

title: Radioactive Boars in Fukushima Thwart Residents Plans to Return Home
description: They descend on towns and villages, plundering crops and rampaging through homes. They occasionally attack humans. But perhaps most dangerous of all, the marauders carry with them highly radioactive material.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Louvre Attendants Strike After Vermeer Bottleneck
description: PARIS  Dozens of museum attendants at the Louvre went on strike on Thursday to protest what they said was the museums poor handling of crowds at a temporary exhibition dedicated to Vermeer, with another strike possible on Friday.

title: Game Change Authors Writing Book About Trump the Man and His Campaign
description: On election night last year, the political journalists and analysts Mark Halperin and John Heilemann appeared on The Late Show With Stephen Colbert and offered stunned commentary to their ashen-faced host as Donald J. Trumps victory became clear.

title: A Soothing Skyline and a Weimaraner, the Most Architectural of Dogs
description: NEW HAVEN  When Deborah Berke took over as dean of the Yale School of Architecture last year, she gut-renovated an apartment here, turning a two-bedroom into a one-bedroom by knocking out a wall.

title: Review: The Soundtrack Is the Star of Whos Crazy?
description: In late 1964, Tom White, an American living in Paris, encountered the avant-garde troupe the Living Theater, also from the United States. While the group was waiting for its leaders, Julian Beck and Judith Malina, to return from the States (they were serving brief prison terms related to back taxes; the long story was recounted in The New York Times last year), the members paired up with Mr. White to make a film. That loose-narrative movie, Whos Crazy?, had its New York premiere last year and is screening here again this week.

title: Text to Text: The Outsiders and Bored, Broke and Armed
description: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through March 25. Gladstone Gallery, 530 West 21st Street, Manhattan; 212-206-7606, gladstonegallery.com.

title: In Orchestrating Barcelona Rally, Neymar Proves Ready for the Baton
description: There was no unseemly argument, no heated, agonized debate. Barcelona had five minutes to play, and a penalty kick to take. Lionel Messi, the worlds finest player, had not missed one all season; indeed, he had scored one about a half an hour earlier.

title: Irish Whiskeys Rise Above the Annual Celebration
description: Its that time of year again, when St. Patricks Day approaches and the thoughts of beverage writers across the land turn to Irish whiskey. But for American spirits drinkers, Irish whiskey is clearly no longer a once-a-year fling.

title: A Dutch Masters Surreal Visions
description: If you happened to see Werner Herzogs video installation Hearsay of the Soul in the 2012 Whitney Biennial, you have already caught sight of the startlingly experimental etched vistas of the 17th-century Dutch master of the Golden Age, Hercules Segers. Greatly magnified details of his strangely barren, slightly unreal landscapes dominated Mr. Herzogs five-channel video installation, which paid homage to Dutch artistry.

title: Review: Give a Student Some Offal, and Youll Regret It in Raw
description: Raw, Julia Ducournaus jangly opera of sexual and dietary awakening, is an exceptionally classy-looking movie about deeply horrifying behavior. Infusing each scene with a cold, unwelcoming beauty, the Belgian cinematographer Ruben Impens makes his camera complicit in the trashy goings-on. Sneaking beneath bedsheets and sliding over young flesh, his lens takes us places we may not want to go.

title: Jon Huntsman Is Said to Accept Post as Ambassador to Russia
description: WASHINGTON  Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has accepted President Trumps offer to be ambassador to Russia, people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday, taking on a diplomatic assignment that would be challenging in the best of times but is more so now, given the questions swirling around the Trump campaign and its links to Russia.

title: Review: Love as the World Wars, in The Ottoman Lieutenant
description: The Ottoman Lieutenant is an overwrought nurse romance merged with a history lesson, a combination that is hard to take as seriously as the film wants to be taken.

title: Review: A Combustible Pair Find Love in The Other Half
description: Acting prowess is in vast abundance in the moody romance The Other Half. Tatiana Maslany (the dazzling star of Orphan Black) plays Emily, a bipolar painter and teacher; Tom Cullen (Lord Gillingham on Downton Abbey) portrays Nickie, a brooding cabdriver and musician whose brother vanished almost five years ago. When these two meet, passionate sparks fly, but not without consequences.

title: The Truth About the WikiLeaks C.I.A. Cache
description: On Tuesday morning, WikiLeaks released an enormous cache of documents that it claimed detailed C.I.A. hacking tools. Immediately afterward, it posted two startling tweets asserting that C.I.A. hacker malware posed a threat to journalists and others who require secure communication by infecting iPhone and Android devices and bypassing encrypted message apps such as Signal and WhatsApp.

title: From Alexei Jawlensky, Abstract Faces at Full Intensity
description: The son of a colonel in the imperial Russian Army, Alexei Jawlensky was 18 and a cadet when a visit to the All-Russian Exhibition of Industry and Art in Moscow in 1882 changed his life by introducing him to painting. Eventually he moved to Munich with Marianne von Werefkin, another artistic expat from the nobility, vacationed with Kandinsky, bought a van Gogh and studied Buddhism, yoga and theosophy.

title: Review: In This Beautiful Fantastic, a Gardener Blooms
description: With spring imminent, backyard putterers are turning their thoughts to the garden, which makes This Beautiful Fantastic, a charming tale about one, all that much sweeter.

title: Review: In Canners, One Mans Trash Is Anothers Nickel Treasure
description: Manfred Kirchheimer, born in Germany in 1931, is an indispensable New York filmmaker, a noticer and a listener without peer. His best-known work is probably Stations of the Elevated, a short documentary from 1981 that is a wordless, jazzy, poetic hymn to public transportation, graffiti and the battered glory of a rough time in the citys history. Though his new feature, Canners, takes place in the present, a relatively safer and more prosperous era, it demonstrates that New York remains, in several senses, a tough place.

title: Beware, a Notorious Broadway Bomb Is Ticking Again
description: On the wall that commemorates Broadway flops at the theater district restaurant Joe Allen  a few spots down from the sinister artwork for Carrie, the floppiest flop of all  there hangs a stardusted poster for the 1973 musical Rachael Lily Rosenbloom and Dont You Ever Forget It! To connoisseurs of stage catastrophes, that disco-infused curiosity is perched there with pedigree: Its one of just seven Broadway musicals that closed in previews. (Can a show close if it never opened? Discuss.)

title: Review: In Brimstone, the B Is for Bleak, Brutal and Bloody
description: It doesnt take long before Brimstone makes good on the promise  and threat  implicit in its title. A western horror show with an unrelenting Old and New Testament kick, it opens on an ambiguous scene that soon gives way to a world of terrors, many involving children and parents. In one scene, a fetal hand juts out of the womb; in another, a man is gutted and his entrails are draped over his still-breathing body. Its a hard, ugly world, or so the Dutch writer and director Martin Koolhoven keeps insisting for 149 grueling minutes.

title: After a Stillbirth, Tests Can Help Pinpoint the Cause
description: Some 26,000 women in the United States give birth to a stillborn child each year. Its a harrowing experience for parents, and many eventually want to know what went wrong, in part to avoid going through a similar experience in the future. But in the days after delivery, when tests to search for a cause must be conducted, doctors are often hesitant to suggest them, and grief-stricken parents often reluctant to permit them.

title: Airbnb Raises $1 Billion More in a Funding Round
description: Airbnb has raised an additional $1 billion, expanding its war chest at a time of increased investor interest in fast-growing businesses.

title: This Weeks Movies: March 10, 2017
description: The New York Times film critics review Kong: Skull Island, Personal Shopper and The Sense of an Ending."

title: Parents of Girls Scalded to Death in Homeless Housing May Sue
description: The parents of two toddlers scalded to death by steam from a radiator in a Bronx apartment for the homeless have filed a legal document that could pave the way for lawsuits against the city, the landlord and a nonprofit social services company that handled their case.

title: New Hamas Charter Would Name Occupiers, Not Jews, as the Enemy
description: CAIRO  Hamas, the Palestinian Islamist group that has governed the Gaza Strip for a decade, is drafting a new platform to present a more pragmatic and cooperative face to the world, Hamas officials confirmed on Thursday.

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: In Natural Opium, a Tourist Attuned to Every Indignity
description: NATURAL OPIUMSome Travelers TalesBy Diane JohnsonOut of print

title: The Making of the Making of a Movie
description: Michel Gondry, the writer and director of Be Kind Rewind,  discusses his process.

title: Review: Aging Magician, a Fable Complete With Complexities
description: Harold, a middle-aged, solitary sad sack, earns his living making and repairing clocks. What really consumes him, though, is the childrens book he has been writing for years, about an aging magician who must pass on his Book of Secrets to a receptive child, a magician heir. But before he can do so, the magician collapses and is rushed to a hospital.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: A Brand Name for a Hedge Fund Happy Hour: Trumps Mar-a-Lago
description: The invitation suggests your run-of-the-mill weekday evening of drinks, canaps and networking for the hedge fund crowd.

title: First Underwater Video of Elusive Trues Beaked Whales
description: Trues beaked whales look a bit like weird dolphins with big foreheads, fat bellies and small flippers. Theyre about the size of an elephant. And yet they are so elusive that most scientists who study them have never seen one in the wild.

title: With Rebels Gone, Colombia Jumps Into the Pot Industry
description: CORINTO, Colombia  For years, Blanca Riveros has had the same routine: After fixing breakfast and taking her son to school, she heads home to a large plastic trash bag filled with marijuana.

title: Snap Sketch: The Faces of Paris Fashion Week
description: The illustrator Damien Florbert Cuypers draws the people  and looks  at the fall/winter 2017 collections in Paris.

title: A Possible Clue in Jane Austens Glasses. Did Arsenic Kill Her?
description: LONDON  The cause of Jane Austens mysterious death at the age of 41 has been much pondered over the years. Was it a hormonal disorder? Cancer? Complications from drinking unpasteurized milk?

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: We Rounded Up Politics Stories You Shouldnt Miss
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Thats why were collecting great political feature writing from The New York Times and around the web that offers context, analysis and insight.

title: A Brooklyn Charter School Looks Past No Excuses
description: Four years ago, while reporting on the difficulties of life in Brownsville, Brooklyn, one of the poorest neighborhoods in New York, I met a school administrator named Marsha Gadsden who worked for the Ascend Public Charter Schools network. Ms. Gadsden had grown up not far away, attended prep school on a scholarship and later went to Georgetown and Harvard, and she told me she worried about the unforgiving disciplinary codes used by her employer and so many urban charter schools around the country.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: Republican Party, C.I.A., Syria: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trumps New Travel Ban May Be Hard to Beat. But States Are Trying.
description: President Trumps executive order banning travel from six predominantly Muslim countries faced a new front of opposition from the states on Thursday, as the attorney general of Washington announced that he would seek to block the order from taking effect next week.

title: Dolley Madison and Her Peers Ran Their Own Pussy-Hat Brigade
description: Before there were pussy hats, there were the women of Revolutionary-era America.

title: Fans Honor The Notorious B.I.G.
description: Fans paid tribute to Christopher Wallace, a.k.a. Biggie, on the 20th anniversary of his death by rapping their favorite lyrics on social media.

title: Steve Wolfe: Remembering Steve Speaks Volumes About an Artist
description: Steve Wolfe, an artist who died last year at 60, was known for the small, select library of trompe loeil books he created. From his first solo show in 1989, Wolfes sculptures and wall pieces were all-but-perfect replicas of worn, well-used copies of modern classics and artist monographs and catalogs  usually his own  tweaked to within a hair of the original. Initially anonymous and ordinary in appearance, these copies become exquisitely personal as you grasp the level of skill and commitment required to make them. They are labors of love.

title: Review: American Crime Fixes on Migrant Dreamers in the Fields
description: The third season of American Crime, the gritty ABC drama with an investigative heart, will unspool just as President Trumps proposed border wall will be generating a lot of discussion. The series wants a piece of that debate, but not the obvious one about cost and necessity. It wants you to ponder just why anyone would want to work the fields of the giant farms that are so important to the United States economy.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: Irans Top Leader Appears to Rebuke President as Election Nears
description: Irans top leader criticized the pace of national economic growth on Thursday in what appeared to be a rebuke of the president, who had forecast prosperous times after the 2015 accord that lifted international sanctions in exchange for nuclear limits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Lincoln and the Lost Souls

title: Reading by Numbers
description: It was only a matter of time before big data came for literature.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: Stephen Ross, Economist Who Developed Arbitrage Pricing Theory, Dies at 73
description: Stephen A. Ross, a seminal theorist whose work over three decades reshaped the field of financial economics, died on March 3 at his home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 73.

title: Vestiges of Old Harlem
description: David Vades Joseph, who grew up in Harlem, photographs the neighborhood as he knew it.

title: Images of Old-School Harlem, Rapidly Vanishing
description: Is Harlem coming or going? Evolving into its next iteration or disappearing under the onslaught of change? It depends on whom you ask. For the photographer David Vades Joseph, who grew up in the neighborhoods Hamilton Heights section, Harlem is an idea that is vanishing daily. Certain mom and pop stores that Ive walked past most of my life arent there anymore, Mr. Vades Joseph, 30, said recently. Buildings that I grew up with are being torn down and replaced by condominiums. Its haunting, in a way.

title: Marilyn Young, Historian Who Challenged U.S. Foreign Policy, Dies at 79
description: Marilyn B. Young, a leftist, feminist, antiwar historian who challenged conventional interpretations of American foreign policy, died on Feb. 19 at her home in Manhattan, where she was a longtime professor at New York University. She was 79.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Sustained by Saints and Song, This Little Italy Shopkeeper Hangs On
description: E. Rossi & Company, an Italian gift shop on Grand Street near Mulberry Street in Little Italy, has become something of a museum of Italian-American pop culture.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: Chris Bertish Becomes First to Cross Atlantic by Paddleboard
description: As dawn broke over the Caribbean on Thursday, Chris Bertish, bearded and shirtless, paddled toward Antiguas English Harbour more than three months after leaving Africa, successfully finishing the first crossing of the Atlantic Ocean in a stand-up paddleboard.

title: Where Do You Go on a Saturday Night in New York?
description: Saturday night in New York. Its when Times Square, the Village and Williamsburg are even more jammed  inside bars, restaurants, clubs and on the sidewalks. But there are many New Yorks, and many Saturday nights, and not all of them unfold in the same old places. Thats where we need your help:

title: Howard Hodgkin
description: Howard Hodgkin was one of the most admired artists of the postwar period.

title: Howard Hodgkin, Whose Paintings Were Coded With Emotion, Dies at 84
description: Howard Hodgkin, a British artist whose lush, semiabstract paintings, aquiver with implicit drama, established him as one of the most admired artists of the postwar period, died on Thursday in London. He was 84.

title: From Green Taxis to Taxes on Nose Jobs, Budget Tips for New York
description: Maybe the skies will continue to rain tax money in New York City, where more people are now on the city payroll than at any time in modern history. And perhaps the budget that President Trump and Republicans in Congress come up with will not slash the federal money that comes to the city.

title: Kurt Moll, German Basso Profundo, Dies at 78
description: Kurt Moll, the imposing German bass whose theatrical flair and cavernous low notes allowed him to plumb the serenity, humor and ferocity of a wide array of operatic characters created by Mozart, Strauss and Wagner, died on March 5 in Cologne, Germany. He was 78.

title: Trumps Intelligence Nominee Gets Early Lesson in Managing White House
description: WASHINGTON  If Dan Coats, President Trumps nominee to serve as the director of national intelligence, had any illusions about what he was getting into, the past seven weeks have certainly made clear the challenges he will face in a job created after the Sept. 11 attacks to coordinate the activities of the entire intelligence community.

title: Exploring Populism and Popularity
description: This newsletter is one small attempt to bring you, our audience, into the process of journalism as The New York Times expands in Australia  but how else might we listen and learn from readers and subscribers?

title: Bar Mitzvah in the Blizzard of 69
description: Dear Diary:

title: Tanning Industry, Taxed Under Obama, Cheers G.O.P. Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The tanning industry found little to celebrate during Barack Obamas presidency, but its starting to cheer up.

title: Stand Your Ground Could Get Worse
description: Republican legislators in Florida are planning to compound the deadly mischief of the states Stand Your Ground law by allowing accused killers even greater leeway to claim self-defense and immunity from prosecution in violent confrontations.

title: White House Casts Pre-emptive Doubt on Congressional Budget Office
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump showed an affinity for working the referees in his race to the White House, criticizing a federal judge as biased, panning polls as rigged and even questioning the aptitude of the nations intelligence agencies.

title: With Trump in White House, His Golf Properties Prosper
description: WASHINGTON  It is a golden age for golf  at least as far as the Trump Organization is concerned.

title: Quotation of the Day: Baylors Pride Turns to Shame in Rape Scandal
description: Let the word come out. Let it come out, the good, the bad, the ugly. Put it all on the table.

title: Yoelkis Cespedes, Half Brother of Mets Yoenis, Draws Notice
description: TOKYO  These days, many of Cubas best baseball players can be found in the major leagues in the United States. And until Cuba changes its stance on defectors, those players will not be allowed to represent the island nation in the World Baseball Classic.

title: Sessions Says Guantnamo Is a Very Fine Place for New Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Jeff Sessions said on Thursday that he would advise President Trump to send newly captured terrorism suspects to the wartime prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, which he called a very fine place, rather than to bring them to civilian court for prosecution by the Justice Department he now runs.

title: South Korea Removes President Park Geun-hye
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A South Korean court removed the president on Friday, a first in the nations history, rattling the delicate balance of relationships across Asia at a particularly tense time.

title: Brock Osweiler Traded to Browns, but He May Not Stay
description: The Houston Texans announced on Thursday that they had traded quarterback Brock Osweiler to the Cleveland Browns  though its not certain that Osweiler will throw a pass for the Browns in 2017.

title: Dismal Turnout
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Deb refers to puzzles like this as crunchy; I thought this one could have broken a tooth. Lots of uncommon midlength entries, combined with clues that seemed designed to get the mind to wander and doubt, and it took me a good long time to peck an entry hole to begin with. I did it with TAPPER at 3D, a guy whos been pretty ubiquitous in the news, and LOTT at 54A, one of those good ol boys in politics who just seemed like the worst in a simpler era (and, guess what, hes back).

title: Review: Dismantling The Glass Menagerie
description: That shattering sound you hear coming from the Belasco Theater is the celebrated director Sam Gold taking a hammer to everything thats delicate in The Glass Menagerie. The jagged, glistening shards of Tennessee Williamss breakthrough play are available for inspection in the revival that opened on Thursday night.

title: New Details Emerge in Murder Case After Ex-Officers Suicide
description: Gerard Benderoth, a retired New York City police officer and bodybuilder, was pulled over by F.B.I. agents and local police officers on Wednesday morning in a small town near the Hudson River just a short drive from his home. The agents and officers, who were investigating Mr. Benderoths links to a case involving a drug conspiracy and four murders, hoped to get him to cooperate with their inquiry, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

title: U.N. Court Declines to Reopen Bosnias Genocide Case Against Serbia
description: PARIS  The United Nations highest court on Thursday denied a request by Bosnia to reopen a 2007 case that cleared Serbia of playing an active role in the genocide committed during the war in Bosnia in the 1990s.

title: 35 Girls Killed in Guatemala Fire May Have Been Locked In
description: GUATEMALA CITY  Guatemalan human rights officials said Thursday that they believe that the 35 girls who were killed when a fire swept through a dormitory at a childrens home had been unable to escape because they were locked inside.

title: Redskins Fire G.M. Scot McCloughan on First Day of Free Agency
description: While other teams in the N.F.L. were scrambling to make deals on Thursday, the first day of free agency, the Washington Redskins announced that they had fired their general manager.

title: Keeping the Beat
description: Adam Shankman discusses his direction and choreography for the movie musical "Hairspray."

title: Davis Cup May Switch to Best-of-Three-Set Matches
description: The leaders of the International Tennis Federation took a significant step on Thursday toward ending a 117-year tradition when they voted unanimously in favor of a proposal that would switch the Davis Cup to best-of-three-set matches.

title: Ryan Dempster Returns From Retirement to Pitch for Canada
description: MIAMI  Ryan Dempster has not pitched in the major leagues in more than three seasons, and he is not making a comeback. At 39, after nearly 3,000 professional innings, he knows he could not withstand the rigors of a season.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Kong: Skull Island
description: Jordan Vogt-Roberts narrates a sequence from "Kong: Skull Island" with Brie Larson and Tom Hiddleston.

title: Jordan Vogt-Roberts Narrates a Scene From Kong: Skull Island
description: Expectedly, Kong does a lot of stomping and roaring in Kong: Skull Island. But he also has his softer moments  including one in this scene.

title: A Broader View vs. An Invasion: Dutch Voters Speak Out on Immigration
description: Dutch voters go to the polls next week after a loud and divisive campaign that focused on immigration, the first of a series of European elections this year that could propel populist forces into power. Geert Wilders, the virulently anti-immigrant leader of the Netherlands Party of Freedom, or P.V.V., has led the charge on the immigration debate, drawing in parties on the mainstream right.

title: WikiLeaks, Donald Tusk, European Central Bank: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Corrections: March 10, 2017
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Trumps Golf Empire Raises Questions
description: The president is certainly not the first in the White House to golf, but he is the first to own a collection of golf courses, which some critics say is a conflict of interest.

title: Ex-Players Accuse N.F.L. Teams of Violating Prescription Drug Laws, Report Says
description: Former players have asserted that N.F.L. teams violated federal prescription drug laws, The Washington Post reported on Thursday after it reviewed sealed court documents from a federal lawsuit filed by the ex-players.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Love and The Vampire Diaries
description: Love, the Netflix comedy series filled with Judd Apatows signature blend of discomfort and brutal honesty, returns for Season 2: 12 episodes of misadventures in dating for the unlikely couple Gus and Mickey. And The Vampire Diaries, a CW drama that rode the wave of Twilight popularity eight seasons ago, comes to an end with an action-packed series finale.

title: Word + Quiz: idolatry
Mike Krzyzewskis Secret to Staying Relevant: Bitmoji
description: The man has brown eyes, a prominent nose, a few wrinkles on his forehead, well-kept dark hair and a tight smile.

title: The Week in Pictures: March 10, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: An Early Spring
description: What was the weather like where you live this winter? Was it unusually mild? Are you seeing signs of spring, and, if so, did they come earlier than usual?

title: The Week in Pictures: March 10, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: Afghanistan Is Now Trumps War
description: Before the White House responds to the Pentagons latest request for a troop surge in Afghanistan to counter insurgent forces that now control substantial parts of the country, it would serve administration officials well to examine the long history of deluded thinking about what could be accomplished if the United States committed more troops to the effort.

title: A Bill So Bad Its Awesome
description: It has long been obvious to anyone following health policy that Republicans would never devise a workable replacement for Obamacare. But the bill unveiled this week is worse than even the cynics expected; its awfulness is almost surreal. And the process by which it came to be tells you a lot about the state of the G.O.P.

title: The Republican Health Care Crackup
description: The Republican health care bill could represent the moment when the old order of American politics completely cracks up, the end of a certain era in American politics.

title: The Bombs of Steve Bannon
description: Like much of the world, Ive been trying to understand Stephen K. Bannon, the chief strategist and guiding force behind the chaos of Donald Trumps bizarre presidency  chaos by design.

title: Design Competition, or Ideological Crisis?
description: Donald J. Trump ran on a platform of building a wall on the southern border of the United States when 650 miles of wall is already built. If he does nothing, he needs only to inform people that the existing 650 miles of wall (O.K., its a non-contiguous fence) is working.

title: Why Is Mr. Tillerson in a Perpetual State of Duck and Cover?
description: For a guy who has spent his life delivering messages  as a businessman, reality TV star, presidential candidate and now president  President Trump is doing an abysmal job explaining his view of the world and Americas place in it. Normally, that would increase the importance of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. But if Mr. Trumps messages are confusing, Mr. Tillersons are almost nonexistent.

title: John Kasich: End the Partisan Warfare on Health Care
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Americans are relying on leaders in Washington to fix health care, not engage in yet another unproductive partisan standoff. In 2010, one side of the political aisle in Congress, the Democrats, chose to fix health care unilaterally, without bipartisan support. The result was Obamacare, which has run up government spending while failing to drive down the cost of health care.

title: Want to Fix Schools? Go to the Principals Office
description: CHICAGO  Gregory Jones, the principal of Kenwood high school, has learned that when spring finally arrives in Chicago, trouble often arrives with it. He saw it happen again on a warm afternoon last May, when students were lingering outside the school, on the citys South Side, and a fight broke out.

title: Questions for: Trauma, Then Triumph: The New York Times College Scholarship Winners
description: Article: Trauma, Then Triumph: The New York Times College Scholarship Winners

title: Does Better Sports Equipment Unfairly Improve Athletic Ability?
description: Have you ever longed for a newer, faster and better bike, sneaker, racket, stick, ball or other piece of equipment?

title: Jimmy Kimmel Would Pay to Watch Trump and Cruz Eat Together
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: The 2.26.17 Issue
description: RE: THE FUTURE OF WORK ISSUE

title: A Boy Finds a Most Bizarre Creature in This Middle-Grade Novel
description: ME AND MARVIN GARDENSBy Amy Sarig King243 pp. Arthur A. Levine Books/Scholastic. $16.99.(Middle grade; ages 8 to 12)

title: Picture Books That Deliver Eureka Moments
description: LAUNDRY DAYWritten and illustrated by Jessixa Bagley32 pp. A Neal Porter Book/ Roaring Brook Press. $17.99.(Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: She Persisted: Girls Find a Way to Live on Their Own Terms
description: PRINCESS CORA AND THE CROCODILEBy Laura Amy Schlitz Illustrated by Brian Floca74 pp. Candlewick Press. $16.99.(Early chapter book; ages 6 to 8)

title: Are You Middle Class Enough to Deserve a Health Care Tax Break?
description: Something fascinating happened during the most recent rewrite of the Obamacare repair bill: Its authors tried to define who is middle class enough to be deserving of a big tax handout.

title: Steady U.S. Job Growth Sets Stage for Fed to Raise Interest Rates
description: A wave of hiring in February  President Trumps first full month in office  pointed to a strong foundation for the nations economy, providing further evidence for the Federal Reserve that the moment to raise interest rates has come.

title: Even Before the Wall, Migrants Find the U.S. Forbidding
description: SONOYTA, Mexico  Reiner Ros Gmez, who is from Hondurass capital, Tegucigalpa, lifted his shirt last week to expose a scar about 12 inches long in the middle of his back, where he said a machete hit him as he fled the robbers who were trying to steal his pay: 2,800 lempiras, or about $119, for half a months work in construction.

title: When Is a Drought Over? A Wet California Wants to Know
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood Reservoir is nestled in a basin surrounded, usually, by dusty brown hillsides, broken up by the occasional dry wisp of shrubbery. Not these days. After yet another burst of rain the other day, the hills were transformed into lush fields of knee-high grass, spotted with purple flowers. And the reservoir? As high as it has been in years.

title: When Mothers Bully Back
description: Many years ago, I threw a playground ball at the head of a boy who was repeatedly dunking my young son underwater. Before I threw the ball, I shouted at him to stop, but he continued. I was at the other end of the pool, maybe a six-second swim away, but my 5-year-old son was gasping and pleading, and the fastest way to make my point was to throw the ball.

title: Wisconsin and Minnesota Await Latest Round in Ice-Melting Rivalry
description: Since earning the preseason No. 1 ranking, Wisconsin has yet to slip from its perch atop college womens hockey. Last weekend, the Badgers (31-2-4) captured their third straight Western Collegiate Hockey Association tournament title, winning what is regularly the toughest conference in the nation.

title: Prewar Is So Last Year
description: Prewar charm in New York City is defined by original details like crown moldings, built-in bookshelves, coffered ceilings and fireplaces, some more decorative than others. But driven by design trends and the need for more space, some apartment buyers are doing what some would consider unthinkable: tearing out traditional finishes.

title: Revolution? What Revolution? Russia Asks 100 Years Later
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin plans to sit out the centenary of the Russian Revolution.

title: Friday Mailbag: A Surprising Advertisement and Some Missing Fathers
description: On Thursday the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Scott Pruitt, said that carbon dioxide was not a primary contributor to global warming. That statement was at odds with the global scientific consensus on climate change  and with Pruitts own agency. But readers wouldnt be wrong to think that he came to this conclusion by way of The Times.

title: Who Needs Manhattan? Hanging With the Locals on Bell Boulevard
description: Johno Gargan stepped out of a wind-whipped evening and into Bourbon Street, a large New Orleans-style restaurant whose long, busy bar is one of the centers of the bustling night life scene in Bayside, Queens.

title: Charlie Crist, Once a Republican, Takes a Seat Among Democrats in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Charlie Crist, Democrat of Florida, has had many identities. Governor. Senate candidate. State attorney general. Education commissioner. State legislator. Democrat. Republican. Independent.

title: Fukushima, 6 Years On: Empty and Eerie
description: Inside the exclusion zone surrounding Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, homes and restaurants are still abandoned despite Japans plan to lift the evacuation order.

title: The Lonely Towns of Fukushima
description: Thousands of people fled from their homes, offices and schools six years ago after a devastating earthquake and tsunami caused a meltdown at a nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan. To this day, few have returned, leaving behind ghost towns where eerie signs of the departed linger under a caking of dust.

description: Who will lead American International Group?

title: Trump Supporters Have the Most to Lose in the G.O.P. Repeal Bill
description: The people who stand to lose the most in tax credits under the House Republican health plan tended to support Donald J. Trump over Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election, according to a new Upshot analysis.

description: This short documentary introduces viewers to lowrider fans in Odessa, Tex., and their tricked-out cars that stand up on hydraulics. Ben Steinbauer, the filmmaker, writes:

title: South Korea, Republican Party, Jobs Report: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Afghans Who Worked for U.S. Are Told Not to Apply for Visas, Advocates Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghans who worked for the American military and government are being told that they cannot apply for special visas to the United States, even though Afghanistan is not among the countries listed in President Trumps new travel ban, according to advocates for Afghan refugees.

title: My Grandmothers Story Is Ending as Mine Begins
description: My grandmother knew shed succumb to dementia long before she began to lose her memory, as her two older sisters had shared the same fate before they died. She fought against time to write her life story, but she will never see her dream realized.

title: In Paris, a Place for Coffee, Cocktails and Small Plates
description: In Paris, premium coffee, craft cocktails and Mediterranean small plates would have been an incongruous combination not that long ago. But Bonhomie, the first dining venture from the group behind the Parisian cocktail bars Little Red Door and Lulu White, brings those elements together harmoniously.

title: When in Doubt, Make Her Laugh
description: When John Hughes met Kristen Welker, his first thought was that she was out of his league, but his ability to make her laugh helped win her over.

title: For NBCs Kristen Welker, Love Took Its Time
description: Working as a television reporter covering the White House isnt conducive to dating  the hours are long, the schedule unpredictable  and Kristen Welkers love life was suffering.

title: New York Today: Winter Weather, Signs of Spring
description: Updated, 8:46 a.m.

title: Whats Under Discussion at One of Chinas Biggest Political Gatherings
description: BEIJING  Its that time again, when more than 5,000 delegates to Chinas National Peoples Congress and its advisory body, the Chinese Peoples Political Consultative Conference, meet in Beijing to endorse legislation and discuss government plans for the coming year. They talk about their policy ideas with the local media too, and coverage of their proposals and the online comments they attract provide glimpses into some of the issues on the minds of Chinese today.

title: Wine Bar Sues Trump and Hotel, Claiming Illegal Advantage
description: Diane Gross and Khalid Pitts, the owners of the Cork Wine Bar in Washington, are no strangers to publicity.

description: This interview with Mike Ettling, president of SAP SuccessFactors, a human resources software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

description: DEAD LETTERSBy Caite Dolan-Leach332 pp. Random House, $27.

title: When a Swarm of Velocipedes Overtook New York
description: Q. Bicycles have become an integral part of New York over the years. But when did bicycles first gain popularity in the city?

title: 11 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times stories from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: The N.B.A.s Turkish Thunder Excels at a Painful Task
description: ATLANTA  Ersan Ilyasova has, for many years, been a fine basketball player. A 6-foot-10 power forward for the Atlanta Hawks, Ilyasova was averaging 13.7 points and 5.8 rebounds a game through Friday. He is a dependable defender and an excellent outside shooter. He even has a cool nickname: Turkish Thunder.

title: The Story After the Story for a 16-Year-Old Refugee With Dashed Hopes
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: What the President Could Learn From Professional Economists
description: Michael T. Flynn, who briefly served as national security adviser, gave President Trump at least one piece of excellent advice.

title: As a Girl She Spent Time in the Library. Now Shes Giving It $20 Million.
description: Merryl H. Tisch, the former chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, and her husband, James S. Tisch, the president and chief executive of Loews Corporation, are giving $20 million to the New York Public Library to expand and strengthen its education programming, from early literacy classes to technology training.

title: A New Memoir From the Author of Whip Smart Explores Her Family Origins
description: ABANDON ME MemoirsBy Melissa Febos308 pp. Bloomsbury. $26.

title: California Today: Droughts Over, Right? Not So Fast, State Says
description: Good morning.

title: The @realDonaldTrump Doctrine
description: Diplomacy in 140 characters.

title: What to Do if You Have Medical Debt
description: The share of people with medical debt has fallen in recent years, but past-due medical bills remain a stubborn burden, especially among younger adults, according to reports published this month by the Urban Institute.

title: Marchs Book Club Pick: Exit West, by Mohsin Hamid
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: How Gigi Loizzo, Guggenheim Museums Retail Chief, Spends Her Sundays
description: As the director of retail strategy and operations for the Guggenheim Museum, Gigi Loizzo selects the items sold in the museums store and is in charge of building its e-commerce site. She commutes into Manhattan from her home in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx five days a week, so on the weekends, she prefers to keep things local. Ms. Loizzo, 55, lives in a townhouse with her husband, Angel Molina, 57, a recent retiree; their daughter, Maya Luz Molina, 29, an accessories designer; their three dogs, Bruno, Bad Betty and Larry; and a cat, New Kitty.

title: Protests Erupt in South Korea After President Park Geun-hye Is Ousted
description: Silence fell over thousands of supporters of South Koreas president, Park Geun-hye, as the countrys Constitutional Court announced it was removing her from office on Friday. The unanimous ruling capped months of turmoil for a country that has been gripped by the corruption scandal that brought down Ms. Park.

title: Pressed Into Caregiving Sooner Than Expected
description: It was August, and Gina Rinehart was preparing for another school year as a special-education teacher in Hemet, Calif., when she got the call: Her father, Floyd Hall, was facing surgery to remove a tumor in his lung.

title: Nigerias President, Muhammadu Buhari, Returns Home, but His Health Remains a Mystery
description: LONDON  President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria returned home on Friday after spending seven weeks in Britain on a vacation that turned into an extended medical leave, with questions about his health and about the stability of Africas most populous country remaining unanswered.

title: Reporting From Syria, an American With a Point of View and a Message
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  On a stretch of road in northern Syria, a missile screamed from the sky and obliterated a car, killing an Islamist militant and leaving a wreck of twisted metal in an olive grove.

title: Illegal, Undocumented, Unauthorized: The Terms of Immigration Reporting
description: Illegal immigrant. Unauthorized immigrant. Undocumented immigrant. Illegal alien. Migrant. Noncitizen.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Warm-Ups, Sex After 60 and Teens Behaving Badly
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: The Story of O: A Recollection by Oliver Sackss Surviving Partner
description: INSOMNIAC CITYNew York, Oliver, and MeBy Bill HayesIllustrated. 291 pp. Bloomsbury. $27.

title: A Japanese Womans Life in Art, Made in the Village
description: HARMLESS LIKE YOUBy Rowan Hisayo Buchanan308 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: Intertwined Lives Cast Light on Korean Society
description: EVERYTHING BELONGS TO USBy Yoojin Grace Wuertz356 pp. Random House. $27.

title: A Science Journalist Foresees One Grand Explanation for the Universe
description: CONVERGENCEThe Idea at the Heart of Science: How the Different Disciplines Are Coming Together to Tell One Coherent, Interlocking Story, and Making Science the Basis for Other Forms of KnowledgeBy Peter Watson543 pp. Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: Vitaly Mutko, Russias Deputy Premier, Is Barred From FIFA Leadership
description: World soccers governing body, FIFA, has barred Russias deputy prime minister, Vitaly Mutko, from seeking re-election to his position as a top executive of the organization.

title: Margaret Atwood on What The Handmaids Tale Means in the Age of Trump
description: In the spring of 1984 I began to write a novel that was not initially called The Handmaids Tale. I wrote in longhand, mostly on yellow legal notepads, then transcribed my almost illegible scrawlings using a huge German-keyboard manual typewriter Id rented.

title: Sean Spicers Briefings, Cringe TV for an Audience of One
description: As long as you dont care too much about facts, you can learn a lot from a Sean Spicer daily briefing.

title: Why One School Lives as Another Dies in the Same Building
description: What is the distance between progress and failure?

title: Trumps Climate Views: Combative, Conflicting and Confusing
description: Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, drew criticism on Thursday for saying that carbon dioxide was not a primary contributor to global warming, contradicting years of established science. But his boss, President Trump, has similarly raised doubts about the cause of global warming and has said a great deal more on the subject  as part of an argument, an applause line, a punch line or an insult.

title: Jackboot Germany: A New History of the Gestapo
description: THE GESTAPO The Myth and Reality of Hitlers Secret PoliceBy Frank McDonough309 pp. Skyhorse Publishing. $24.99.

title: Size Matters in Fay Weldons Novel of Aristocratic Manners
description: BEFORE THE WARBy Fay Weldon298 pp. St. Martins Press. $26.99.

title: Another Woman at the March Madness Mike? That Only Took 2 Decades
description: When Debbie Antonelli got the phone call from CBS Sports a month ago, asking her if she was interested in working this years N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament as an on-air analyst, she said, Yes, of course. How could she not be?

title: A $2,000 Room and Stale Pastry? When Luxury Travel Goes Awry
description: Cristina Verger, a wedding and event planner, arrived at the Hotel Boscolo in Milan eager to mix business with pleasure. With the hotels room rates topping $2,000 a night, her expectations were high.

title: When the Kids Crash Your BBC Interview
description: There are well-known drawbacks to working from home: the isolation, the need for self-discipline.

title: When Japan Had a Third Gender
description: A figure in a translucent kimono coyly holds a fan. Another arranges an iris in a vase. Are they men or women?

title: Emily Coatess Incarnations: Quantum Leaps, When Physics Meets Dance
description: As colleagues at Yale University, the former New York City Ballet dancer Emily Coates and the particle physicist Sarah Demers have collaborated on classes, lessons and a textbook. The course they designed and taught together, Physics of Dance, introduced students to concepts from each discipline using the other. Taking that teamwork to the stage, Ms. Coates unveils a new work at Danspace Project starting Thursday, March 16. Part lecture, part performance, Incarnations addresses topics ranging from Newtons corporeality to the Higgs boson particle. An early showing of the piece, in 2015, included a winning demonstration of how George Balanchine, who defined a high-speed American style of ballet, finessed the physics of the pirouette. Ms. Coates will be joined by Ms. Demers and the dancers Lacina Coulibaly, Irne Hultman and Jon Kinzel  and the music director Will Orzo. The postmodern visionary Yvonne Rainer, with whom Ms. Coates has danced, will also make a brief appearance. (danspaceproject.org)

title: Groundhog Day Offers Repetition, Offers Repetition
description: Bill Murrays indelible performance as a jaded, delightfully obnoxious weatherman in the 1993 film Groundhog Day is a hard act to follow  even if the movie proved that repetition offers comic rewards. In any case, after a well-received run in London last summer, a new musical based on the movie about that weatherman having to relive the same day repeatedly, arrives on Broadway this month (hopefully bringing spring weather along with it).

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Should Trump Get Credit for Good Jobs Numbers?
description: The first monthly jobs report to reflect the state of the economy during the Trump presidency is quite good. Theres not much to dislike about the 235,000 jobs added in February, nor an unemployment rate that ticked down to 4.7 percent, nor an average hourly earnings rise of 0.2 percent.

title: True North: Marsden Hartleys Maine at the Met Breuer
description: The painter Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) ranged far and wide during his career, but when he returned to his home state for good in 1937, declaring his intention to be the painter of Maine, he seemed to find an intellectual birthright he had been seeking his whole life.

title: Sean Spicers Quick Twitter Reaction to Jobs Report May Break a Rule
description: Oops.

title: A Tribe Called Red and Clap! Clap! in a Cross-Borough Double Bill
description: Ancient traditions plus modern electronics: Its one recipe for music that brings a human element to the digital dance floor and could introduce a new audience to venerable sounds. Two versions of that approach are due in New York on Friday, March 17, with timing that makes it plausible to attend them both.

title: Julia Bullock and Sarah Connolly Offer Enchantments New and Old
description: Ever since its meticulous restoration in 2013, the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, with its mahogany wainscoting and enormous fireplace, has become an intimate space for chamber music and recitals. On Wednesday, March 15, the velvety-voiced British mezzo-soprano Sarah Connolly presents an enticing recital of songs by Copland, Berlioz, Schumann and Poulenc, accompanied by the pianist Joseph Middleton, in this inviting setting. With flexible seating, the room accommodates 140 or so people. This program will be presented twice; the second performance is on Friday. (armoryonpark.org)

title: The Odyssey Explores the Life of Jacques Cousteau
description: Its Homeric title notwithstanding, Jrme Salles The Odyssey is less an epic than a standard biopic of the explorer-turned-filmmaker Jacques-Yves Cousteau, as played by Lambert Wilson.

title: Yes, Your Sleep Schedule Is Making You Sick
description: Jet lag makes everyone miserable. But it makes some people mentally ill.

title: Allies Fear Trump Is Eroding Americas Moral Authority
description: PARIS  When the State Department released its annual human rights report last week, it contained many of the usual tough American judgments of other countries. Iran was criticized for restricting freedom of religion and the media; Russia for discriminating against minorities; Eritrea for using torture; Bulgaria for violence against migrants and asylum seekers. The list went on.

title: Former N.Y. Comic, Reporting From Aleppo
description: Bilal Abdul Kareem is a Muslim convert and former comedian from New York. In the last few years, hes made hundreds of news reports from Syria.

title: As VW Pleads Guilty in U.S. Over Diesel Scandal, Trouble Looms in Europe
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen took a big step toward resolving its legal problems in the United States when it pleaded guilty on Friday to its vast emissions deception. But in Europe, its troubles may be just beginning.

title: Beef Barley Soup With Lemon
description: A hearty winter soup is given a bright new twist with the addition of spinach and lemon.

title: Beef Barley Soup Lightens Up
description: Most beef barley soups are like stews  so thick with grains and chunks of meat that your spoon practically stands up even when youre not holding on.

title: Single? No Children? No Will? Big Mistake
description: You would think I would know better.

title: Detentions and Travel Orders Coincide With Dip in Interest in Coming to America
description: It should have been a routine flight from Paris to Houston for Henry Rousso, a prominent French historian and a Holocaust scholar. Instead, it became another high-profile and unflattering incident for United States customs authorities who have been tasked with enforcing President Trumps border security initiatives.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: Newfound Fame for Stubbs & Wootton Slippers, the Bumper Sticker for Your Foot
description: Eric Edwards, 32, and a general manager of a bakery in Houston, and Wilbur L. Ross Jr., 79, and the commerce secretary for the Trump administration, have at least one thing in common. They both are devoted clients of the footwear brand Stubbs & Wootton, known for its patterned and embroidered slippers.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are on the Upper West Side, in Greenwich Village and in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: The Hills Are Alive With the Sound of Julie Andrews and Henson Puppets
description: On a wintry morning last month, Julie Andrews and her daughter Emma Walton Hamilton breezed into the Jim Henson Companys Creature Shop in Queens, where they warmly greeted puppets hanging limply from a stand.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Cries From Syria, on HBO, Is a Grim Look at That Nations s War
description: Six years into the Syrian war, weve grown accustomed to the images of death and devastation. But from its first frames, in which water laps at the body of a boy washed ashore after the boat he was on capsized, its clear that Cries From Syria is still going to be hard to watch.

title: The Artist Jimmie Durham: A Long Time Gone, but Welcomed Back
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a big night for the 76-year-old American artist Jimmie Durham. That evening, Jan. 28, was the opening of his retrospective at the Hammer Museum here, eagerly anticipated because he has not had a solo show in the United States in 22 years.

title: Pan, Moon of Saturn, Looks Like a Cosmic Ravioli (or Maybe a Walnut)
description: In a stunning set of close-ups, Pan, a diminutive moon of Saturn, looks like a floating ravioli lost in space, or a wrinkled flying saucer.

title: On the Market in New York and New Jersey
description: This weeks properties include a six-bedroom in Highland Park, N.J., and a five-bedroom Upper Brookville, N.Y.
