description: If he wants to leave

title: Too big to fail
description: Too big to fail

title: A new Fed chief
description: A new Fed chief

title: Canada Today: A Dead-End Road, Judging a Judge and Broadway
description: Last month we looked at migrants entering Canada through sometimes risky, illegal border crossings from the perspective of the Canadian side of the border. This week, Rick Rojas went to the part of New York State known as the North Country to provide the reverse border perspective through an article about how people are making their way to the border. Here are his thoughts on the experience:

title: Letter From Foreign Policy Experts on Travel Ban
description: More than 130 members of Americas foreign policy establishment denounced President Trumps revised travel ban on Friday as just as damaging to the United States interests and reputation as his original order.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: S.N.L. and the Kids Choice Awards
description: Scarlett Johansson hosts Saturday Night Live, on NBC. And this weekend is your last opportunity to stream the opening-night concert at the Pierre Boulez Saal in Berlin, designed by Frank Gehry, on arte.tv.

title: Trumps Revised Travel Ban Is Denounced by 134 Foreign Policy Experts
description: WASHINGTON  More than 130 members of Americas foreign policy establishment denounced President Trumps revised travel ban on Friday as just as damaging to the United States interests and reputation as his original order that halted refugees and froze travelers from predominantly Muslim countries.

title: In Reversal, Boston St. Patricks Day Parade Welcomes Gay Veterans Group
description: A group of gay and transgender military veterans barred from marching in the St. Patricks Day Parade in South Boston will now be allowed to participate in the March 19 event.

title: How a Mother Copes With Zika
description: At the epicenter of the Zika crisis, a mother in Recife, Brazil, struggles to care for her afflicted baby.

title: A Zika Tale in a Favela
description: RECIFE, Brazil  At night, rats often scurry on top of the thin gray mattress where Maria de Ftima dos Santos and Paulo Rogrio Cavalcanti de Arajo sleep with their two small children in a one-room house with a floor of dirt and concrete, and a green plastic basin for a toilet.

title: Want to Help Those Coping With Zika?
description: The following organizations direct donations to help cope with Zika in Latin America. Depending on the organization, the funding may be used to help provide services to affected families, educate people about preventing Zika infection, contribute to efforts to improve diagnosis, or other functions.

title: Backpages Sex Ads Are Gone. Child Trafficking? Hardly.
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Since she was 14, Tiffany says, she has been sold for sex, offered via hundreds of advertisements on Backpage.com, a website that grew rich on classified ads for services like escorts, body rubs and exotic dancers. Far from being a marketplace for consensual exchanges, Backpage, the authorities said, often used teasers like Amber Alert and Lolita to signal that children were for sale.

title: Behind the Quiet State-by-State Fight Over Electric Vehicles
description: When Georgia repealed its generous $5,000 tax credit on electric vehicles in July 2015, and instead slapped a $200 registration fee on electric cars, sales quickly tumbled.

title: For Brazils Zika Families, a Life of Struggle and Scares
description: ESCADA, Brazil  Not a soul was in sight on the narrow dusty street, except for a cat skittering under a three-quarter moon.

title: Realize One Day Youll Be Old
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: Im Not O.K. Neither Are You. Who Cares?
description: Most self-help books make exhausting demands of their readers. The endless list-making and inventorying. The frequent deployment of the encomium Yay, you! The tacit assertion that journey has not been overexposed as a result of the Dont Stop Believin glut. Its easy to conclude, why cant someone just write a self-improvement book called Canceling Lunch and be done with it?

title: Glenn Close and Patrick Kennedy on the Weight of Mental Illness
description: Glenn Close does not read her reviews. So the jumbo excerpt on the marquee where she is reprising her Tony Award-winning role in Sunset Boulevard (One of the great stage performances of this century), surrounded by flashing lights, may be a spoiler.

title: Damascus Bombings Near Pilgrimage Sites Kill Dozens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A double bombing near Shiite shrines often visited by foreign pilgrims in Damascus, Syria, killed at least 40 people on Saturday, shattering the capitals efforts to isolate itself from the war raging elsewhere in the country. Many of the dead were from neighboring Iraq.

title: Narendra Modis B.J.P. Party Wins Big in Uttar Pradesh, Indias Largest State
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Narendra Modi led his party to a landslide victory in Indias largest state on Saturday, consolidating his power and putting him in a strong position to win re-election in 2019.

title: Farhads and Cecilias Week in Tech: Tech Policy, Too, Is Undergoing a Sea Change
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is out this week, so Cecilia Kang, a tech reporter in Washington, stepped in.

title: Yemen Market Airstrike Kills at Least 16 People
description: SANA, Yemen  An airstrike by a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia on an open market in western Yemen killed at least 16 people, United Nations and local officials said Saturday.

title: Is a Co-op Required to Report Break-Ins to Shareholders?
description: Q. In January, a burglar slipped into our  co-op in Hudson Heights, Manhattan, behind a shareholder who was walking out. He stole a laundry cart  and  packages. The theft was reported to the police, but it took the board almost two weeks to notify shareholders. The notice minimized the event, failing to give a full account of it. What responsibility does the board have to shareholders  in reporting security breaches?

title: Two Saves, One Life Together
description: James Williams and Marc Wenderoff were married March 11 at the Parker, a hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Barby K. Siegel, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: No Health Insurance Is Hard. No Phone? Unthinkable.
description: SPRINGVILLE, Utah  As the health care debate thundered away in Washington, Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah stirred up a social media squall the other day by suggesting that uninsured Americans should invest in their own health care rather than getting that new iPhone that they just love.

title: Why U.S. Antimissile System in South Korea Worries China
description: BEIJING  Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a paper tiger, able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal of its own, and now concerns about the effectiveness of that arsenal as a deterrent are driving it into confrontation with the United States over an antimissile system being built in South Korea. Heres an explanation of why.

title: Uprooted by War, Threatened by Boko Haram and Desperate to Go Home
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  Dozens of drivers lined up in beat-up vehicles stuffed with mattresses, cooking pots and other belongings, clogging a road outside one of the most desperate and dangerous camps that serve as refuge from the war with Boko Haram.

title: Belgiums New Deportation Law Raises Red Flag With Civil Rights Groups
description: BRUSSELS  Belgiums Parliament has quietly passed legislation giving the government extraordinary powers to deport legal residents on the mere suspicion of engagement in terrorist activities, or for presenting a risk to public order or national security, without a criminal conviction or the involvement of a judge.

title: If Russia Inquiry Is Not Legitimate, Democrats May Abandon It
description: WASHINGTON  They agreed just a week ago to the terms of a House Intelligence Committee investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. But now some of the panels Democrats are warning that they may pull their support for the inquiry if it becomes mired in party-line politics.

title: Even Child Care Divides Parties. Ivanka Trump Tries Building a Bridge.
description: WASHINGTON  One evening last month, a small group of Republican lawmakers  all of them women  were summoned to the Roosevelt Room of the White House for a private meeting.

title: Variety: Missing Links
description: VARIETY PUZZLE(S)  It took me forever and a day to make any progress on this variety puzzle, the style of which was new to me, and I really look forward to seeing your experiences in the comments.

title: Intruder Gets Within Steps of White House
description: WASHINGTON  A man carrying a backpack jumped over a fence and got within several steps of the White House before being arrested late Friday, the Secret Service said. The intrusion, the first reported since President Trump took office, came as the president was inside the residence.

title: A Work in Progress, Since Before the Civil War
description: If Page 1 is the front door to The New York Times, Pages 2 and 3 are the entranceway.

title: From an Obit Writer, the Last Word on The Last Word
description: In her next life, Shirley MacLaine may come back as a movie critic  you never know. If she does (or even if she doesnt), she wont likely look back on The Last Word, released this month, as a current-life highlight.

title: The Holy Grail for Reporters: Presidential Secrets
description: The New York Times and other news organizations are in pursuit of President Trumps secrets, including his possible links to Russia and that most elusive of leaks: his tax returns.

title: The G.O.P.s High-Risk Strategy for Health Law Repeal
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump and House Republicans are pressing forward with a high-risk strategy to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, disregarding the views of medical professionals and potentially imperiling the partys political future in conservative states where many voters stand to lose their health care.

title: Meet Diego, the Centenarian Whose Sex Drive Saved His Species
description: CHARLES DARWIN RESEARCH STATION, Galpagos  Of all the giant tortoises on these islands, where the theory of evolution was born, only a few have received names that stuck.

title: Latino Players Relish the World Baseball Classic
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  Two questions remain constant during the 2017 World Baseball Classic, the fourth installment of the tournament: Who will win? And how much will players care?

title: Tenants on the 18th Floor
description: The New York Times is not the only newsroom at 620 Eighth Avenue.

title: Tillerson Leads From State Dept. Shadows as White House Steps In
description: WASHINGTON  Henry A. Kissinger slipped into the State Department last week for a quiet lunch in his old office with Rex W. Tillerson, the former Exxon Mobil chief executive, who has all but covered himself in a cloak of invisibility in his first six weeks as secretary of state.

title: Venezuelan Baseball Players Love Their Chaotic Country From Afar
description: Five years after he was kidnapped in his native Venezuela, Wilson Ramos, a catcher for the Tampa Bay Rays, finally secured the paperwork necessary for his family to live with him in the United States. Carlos Carrasco, a pitcher for the Cleveland Indians who was born in Venezuela, passed his United States citizenship test in August and has not returned to his birthplace for years.

title: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Says He Was Fired After Refusing to Quit
description: The call to Preet Bhararas office from President Trumps assistant came on Thursday. Would Mr. Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, please call back?

title: Erdogan Calls Dutch Nazi Remnants After Turkish Minister Is Barred
description: PARIS  The Dutch government on Saturday intensified a diplomatic dispute between Turkey and its NATO allies in Europe by refusing to let the Turkish foreign minister fly into the Netherlands to campaign on behalf of a referendum that would augment the power of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.

title: Reader Responses to Our Underground Railroad Issue
description: In the March 5 edition of the Race/Related newsletter, we asked you to share explorations of your family history, after Monica Drake, travel editor at The Times, wrote about hers.

title: Resist the Internet
description: So far, in my ongoing series of columns making the case for implausible ideas, Ive fixed race relations and solved the problem of a workless working class. So now its time to turn to the real threat to the human future: the one in your pocket or on your desk, the one you might be reading this column on right now.

title: In a Refugees Bags, Memories of Home
description: Seeds and saplings, musical instruments, elderly parents leaving home for the first time. Telephones containing recordings of voices, festivals, pictures of the missing and the dead. Recipes for eggplant stuffed with hot peppers. A nursery rhyme sung in a dying language. These are just some of what Syrian and Iraqi refugees and migrants bring with them as they travel across borders and into new lives.

title: Are Your Sperm in Trouble?
description: Lets begin with sex.

title: A Lifeline for Troubled Veterans
description: After the United States withdrew troops from Iraq in 2011, thousands of combat troops were expelled from the force with less than honorable discharges as the military came under pressure to downsize quickly. This left a large number of veterans  including many kicked out for minor infractions  without access to health care and other benefits that are granted to service members who leave the armed forces with honorable discharges.

title: Crime and the Adolescent Brain
description: When the Supreme Court banned capital punishment for crimes that were committed when a defendant was under the age of 18, it ruled that standards of decency had evolved to recognize that a juveniles lack of maturity and an underdeveloped sense of responsibility distinguished his crimes from those of an adult.

title: Kiss Me, Im Pretty Sure Im Irish
description: Every person alive can define himself in a single sentence. Thats what the novelist Susan Rieger once told me, and as soon as she said it I knew what mine would be: I come from a large, Irish Catholic family.

title: Dont Think About the White Bear
description: I first heard about the white bear trick in my eighth-grade West Virginia studies class. The girl sitting in front of me turned around and said, Try not to think of a white bear.

title: The Dangerous Safety of College
description: The moral of the recent melee at Middlebury College, where students shouted down and chased away a controversial social scientist, isnt just about free speech, though thats the rubric under which the ugly incident has been tucked. Its about emotional coddling. Its about intellectual impoverishment.

title: In Los Angeles, a Festival of Love and Hapa-ness
description: Los Angeles  The current political moment, with its upwelling of nationalism and xenophobia, has a repellent taste, like a mouthful of citrus pith, all bitter and white.

title: Prisoners of Boko Haram, Then Prisoners of Fame
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  The next time international do-gooders decide to lend their hashtag support to a cause in Africa, it would be wise to remember the fallout of the Bring Back Our Girls campaign.

title: The Moral Failing of Obamacare Repeal
description: PITTSBURGH  Imagine a car crash. Theres twisted metal, broken glass and the low moaning of an injured human being. An ambulance arrives, and two emergency medical technicians get out.

title: The Laws Emotion Problem
description: In the 1992 Supreme Court case Riggins v. Nevada, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy acknowledged  perhaps unwittingly  that our legal system relies on a particular theory of the emotions. The court had ruled that a criminal defendant could not forcibly be medicated to stand trial, and Justice Kennedy concurred, stressing that medication might impair a defendants ability to exhibit his feelings. This, he warned, would interfere with the critical task, during the sentencing phase, of trying to know the heart and mind of the offender, including his contrition or its absence.

title: Misogyny and Women in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Blackhawks Patrick Kane, an M.V.P., Is Still Looking to Improve
description: CHICAGO  For all of his natural talent and the seemingly endless collection of moves in his arsenal, Patrick Kane remains, in many ways, unsatisfied.

title: Trump Adviser Had Twitter Contact With Figure Tied to Russians
description: WASHINGTON  Roger J. Stone Jr., an off-and-on adviser to President Trump for decades, has acknowledged that he had contact on Twitter with Guccifer 2.0, the mysterious online figure that is believed to be a front for Russian intelligence officials.

title: Struggling With Japans Nuclear Waste, Six Years After Disaster
description: FUKUSHIMA DAIICHI NUCLEAR POWER STATION  Six years after the largest nuclear disaster in a quarter-century, Japanese officials have still not solved a basic problem: what to do with an ever-growing pile of radioactive waste. Each form of waste at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, where three reactors melted down after an earthquake and a tsunami on March 11, 2011, presents its own challenges.

title: Texas Congressional Maps Are Struck Down for Discrimination
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A panel of federal judges in San Antonio has ruled that a handful of Texas congressional districts drawn by the Republican-dominated state Legislature in 2011 discriminated against black and Hispanic voters and violated the Voting Rights Act and the Constitution.

title: Taking the Fifth
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you asked me in court, Id gladly tell you that the title of this puzzle refers to the alphabet rather than the justice system, and stuff that gets taken doesnt always get taken away.

title: Reporting on Zika Families  and Their Resilience
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

title: Bladed Runner Hunter Woodhall Fails to Qualify for Finals at Indoor Meet
description: The steep, claustrophobic curves at the Armory track in Manhattan took their toll Saturday on the high school runner Hunter Woodhall, a Paralympic medalist who was competing on prosthetic blades at the New Balance Nationals Indoor meet against some of the top scholastic stars.

title: Princeton, at Center of Bulls-Eye, Keeps Focus Against Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA  Princeton won the first game of the inaugural Ivy League mens basketball postseason tournament Saturday, barely averting an upset by Penn and denying traditionalists an I told you so.

title: New Ferguson Video Adds Wrinkle to Michael Brown Case
description: In the two and a half years since Michael Brown, a black 18-year-old, was shot and killed by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the explosive case has been parsed in intricate detail. Witnesses offered varying descriptions of the fatal encounter. Investigators examined bloodstain evidence on the street where Mr. Brown died. And the police released a security video from a nearby store that showed Mr. Brown pushing a worker and taking cigarillos minutes before the shooting.

title: Quotation of the Day: The Tortoise Whose Sex Drive Saved His Species
description: Hell keep reproducing until death.

title: Corrections: March 12, 2017
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Venezuela Outlasts Italy in a Marathon
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  Venezuela, one of the most talented teams in the World Baseball Classic, needed 10 innings and sustained two injuries in an 11-10 win over Italy on Saturday.

title: United States Quiets Dominican Bats, but Only for a Time
description: MIAMI  Of all the American stars who were asked to play in the World Baseball Classic, Andrew Miller might have had the best excuse to say no. He had toiled for nearly 20 innings in the postseason for the Cleveland Indians, right through Game 7 of the World Series, when he finally seemed to tire. He could have eased into a new year.

title: Camille Perri, Helen Pennock
description: Camille Perri and Helen Pennock were married March 10 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Alisa Fuentes, a staff member in the City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Aliza Stern, Ian Grossman
description: Aliza Ann Stern and Ian Dov Grossman are to be married March 12 at the Schoolhouse at Cannondale, a restaurant in Wilton, Conn. Rabbi Colin Brodie is to perform the ceremony at Temple Bnai Torah in Trumbull, Conn.

title: Kelly Paulson, Michael Furchtgott
description: Kelly Christina Paulson and Michael Max Furchtgott are to be married March 12 on a whale-watching vessel in the Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary in Maui, Hawaii. Rabbi Barry Axler is to officiate.

title: Sheetal Rajagopal, Sushanth Bhaskarabhatla
description: Sheetal Rajagopal and Sushanth Bhaskarabhatla were married March 8 at the Chicago Marriage and Civil Union Court. Stephanie K. Miller, a judge of the First Municipal District of Chicago, officiated. On Dec. 21, the couple took part in a traditional Hindu ceremony in Bangalore, India.

title: Lauren Weinstein, Eli Kintisch
description: Lauren Beth Weinstein and Eli Steven Kintisch are to be married March 12 at Hotel Monaco in Washington. Lilah L. Pomerance, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, is to officiate, with Cantor Benjamin Kintisch, the grooms brother, participating.

title: Laura Gleiberman, Seth Heller
description: Laura Gleiberman and Seth Isaac Heller were married March 11 at the Cosmos Club, a private social club in Washington. Rabbi Eric B. Stark officiated.

title: Stephanie Simon, Michael Wax
description: Stephanie Nicole Simon, the daughter of Randi J. Simon and Dr. Richard J. Simon of Weston, Fla., was married March 11 to Michael Nathan Wax, the son of Ruth A. Silon of South Euclid, Ohio, and Mitchell L. Wax of Lakewood, Ohio. Rabbi Gayle Pomerantz officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Miami. Paul A. Engelmayer, a United States district judge for the Southern District of New York for whom the bride was a clerk from 2013 to 2014, participated.

title: Putin and Merkel: A Rivalry of History, Distrust and Power
description: BERLIN  He was skinny in his trim, dark suit, an almost lupine figure, nervous and unexpectedly youthful for a president of Russia. Taking the lectern beneath the dome of the restored Reichstag, Vladimir V. Putin soon shifted to German, with a fluency that startled the German lawmakers and a pro-West message that reassured them. The Cold War seemed over.

title: Sarah Melby, Jochem Zijp
description: Sarah Crommelin Melby and Jochem Philip Zijp were married March 11 at the Meridian House, an event space in Washington. Alexandra Melby Farnum, the brides sister, received permission from the Marriage Bureau of the District of Columbia Courts to officiate.

title: Noah Levine, Jonathan Rebell
description: Noah Allen Levine and Jonathan Edward Rebell were married March 11 at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, an event space in New York. Andrew S. Koerner, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions.

title: Jessica Cohen, Jeffrey Barmach
description: Jessica Cohen and Jeffrey Alan Barmach are to be married March 12 at Woodfield Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Michael G. Berenbaum, a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Julia Powell, James Love IV
description: Dr. Julia Blair Powell and James Erskine Love IV were married March 11 at the Figure Eight Island Yacht Club in Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Scott Black Johnston, senior pastor of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, officiated.

title: Caitlin Miller, Jared Dolan
description: Dr. Caitlin Mary Miller and Jared Edward Dolan were married March 10. Msgr. William Dever, a Roman Catholic priest and the great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church in Naples, Fla.

title: Chasing Big Sports Goals, Rutgers Stumbles Into a Vat of Red Ink
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Ah, how grandness beckoned. When Rutgers officials announced in 2012 that their university would join the Big Ten, one of the nations premier athletic conferences, the sun itself seemed to burn brighter.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: American Crime and Jurassic Park
description: ABCs anthology series American Crime returns for its third season with a new story starring Felicity Huffman, Timothy Hutton and Regina King. And the first three Jurassic Park films are ripe for binge-watching on Netflix.

title: Will the N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket Be Leaked Again? CBS Hopes Not
description: The anonymous Twitter poster who leaked last years N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament pairings halfway through CBSs televised selection show is on the minds of a lot of people this weekend.

title: Israel Wins Again in the W.B.C., Beating Cuba to Stay Undefeated
description: TOKYO  Israel had not played from behind during its magical run at the World Baseball Classic until Sunday, when it overcame an early one-run deficit to beat Cuba, 4-1, in the first game of the second round of the tournament.

title: On S.N.L., Donald Trump Botches His Independence Day Moment
description: Sure, Saturday Night Live has offered ample criticism of President Trump and his young administration. But in its latest episode, the program expressed confidence that hell be in office until at least 2018, long enough to see America decimated by an alien invasion force from the planet Zorblatt 9.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: 210 Christopher Street, Montclair

title: How the Republican Health Plan Could Affect You
description: Some examples of how the proposals effects could play out.

title: What I Love | B.H. Barry
description: The name B.H. Barry was invented for a sideline gig. Now, Mr. Barry embraces his career as a fight director and delights in his penthouse duplex.

title: A Stage Fight Directors Gentler Side
description: African violets. A ukulele. The first impression of me is a man of violence, B.H. Barry said. But his home suggests otherwise. Step inside as part of our What I Love series.

title: From Stage Combat to Hudson Views
description: You can see the Hudson rolling serenely along from the many windows in B. H. Barrys penthouse duplex on the Upper West Side. Special tip for first-time visitors: The river is even more lovely to look at when youre standing on the terrace off the 16th-floor living room.

title: G.O.P. Desire to Keep Party Feuds Private Breaks Down Over Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Top Republicans never like to see their internal party quarrels messily spilled out in public for all to see.

title: Donald Trump, Republican Party, Daylight Saving: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Park Geun-hye, Ousted South Korean Leader, Leaves Presidential Palace
description: SEOUL, South Korea  For months, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators have gathered almost weekly near the presidential Blue House in Seoul, calling for the departure of Park Geun-hye as South Koreas leader.

title: Pakistan Citys Affluent Women Bring Islam Into Their Lives and Lifestyles
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  It was a weekday afternoon in an upscale neighborhood of Karachi, but the hall was packed for the lecture on Islam and marriage.

title: He Didnt Like Homeland. Now Hes Advising It.
description: A sharply dressed lawyer represented his Muslim-American clients before a three-judge panel in New York recently, claiming that because federal authorities tried to coerce them into becoming informants, they had the right to receive monetary damages.

title: Russian Espionage Piggybacks on a Cybercriminals Hacking
description: To the F.B.I., Evgeniy M. Bogachev is the most wanted cybercriminal in the world. The bureau has announced a $3 million bounty for his capture, the most ever for computer crimes, and has been trying to track his movements in hopes of grabbing him if he strays outside his home turf in Russia.

title: After $225 Billion in Deals Last Year, China Reins In Overseas Investment
description: BEIJING  China struck $225 billion in deals to acquire companies abroad last year, a record-breaking number that signaled to the world that Chinese business leaders were hot to haggle.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Maoist Rebels Ambush and Kill 11 Police Officers in India
description: NEW DELHI  Maoist rebels killed 11 Indian police officers and seized their automatic weapons and ammunition after ambushing a foot patrol on Saturday morning in the eastern state of Chattisgarh, according to a police official.

title: A Financial Lifeline for Owners of Historic Homes
description: You never know what you might find when you start peeling away layers. For Attila Piros, that is more than an aphorism. It is an explanation of why his rowhouse in a historic district in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was not what everyone thought it was.

title: Heavy Snowfall Is Forecast Across Northeastern U.S.
description: Maybe you thought you were going to get through this winter without too much rough weather. Not so fast. If the current forecast is accurate, there is still some winter yet to come.

title: 2017 N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket: Who Has the Edge in Each Region?
description: Villanova (31-3), which won last years N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament on a three-pointer at the buzzer in the championship game, was awarded the top overall seed in this years bracket, released Sunday evening, one day after winning the Big East tournament.

title: An Incisive Play About Hasidism, With Actors Who Lived It
description: Melissa Weisz, a working actress in Manhattan, did not exactly grow up a drama club kid.

title: Israel at the World Baseball Classic: From Curiosity to Contender
description: TOKYO  When Peter Kurz, the president of the Israel Association of Baseball, left home two weeks ago to accompany Team Israel on its first trip to the World Baseball Classic, he packed two passports, a decision that was both practical and whimsical.

title: Kong: Skull Island Roars as March Becomes a Tent-Pole Season
description: LOS ANGELES  As Hollywood has focused on making lumbering, all-audience movies stuffed with visual effects  Kong: Skull Island, which arrived on Friday, being a prime example  movie studios have run into a problem: where to put them all.

title: Lloyd Conover, Inventor of Groundbreaking Antibiotic, Dies at 93
description: Lloyd H. Conover, a chemist whose breakthrough invention of one of the most effective and widely prescribed antibiotics, tetracycline, led to a whole new approach to developing such drugs, died on Saturday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 93.

title: In Armenia, What Do You Want to Be? Is Asked in Infancy
description: Children in Armenia start thinking about their careers at a very young age  around six months or so.

title: Jordan Frees Soldier Who Killed 7 Israeli Schoolgirls in 97 Rampage
description: JERUSALEM  The fragile treaty between the two former enemies was not even three years old when a Jordanian soldier went on a shooting rampage and killed seven Israeli schoolgirls visiting a park in a border area known as the Island of Peace.

title: Narendra Modi, South Korea Impeachment, Netherlands: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: In Brooklyn, Police Find Toppled Tombstones, but No Crime
description: The headstone was made in 1915 for a wife and mother named Fannie who lived to be 54 years old. And last weekend, 102 years later, police officers stood around it in Washington Cemetery in Brooklyn, looking beyond the name and dates for other kinds of clues.

title: 2 of a Farmers 3 Children Overdosed. What of the Third  and the Land?
description: BLANCHESTER, Ohio  A life of farming taught Roger Winemiller plenty about harsh twists of fate: hailstorms and drought, ragweed infestations and jittery crop prices. He hadnt bargained on heroin.

title: A Glimpse Into the Life of a Slave Sold to Save Georgetown
description: He was an enslaved teenager on a Jesuit plantation in Maryland on the night that the stars fell. It was November 1833, and meteor showers set the sky ablaze.

title: Is ICEs Help-Wanted Sign a Welcome Mat for Rogue Applicants, Too?
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has vowed a hiring surge of 10,000 immigration and customs officers to accelerate the deportation of unauthorized immigrants. But the aggressive pace he has laid out risks adding to the ranks of rogue agents who have been charged with abusing immigrants.

title: Trump Lets Key Offices Gather Dust Amid Slowest Transition in Decades
description: WASHINGTON  At the State Department, the normally pulsating hub of executive offices is hushed and virtually empty. At the Pentagon, military missions in some of the worlds most troubled places are being run by a defense secretary who has none of his top team in place. And at departments like Treasury, Commerce and Health and Human Services, many senior posts remain vacant even as the agencies have been handed enormous tasks like remaking the nations health insurance system.

title: Trump Wants Faster Growth. The Fed Isnt So Sure.
description: WASHINGTON  For President Trump and his economic advisers, the strong February jobs report was a cause for celebration  and a first step toward delivering on the presidents promise of faster economic growth.

title: As Daylight Saving Starts, Some Ask: Why Fall Back at All?
description: DAMARISCOTTA, Me.  Several years ago, the owner of a sandwich shop on the main drag here grew so tired of turning the clocks back in the fall  and witnessing the early sunsets that followed  that he simply decided not to. That year, he kept his shop on daylight saving time all winter.

title: Members of the Italian Band Soviet Soviet Are Deported
description: Members of the Italian postpunk trio Soviet Soviet, booked to play at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., were detained in Seattle on Wednesday and eventually deported by United States Customs and Border Protection officials as immigration enforcement under the Trump administration continues to cause tension.

title: The Five Big Numbers to Look For in the C.B.O. Report on Health Care Reform
description: The Congressional Budget Office is expected to score the Republicans health plan this week. Here, based on some expert estimates, is a guide to the key numbers.

title: An Opera Inspired by Pink Floyd Will Get Its United States Premiere
description: The Cincinnati Opera has announced the United States premiere of Another Brick in the Wall: The Opera, capping its 98th season and its first after a $135 million restoration of the Cincinnati Music Hall. Opening in July 2018, Another Brick in the Wall features original words and music by Roger Waters of the psychedelic rock band Pink Floyd, whose 1979 album, The Wall, inspired the opera. The production made its world premiere at Opra de Montral in Quebec on Saturday.

title: In Chicago and Philadelphia, the Difference a Park Makes
description: CHICAGO  Despite the bitter wind, Kim Wasserman showed me around La Villita Park. Occupying 21 acres in the middle of this citys largest Mexican-American neighborhood, called Little Village, the park used to be a brownfield and illegal dump. Back then, the site leached toxins into hundreds of nearby basements. Sickened residents protested for years. The federal cleanup, finally completed in 2012, became the largest urban Superfund project in America.

title: Richard Simmonss Disappearing Act Inspires a Hit Podcast
description: Richard Simmons is not being tormented by black magic  or so says Mr. Simmons, the fitness guru, whose disappearance from public view three years ago has at least one close friend fearing he is under the spell of a witch.

title: Live! With The Times: Singer-Songwriter Valerie June
description: The singer-songwriter Valerie June came to The New York Times headquarters on Monday, March 13 to perform songs for you and answer your questions. Read the conversation here.

title: The President Changed. So Has Small Businesses Confidence.
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  The cream of the small-business community here tucked into their lunch on a top floor of a bank building and pondered the question put to them by their local lenders economist.

title: Why Winning a State Election Will Strengthen Modis Populism
description: VARANASI, India  Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, is a mesmerizing orator, in the way of a talk-show host with an acerbic tongue, and this month a campaign crowd of more than 50,000 showed up in Deoria, a hardscrabble town in the state of Uttar Pradesh, to hear his story. They knew and loved the part about how this son of a tea seller rose through the party ranks with no help from family connections. But the rest of his rags-to-power tale is changing fast.

title: Review: In Badrinath Ki Dulhania, Boy Meets Girl (and Learns to Respect Her)
description: Recent Bollywood movies have tried out, hesitantly and conservatively, versions of the Modern Woman: Heroines can have careers; they can live alone in the big city; they can even (if very rarely) have sex before marriage.

title: Torontos Housing Boom Refills Empty Nests, Driving Prices Even Higher
description: OAKVILLE, Ontario  Janet Barber doesnt dwell too much on the view from her driveway.

title: Trump Far Behind Obamas Pace on Nominees
description: A chart from the Office of Government Ethics obtained by The New York Times shows that the office had received only 63 disclosure reports for prospective Trump administration nominees as of March 5, less than a third of the 228 that Mr. Obamas team had submitted by that date in 2009.

title: Why The Outsiders Lives On: A Teenage Novel Turns 50
description: TULSA, Okla.  On a particularly windy day in the Crutchfield neighborhood here, the writer S. E. Hinton was touring the renovations of the future Outsiders House museum. The rundown Craftsman bungalow was where the Curtis brothers  Darry, Sodapop and Ponyboy  lived in the 1983 Francis Ford Coppola movie based on Ms. Hintons book The Outsiders.

title: An American Immigrant in Paris
description: PARIS  Soon after Donald Trump was inaugurated, I got a letter from Frances interior ministry informing me that I was now French. By the time it arrived, Id been French for nearly two weeks, without even knowing it. (Had you felt yourself becoming more and more rude? a friend asked.)

title: After Five Years of Bach, Trinity Church Takes On Handel
description: Bach at One  the free concert series in which the musical forces of Trinity Wall Street, directed by Julian Wachner, performed all of Bachs sacred works over five years in St. Pauls Chapel  mostly ran like clockwork. And on its return to the newly renovated chapel on March 6, with an altered focus, it gave every sign that it will continue to do so.

title: Its in the Stratosphere
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  If youre tempted on a Monday to creep back to bed, youll understand the challenge of diving in, taking the plunge, committing to another week of peaks and valleys (and hopefully no geopolitical apocalypses). Since the top and bottom thirds of this grid had clues that spanned from left to right, there were plenty of supportive crosses that made the solve pretty quick for me.

title: Whats Madison Avenue Pitching Now? Cultural and Political Awareness
description: Madison Avenue exists to persuade. (Check out how stylish this car looks! Doesnt everyone seem to be having a great time while drinking this beer?) In a perilous political climate, however, some advertising agencies have decided to use their marketing acumen in service of advancing cultural and political causes, rather than selling products.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 13
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Heng on North Korea and Malaysias Bans
description: A bitter dispute over the investigation into the killing of Kim Jong-nam has resulted in the nations blocking each others citizens from leaving the country.

title: George A. Olah, Carbon Compounds Pathfinder, Dies at 89
description: George A. Olah, a Hungarian-born scientist who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1994 for his study of the chemical reactions of carbon compounds, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.

title: For Solace and Solidarity in the Trump Age, Liberals Turn the TV Back On
description: There is a new safe space for liberals in the age of President Trump: the television set.

title: Trump Administration Is Said to Be Working to Loosen Counterterrorism Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration is exploring how to dismantle or bypass Obama-era constraints intended to prevent civilian deaths from drone attacks, commando raids and other counterterrorism missions outside conventional war zones like Afghanistan and Iraq, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

title: Miscue Calls Attention to Amazons Dominance in Cloud Computing
description: SEATTLE  There have been many opportunities to consider how crucial Amazon has become to the smooth operation of the internet over the past few years.

title: Printable N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket
description: North Carolina defeats Gonzaga to win its sixth N.C.A.A. championship.

title: John Surtees, Two- and Four-Wheel Racing Champion, Dies at 83
description: John Surtees, an Englishman who won seven world motorcycle championships, then switched to auto racing and captured the 1964 Formula One points title, becoming the only racer to hold both two- and four-wheel world crowns, died on Friday in London. He was 83.

title: Gonzaga Earns Second No. 1 Seed, and Hopes for Better Luck This Time
description: One-loss Gonzaga was installed as a No. 1 seed for the second time in program history, but the last time, in 2013, did not go so well. The Bulldogs lost to ninth-seeded Wichita State in the second round. But while Gonzaga (32-1) still has never been to a Final Four, the Bulldogs are a worthy No. 1: They lost only to Brigham Young and outscored opponents by more than 23 points a game. The Zags biggest problem? Arizona, the Pac-12 champion, lurks at No. 2.

title: Losing a Step in the Subway Seat Game
description: Dear Diary:

title: For Children Caught in Syrias War, 2016 Was Worst Year Yet, U.N. Says
description: Children suffered a drastic escalation in violence from the Syrian civil war in 2016, the United Nations said Sunday in a report that showed child deaths jumped at least 20 percent from the year before and recruitment of child combatants more than doubled.

title: Puerto Ricos Yadier Molina Criticizes Security at World Baseball Classic
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  St. Louis Cardinals catcher Yadier Molina, who is playing for Puerto Rico in the World Baseball Classic, accused Major League Baseball of failing to provide security in the section where Puerto Rico players families sat during a 9-4 win over Mexico on Saturday.

title: Man Without an ISIS Plan
description: On the campaign trail, no foreign policy issue seized Donald Trump more than the fight against the Islamic State. Once president, he signed an executive order giving his generals 30 days to produce a plan to defeat the terrorist group, and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis gave him options on Feb. 27.

title: Steve King Says Civilization Cant Be Restored With Somebody Elses Babies
description: Representative Steve King, a Republican from Iowa who has a history of making inflammatory statements viewed by many as insensitive or outright racist, was roundly criticized on Sunday for his apparent endorsement of white nationalism.

title: Joni Sledge, Singer in the We Are Family Group Sister Sledge, Dies at 60
description: Joni Sledge, who along with her three sisters formed the disco-era family quartet Sister Sledge, best known for the hit song We Are Family, was found dead in her home in Phoenix on Friday. She was 60.

title: Jay Lynch, Underground Comics Creator, Dies at 72
description: Jay Lynch, an artist, writer and satirist who was a central figure in the underground comics revolution of the 1960s and 70s, died on March 5 at his home in Candor, N.Y. He was 72.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Familiar Favorites and Compelling Underdogs
description: The last anyone saw of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, Villanovas Kris Jenkins was sinking a buzzer-beating 3-pointer to top North Carolina in the 2016 championship game.

title: Board to Decide Puerto Ricos Financial Future; Fed Rate Boost Is on Way
description: Heres a look at whats coming up this week.

title: The Choose-Your-Own-News Adventure
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A fascinating story emerged about Netflix last week.

title: Turkeys Relations With Europe Sink Amid Quarrel With Netherlands
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys quarrel with Europe worsened over the weekend after the Turkish president accused the Dutch government of Nazism, and Turkish politicians were barred or disinvited from events in two European countries, amid tensions ahead of a tight referendum on a new Turkish Constitution.

title: Quotation of the Day: As Heroin Infests Farms, a Grieving Parent Fears for the Future
description: Its in my blood. Its the family name. Ive done enough to disgrace our name. I want to do everything I can to mend it.

title: Preet Bharara Shunned Politics. His End Was Tinged by Them.
description: Ten days into his tenure as United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara saw his political and prosecutorial worlds collide.

title: Mets Players at World Baseball Classic Reconnect With Roots
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  When Mets pitcher Seth Lugo speaks, the Louisiana in him becomes apparent. There is a Southern accent and no hint that he has Puerto Rican roots. He does not speak Spanish, and he had never been to the island until last month, when he met his relatives there for the first time. He jokes with his family that he is quarter-Rican.

title: White House Addresses Trumps Unorthodox Call to Preet Bharara
description: WASHINGTON  The White House offered an explanation on Sunday for a mysterious phone call that President Trump placed to Preet Bharara a day before abruptly dismissing him and 45 other United States attorneys, saying the president was merely trying to extend his good wishes.

title: Preet Bhararas Dismissal Has a Nixon-Era Parallel
description: The resignation statement from the United States attorney in Manhattan was blunt: I hope that my fight for independence will make it easier for my successor to withstand the harsh, narrow partisan views on law enforcement currently in favor at the Department of Justice in Washington.

title: HSBC Names Mark Tucker to be First Outsider as Chairman
description: LONDON  Mark Tucker, chief executive of the Asian life insurer AIA Group, is set to replace Douglas Flint as chairman of HSBC in October, the bank said on Sunday.

title: New Labor Nominee: Fair Leader or Self-Serving One?
description: MIAMI  In 2008, three years after R. Alexander Acosta had decamped from the Justice Departments Civil Rights Division for the United States attorneys post in South Florida, the Justice Departments in-house investigator laid out a damning conclusion: Under Mr. Acostas watch, his office had repeatedly violated federal law and department policies by weighing political affiliations in hiring and assessing civil rights employees.

title: Homeland, Season 6, Episode 8: The Never-Ending Trials of Quinn
description: Well, now Im upset. And not in a good way.

title: Review: Villa Dramatizes a Plot of Chilean Land With a Dark Past
description: First, the atrocity. Then the architecture.

title: Review: Come From Away, a Canadian Embrace on a Grim Day
description: Try, if you must, to resist the gale of good will that blows out of Come From Away, the big bearhug of a musical that opened on Sunday night at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. But even the most stalwart cynics may have trouble staying dry-eyed during this portrait of heroic hospitality under extraordinary pressure.

title: The Walking Dead Season 7, Episode 13: Morgan Takes a Turn
description: This is it, Morgan. You have to kill, or else you might as well just kill yourself.

title: Feud: Bette and Joan Episode 2: Give the People What They Want
description: After a tough day shooting What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?, director Robert Aldrich complains to his wife (Molly Price) that his two stars  Bette Davis and Joan Crawford  have ganged up on him, undermining his power on the set. He seethes that Jack Palance and Lee Marvin would never have resorted to such maneuvers. His wife replies flatly: They dont have to. Theyre men.

title: Billions Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: More Wendy, Please
description: In the first season of Billions, Wendy Rhoades acted as the narrative linchpin, the basest and truest explanation for why Chuck and Axe went to war against each other. As played so shrewdly by Maggie Siff, Wendy is the trophy that cannot be possessed, despite the claims made on her by both men in her life. Nevertheless, Chuck opened up an investigation against Axe Capital because Axes corruptive enterprise had Wendy under contract as its in-house enabler, coaching analysts to attack vulnerabilities in the market as lions would a wounded gazelle. Chuck couldnt accept Wendy as a mere partner in their marriage  she was his woman, and her professional relationship with Axe felt to him like betrayal, a sexless affair.

title: Playing for Fans Who Travel, Dominicans Feel Right at Home
description: MIAMI  The empty upper decks at Marlins Park on Sunday night said much about the stateside appeal of the World Baseball Classic. The host country was playing Canada in prime time, with a berth in the second round at stake. Yet an announced crowd of just 22,303 dropped by to politely enjoy the United States 8-0 victory.

title: Willing to Blow the Whistle on Doping? New Legal Aid Group Wants to Help
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  Inspired by the Russian doping scandal, a new nonprofit foundation is offering financial and legal assistance to whistle-blowers with information about cheating in international sports.

title: Lowly Nets Send Knicks to 41st Loss
description: Knicks forward Kristaps Porzingis slumped his 7-foot-3 body into a chair in a dour visitors locker room at Barclays Center on Sunday and went about examining the latest turbulence in his teams chaotic season. He had plenty of material, but little clarity.

title: No Corrections: March 13, 2017
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Going to bat
description: Going to bat

title: Four Players to Watch in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: When Kris Jenkins attended the ESPY Awards in July, the former N.B.A. sharpshooter Robert Horry made a point of coming over to share a moment.

title: Excess capacity
description: Excess capacity

title: Changing Dynamics for Englands Elite Devalue the Double
description: By the time Alex Ferguson sat down, late in 1999, to compose the first of his several memoirs, he had already accumulated a slew of honors. Championships in his native Scotland and in England. An assortment of cups, at home and abroad. And his most recent, most treasured: a long-awaited victory in the Champions League.

title: An AIDS Museum: The Challenges Are Huge, but the Timing Is Right
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The National AIDS Memorial Grove in Golden Gate Park here is a somber glen of plants, trees, walks, grass and cairn, with thousands of names etched in stones and pavement. Visitors emotions run high, but the details of exactly how AIDS devastated and transformed the world are not found here.

title: Netherlands Considers a New Relationship to Muslims With Coming Election
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  Like many Muslims, Ahmed Aboutaleb has been disturbed by the angry tenor of the Dutch election campaign. Far-right candidates have disparaged Islam, often depicting Muslims as outsiders unwilling to integrate into Dutch culture.

title: Forget Foreign Hacking. The Big Surprise Was a Candid F.B.I.
description: Of all the surprises Michael Schwirtz and Joseph Goldstein encountered while reporting todays front-page story on Americas most wanted hacker, perhaps none was bigger than this: For once, the F.B.I. was excited to talk to them.

title: Referees Refuse to Work Soccer Games in Mexico
description: Mexican sports fans mourned a weekend without soccer after referees for the countrys first-tier league refused to officiate games in protest of the decision not to impose tougher punishments on two players who shoved officials.

title: Whats on TV Monday: The Bachelor and Beethoven
description: The Bachelor wraps up its 21st season as Nick Viall gives a rose to the winning woman  his potential fiance. And on Medici.tv, Gustavo Dudamel begins conducting the cycle of Beethovens nine symphonies, which continues through Wednesday.

title: Netherlands, Angela Merkel, Park Geun-hye: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: With a Racket in One Hand, World Team Tennis Passes a Torch With the Other
description: In its early days, World Team Tennis attracted big stars and big opposition.

title: A Vanishing Way of Life in Spains Coal Region
description: A once-proud workforce has seen its fortunes dwindle in Spain, where the government has found it cheaper to import coal.

title: A G.O.P. Cri de Coeur, Deconstructed
description: To the Editor:

title: Protectionism in the Guise of Tax Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Keep the President at Bay? Two Consultants Have an Inside Track
description: Attention: corporate America.

title: A Silicon Valley Train Gets Stuck
description: President Trumps promise to repair crumbling roads, bridges, railways and other public works is off to a terrible start. Before his administration has even come up with the $1 trillion infrastructure proposal he has repeatedly promised, his Department of Transportation is sabotaging an important commuter rail project in California opposed by the states Republicans. This doesnt send a good signal about the Trump administrations commitment to infrastructure investment.

title: Facts Are Enemies of the People
description: The U.S. economy added 10.3 million jobs during President Obamas second term, or 214,000 a month. This brought the official unemployment rate below 5 percent, and a number of indicators suggested that by late last year we were fairly close to full employment. But Donald Trump insisted that the good news on jobs was phony, that America was actually suffering from mass unemployment.

title: The Never-Ending War in Afghanistan
description: BOSTON  Remember Afghanistan? The longest war in American history? Ever?

title: Trump and the Parasitic Presidency
description: We have now passed the 50-day mark of the Donald Trump administration and one thing is clear: There is no new Trump.

title: What Our Cells Teach Us About a Natural Death
description: Every Thursday morning on the heart transplant service, our medical team would get a front-row seat to witness an epic battle raging under a microscope. Tiny pieces of heart tissue taken from patients with newly transplanted hearts would be broadcast onto a gigantic screen, showing static images of pink heart cells being attacked by varying amounts of blue immune cells. The more blue cells there were, the more voraciously they were chomping away the pink cells, the more evidence that the patients inherently xenophobic immune system was rejecting the foreign, transplanted heart.

title: Angels and Demons in the Cold War and Today
description: LOS ANGELES  George Kennan knew how to bring down the house. His lecture audiences started off skeptical about whether Russia really wanted to be remade on the American model. Then he told them about the Russian political prisoners who spent the weeks before the Fourth of July scrounging bits of cloth in red, white and blue. When the holiday came, they met their jailers by waving a sea of tiny hand-sewn stars and stripes through the bars.

title: In Spain, Mining Towns Become Ghost Towns
description: From the stoic, coal-smudged faces of miners to the worn and scuffed tools of their trade, lvaro Laizs photographs of northern Spains coal industry have a quiet dignity about them. They speak to an era when men with little education made a good, if dangerous, living. But now, like the tools that are museum relics, the miners themselves are being relegated to memory.

title: Happy Holi! Celebrating Spring in India
description: Revel in Holi, a Hindu festival of spring, in the area where it is believed the festival originated.

title: Biographies of Cecil the Lion and Others in Animals Strike Curious Poses
description: ANIMALS STRIKE CURIOUS POSESEssaysBy Elena PassarelloIllustrated. 217 pp. Sarabande Books. $19.95.

title: The Future of Humans? One Forecaster Calls for Obsolescence
description: HOMO DEUSA Brief History of TomorrowBy Yuval Noah HarariIllustrated. 449 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $35.

title: The New Party of No
description: Onthe morning after Election Day, Chuck Schumers phone rang. It was Donald Trump. Trump has repeatedly described Schumer as his friend  which, the New York senator was at pains to clarify when we first spoke in mid-February, isnt quite true. There had been the occasional favor; at Schumers request, Trump hosted a fund-raiser for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee at Mar-a-Lago in 2008, and Schumer made a cameo on The Apprentice in 2006. Beyond that, Schumer told me: I bump into him at meetings here and there. We never went out to dinner once. We never played golf together. I sort of knew him.

title: Think the N.C.A.A. Brackets Too Easy? Try One of These Pools
description: Starting in the 1970s, eight prosecutors in the Justice Departments Public Integrity Section set up a standing meeting. Once a year, they would gather in the deputy attorney generals conference room and run an elaborate pool for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Its Legal for 14-Year-Olds to Marry. Should It Be?
description: ALBANY  For nearly 90 years, an uncelebrated New York State law has largely escaped attention, allowing what would seem to be unfathomable in this day and age, and particularly in this state: child marriages, by the thousands.

title: When a Common Sedative Becomes an Execution Drug
description: TUCSON  When a chemist named Armin Walser helped invent a sedative more powerful than Valium more than 40 years ago, he thought his teams concoction was meant to make peoples lives easier, not their deaths.

title: The Other Airbnbs: Alternative Home-Sharing Rentals
description: What Airbnb has popularized  the peer-to-peer rental of apartments, homes and spare bedrooms  the market has embellished with a roster of new and growing services that offer home sharing.

title: Democrats Line of Attack on Gorsuch: No Friend of the Little Guy
description: WASHINGTON  Corporate tool. Enemy of disabled people. Deferential to the privileged, including the man who chose him.

description: President Trump and the Federal Reserve are headed for a collision.

description: Updated: March 16, 2017

title: The Feds Era of Easy Money Is Ending
description: When the Federal Reserve made its first tentative step toward ending its era of extraordinary monetary intervention, it earned a nickname: the taper tantrum. Global financial markets metaphorically bawled like a toddler on news that the Fed planned on tapering its stimulus program.

title: National Weather Service, Preet Bharara, N.C.A.A. Basketball: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Broadway Set Designers Home in the Desert
description: Scott Pasks retreat in Tucson pays homage to his Arizona upbringing  and defies Southwestern clichs.

title: A Childrens Museum Surprise Blockbuster: A Show on Islam
description: As terrorism fears have mounted and tensions have escalated toward Muslims in the United States in recent years, the Childrens Museum of Manhattan is doing its part to help defuse the rising anxiety. Its exhibition America to Zanzibar: Muslim Cultures Near and Far showcases the history, art and traditions of Muslims, with the belief that education will beat back ignorance and hate every time.

title: A Guide to Museums Getting Political This Year
description: The Minneapolis Institute of Art has invited the Mexican-born painter Aliza Nisenbaum, who is based in New York, to spend three months this summer in Latino, East African and other immigrant neighborhoods in Minneapolis, painting the people she meets there. Her work will be on display at the museum from this September through February 2018, with videos about the surrounding communities.

title: New Message at Some Museums: Dont Just Look. Do.
description: Sex trafficking and an art exhibition may seem like an incongruous pairing.

title: Museums Chart a Response to Political Upheaval
description: As President-elect Donald J. Trumps Inauguration Day approached, hundreds of artists, critics and others asked American museums, galleries and other institutions to close their doors in protest.

title: Traveling With Adult Children
description: There is nothing like traveling with your adult children to make you feel dazzled and impressed that they are truly all grown up, competent citizens of the world. And there is nothing like traveling with your adult children to remind you that they are still your children and sometimes you need to take care of them.

title: Do We Need to Give Up Alcohol to Lose Weight? Not Necessarily
description: People trying to lose weight  or not gain weight  are frequently advised to lay off the booze. Although organizations like Weight Watchers offer ways to drink wisely within their plans, alcohol, with seven calories a gram and no compensating nutrients, is commonly thought to derail most efforts at weight control.

description: Youve all experienced it: Theres a problem with your health care bill, or you have difficulty getting coverage for the care you need. Your doctor or hospital tells you to talk to your insurer. Your insurer tells you to talk to your doctor or hospital. Youre stuck in an endless runaround.

title: Property Owners Spend on Quality of Life (But Is That Fair?)
description: Benches, crosswalks and shade trees have transformed a once-barren stretch of Manhattan near the Holland Tunnel into a welcoming neighborhood known as Hudson Square.

title: Italian Food With Southern Soul
description: MEMPHIS  Andrew Ticer met Michael Hudman on the basketball court in the sixth grade. Back then, when they played for rival Catholic schools in Memphis, no one could have predicted they would become the citys restaurant royalty, winning national recognition for their restaurant Hog & Hominy.

description: In the world of driverless cars, household names like Google and Uber have raced ahead of rivals, building test vehicles and starting trials on city streets.

title: California Today: San Joses Mayor on Its Secret Sauce, Caltrain and More
description: Good morning.

title: Gazprom Makes Concessions in E.U. Gas Deal, but Trouble Looms for Russian Giant
description: After fitful negotiations spanning nearly two years, Gazprom moved a step closer on Monday to resolving a longstanding dispute with European antitrust regulators critical of the companys dominance in regional natural gas markets.

title: Amid Divisions in U.K. Over Brexit, Nicola Sturgeon Calls for New Referendum on Scottish Independence
description: LONDON  Protesting Britains plans to leave the European Union, Scotlands leader, Nicola Sturgeon, called on Monday for a referendum on Scottish independence as early as next year. The announcement was not unexpected, but it reflected the stark divisions in Britain as the government prepares to start the official process to exit the 28-nation bloc.

title: Boaty McBoatface, From Internet Joke to Polar Explorer
description: LONDON  Boaty McBoatface is back, but this time its serious.

description: Follow our live coverage of the first round of the N.C.A.A. Tournament here.

title: How Darwin Evolved: 25,540 Paper Fragments Tell the Story
description: Deep into the night, 15 computer whizzes toiled feverishly on Charles Darwins groundbreaking research notes at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. As part of the Darwin Manuscripts Project, the team had a daunting mission: piecing together fragments of the renowned British naturalists handwritten work.

title: The Hostel as Art Gallery, and Pipeline to an Arts Community
description: Budget travelers interested in exploring art often barely need to roll out of bed these days, as a growing number of hostels embrace the display of original work in their public spaces and guest rooms.

title: Come for the Guest Rooms. Stay for the Art Galleries.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Wander around this citys 21c Museum Hotel for an afternoon and youll notice a subtle but distinctive dance happening in the hallways. Most of the steps tend to be slow  individuals wandering in a hypnotic, pensive trance; couples moving, then stopping cold in a passageway, staring for minutes at the wall.

title: Kamasi Washington Follows The Epic With a New Work in Whitney Biennial
description: For two years the tenor saxophonist Kamasi Washington has ridden on the strength of The Epic, his hit triple album from 2015, playing almost 200 concerts last year and cementing a level of cultural prominence rarely afforded to jazz musicians.

title: Israel Finally Loses at World Baseball Classic
description: Team Israels unbeaten run in the World Baseball Classic came to an emphatic halt Monday when it was clobbered by the Netherlands, 12-2, in Tokyo.

title: Manhattans Other Bus Terminal, Running Years Late
description: Hidden behind a maze of wooden blockades and yellow tape, a neglected transportation hub in northern Manhattan is gearing up for a reopening  or so people have been led to believe.

title: Cardiovascular Deaths Linked to Poor Dietary Choices
description: Cardiovascular disease claims 610,000 lives in the United States each year. It is the leading cause of mortality nationwide, accounting for one in every four deaths.

title: Start the Week Right
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Code Orange Means Plug It In
description: Q. Why does the screen border on my Android tablet sometimes turn orange?

title: Competition in Job Market Lets Professionals Set Their Travel Terms
description: With the unemployment rate low and competition for top talent rising, travel perks are increasingly coming into play as a bargaining chip in recruitment.

title: A Fumble on a Key Fafsa Tool, and a Failure to Communicate
description: Applying for financial aid for college got a lot harder this month, in the thick of application season, but it took federal agencies nearly a week to explain what was happening.

title: The Wish List I Made After My Wife Almost Died
description: On your deathbed, its too late to make wish lists.

title: A Russian Lakes Future Hangs on Tourists and Toilets
description: BAYKALSK, Russia  Toilets are the talk of Lake Baikal these days, at least among the ecologically minded.

title: Northeast Snowstorm: How Much Are We Getting?
description: Communities across the Northeast are preparing for a late-winter snowstorm, and forecasters are warning of heavy snowfall on Tuesday from Washington to New England. A blizzard warning is in effect for much of the New York City area.

title: E.U. Warns Turkey in Escalating Dispute Over Constitutional Referendum
description: LONDON  Wading into an escalating diplomatic feud, the European Union warned Turkey on Monday that a constitutional amendment to drastically strengthen the presidents powers might harm the countrys longstanding bid to eventually join the bloc.

title: Theres Nothing to Fear at Simone Rocha
description: Right inside the designer Simone Rochas new store, on Wooster Street in SoHo, is a sculpture by the Chinese artist Ren Ri: a wall of stacked plexiglass cubes filled with shapely honeycombs. The artist lets the bees sculpt, rotating hives in progress so that the colony changes direction as it builds. The hives folded shapes remind me of thick clothes balled up.

title: As Drug Deaths Soar, Mayor Offers Plan to Cut Toll
description: With fatal drug overdoses at alarming levels in New York City, particularly from opiates like heroin, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday vowed to reverse the tide and reduce the number of deaths by 35 percent over five years through a combination of outreach, treatment and law enforcement.

title: The New York Times is Investing in Training
description: The New York Times is investing in training. Join our team.

title: Egyptian Prosecutor Orders Release of Hosni Mubarak, President Toppled in 2011
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian prosecutor ordered Hosni Mubarak, the toppled autocrat, released from the Maadi Military Hospital in southern Cairo, where he has been held for much of the last six years.

title: Using Air Quotes, White House Walks Back Wiretap Talk
description: Two senior White House officials suggested on Monday that President Trumps unsubstantiated claim that President Barack Obama had tapped his telephone was not meant to be taken literally, arguing that Mr. Trump had been referring more broadly to a variety of surveillance efforts during the 2016 campaign when he made the incendiary accusation.

title: Northwesterns Vision of an N.C.A.A. Bid Finally Becomes Reality
description: WASHINGTON  On recent Selection Sundays, Bryant McIntosh, a junior guard at Northwestern, had a ritual.

title: Are Teenagers Replacing Drugs With Smartphones?
description: Amid an opioid epidemic, the rise of deadly synthetic drugs and the widening legalization of marijuana, a curious bright spot has emerged in the youth drug culture: American teenagers are growing less likely to try or regularly use drugs, including alcohol.

title: Raphael Bostic to Be First Black President of a Fed Regional Bank
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta on Monday shattered a 104-year-old racial barrier by naming Raphael W. Bostic as its new president.

title: Tech Roundup: Amazon Error Is a Reminder That No Company Is Infallible
description: For all of its famed redundancy, the internet at times can appear awfully fragile.

title: Artur Mas, Former Catalan Leader, Is Barred From Holding Office
description: Artur Mas, the former leader of Catalonia, was banned on Monday from holding public office, after being found guilty of disobeying a Spanish court when his government staged a nonbinding independence vote in Catalonia in 2014.

title: French Fries Ready to Dip in Lower Manhattan
description: An appropriate new addition to Le District, the French market in Battery Park City, is a French fry counter. Hand-cut fries are cooked to order, emerging hot and crisp with a soft interior. They are served with an array of dipping sauces, including several mayonnaise variations and Maille French mustard on tap. The fries can be plated as poutine, the French Canadian indulgence with cheese curds and gravy, or as a topping for a nice portion of beef Bourguignon. Beer and wine are also served: Fries, $5.45 to $8.95, Bar  Frites, Le District, Brookfield Place, 225 Liberty Street (West Street), 212-981-8588, ledistrict.com.

title: Gins That Conjure Spring Delights
description: Four new garden gins from Tamworth, a distillery in Tamworth, N.H., dress their juniper with other tastes in colorfully labeled bottles. Spruce has a resinous flavor; Apiary is a slightly sweet, honeyed spirit that barely suggests gin; and Wild Hops is earthier with spicy notes. My favorite is Flora, in which the juniper is graced with hints of violet and geranium, making it ideal in a French 75. Steven Grasse owns the distillery. He is the advertising executive who created Hendricks, a Scottish gin touched with cucumber: Tamworth Garden Gins, $54.99 for 750 milliliters, warehousewinesandspirits.com.

title: Airlines Drop Cuba Flights, Citing Lower Demand Than Anticipated
description: Just six months after being the first airline to sell seats on regularly scheduled flights to Cuba, Silver Airways, a regional carrier based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that specializes in smaller markets, will scrap its service to the island next month. It is the latest industry move to underscore that fewer Americans are traveling to Cuba than originally anticipated.

title: Suicide Bomber in Afghanistan Slams Into Packed Minibus
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber rammed a sedan full of explosives into a packed commuter minibus in Kabul on Monday, according to Afghan officials and eyewitnesses.

title: Spiral Jetty Is Named an Official State Work of Art by Utah
description: The great American sculptor Robert Smithson, who died in a plane crash in 1973 at the age of 35, was as interested in the history of the Earth as he was in the history of art. He once considered becoming a geologist and said that as a reader, the entire history of the West was swallowed up for him in a preoccupation with notions of prehistory and the great prehistoric epics starting with the age of rocks.

title: Mexico Protests Ruling Knocking It Out of World Baseball Classic
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico  It was around 4:45 p.m. here on Monday when the first sign emerged that Mexico had lost its protest over the way it was eliminated from the first round of the World Baseball Classic. For that was when Venezuela, and not Mexico, took the field at Estadio de Bisbol Charros de Jalisco y Atletismo for pregame stretching and batting practice.

title: Write Me a Concerto: Yo-Yo Ma and Esa-Pekka Salonen on Their New Work
description: CHICAGO  A few years ago, after they had shared more than a couple postconcert martinis, Yo-Yo Ma had a request for the composer and conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen: Write me a concerto.

title: More Croissants for the Flatiron District
description: Rory Macdonalds Ptisserie Chanson opens March 20. The pastry shop and bread bakery is a highly ambitious debut for the chef. In addition to a typical ground-floor retail counter, with communal seating and an open kitchen, the bakery includes a subterranean dessert bar for sweet tasting menus, to open soon. Mr. Macdonald, a London native whose baking is decidedly French, was the pastry chef for Hakkasan restaurants in America. He makes eight kinds of bread, breakfast pastries, fancy cakes, individual pastries and chocolates. Soups, salads, sandwiches and a proper afternoon tea will be served in the ground-floor dining area: Ptisserie Chanson, 20 West 23rd Street, 929-423-8880, patisseriechanson.com.

title: Playful Vegan Dishes at a New Grocery in Manhattan
description: No, that is not smoked salmon in the deli case of the new vegan Orchard Grocer. It is smoked carrots effectively presented in salmon garb  sliced thin, the color of sockeye, and well cured in the kinds of pickling spices used for the fish. I want to be playful and witty, said Joya Carlton, the executive chef and an alumna of Butchers Daughter and Buvette. Ms. Carlton shows her Virginia roots with pulled jackfruit, shredded in barbecue sauce on a bun. Orchard Grocer is owned by the sisters Sara and Erica Kubersky, who also own MooShoes next door, and carries nut-milk cheeses, condiments, chocolates and other foods. This whole world of vegan has exploded, Ms. Carlton said: Orchard Grocer, 78 Orchard Street (Broome Street), 646-757-9910, orchardgrocer.com.

title: In Praise of an Aggressively Unfashionable Shoe
description: There are running shoes and hiking boots, tennis sneakers and ballet slippers. There are cleats for soccer, fins for swimming and sandals for the beach. And then there are Dansko clogs, beloved by chefs, sculptors, gardeners, masseuses, surgeons  and also by every soft-skilled woman in New York I know.

description: The designer and founder of the California-based firm Etc.etera shares some of her favorite spots around the city.

title: On the Verge: Sally Breer
description: Inside her apartment in Los Angeless Frogtown neighborhood.

title: At Home With Young Hollywoods Decorator of Choice
description: THERES A STORY BEHIND everything in Sally Breers apartment, including the apartment itself. For more than a year, shed had her eye on the out-of-the-way complex of 13 live-work units located in Los Angeless Frogtown neighborhood, an erstwhile manufacturing hub bordered by two freeways and the L.A. River to the east. Breer fell in love with the complex when she visited a collector friend who lives there, but residents rarely vacated the airy, affordable, immensely private units. And so Breer, who has the laser-focused persistence of a successful artist, waited. And waited. Eventually, a loft opened up. She moved in last May.

title: Proposed Law Could Be a New Attack on Civil Rights
description: A chilling little bill is working its way through Congress. It could have the effect of ending the class action as an American institution.
