description: A much-anticipated annual tradition in Washington is here: The National Cherry Blossom Festival will take place through April 16. The event, celebrating its 90th anniversary, commemorates the 1912 gift of 3,000 cherry trees from Japan to the United States. Today, there are 3,800 cherry blossom trees, and visitors to the city during the festival can see them in bloom.

title: When Your Ex-Boyfriend Starts Dating Women
description: I am a gay man in my late 20s. For a few months, I hung out with this young guy who had just finished college. We had a strong sexual connection but not much else in common, so the relationship didnt last. I was pretty disappointed. Now I see that he is going out with a woman. I dont know much about relationships, but I know when a guy likes having sex with other guys. And the woman hes going out with is a friend of a friend. Should I tell her about my relationship with her new boyfriend?

title: Tech Roundup: Behind One of Yahoos Big Hacks
description: Tensions between the United States and Russia have festered for months over the issue of cybersecurity. Russian hackers were identified by American intelligence officials as having tried to aid Donald J. Trump during the presidential election last year, at the expense of Hillary Clinton.

title: That Visionary Wharf Rat, J.M.W. Turner
description: In a luminous new show at the Frick Collection, the great 19th-century maritime painter J. M. W. Turner explores the waterfront gateways to Europe with the ravenous eye of a man long deprived of travel. Along with his fellow Brits, Turner had endured nearly two decades of restrictions on visiting the Continent during the Napoleonic Wars. And with other artists, he was eager to cross the Channel in search of fresh and worldly material for his equally tourism-starved patrons.

title: A Couples Secrets, Not Found on Instagram
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Mike Krieger and Kaitlyn Trigger married, they skipped the newlywed clichs of cruises and jewels and feted themselves with something that would always remind them of their bond. They got matching safes. Safes that stored the couples secrets.

title: U.S. Roster, if Not the Country, Starts to Catch W.B.C. Fever
description: SAN DIEGO  There is no Bryce Harper, Mike Trout or Kris Bryant in the lineup. The pitching staff does not include Clayton Kershaw or Madison Bumgarner  or even Noah Syndergaard, who gave voice to why, unlike in many other countries, so many Americans are uninterested in playing in the World Baseball Classic.

title: Architecture of Independence in Africas Fast-Growing Cities
description: Did you make it to the eighth episode of The Young Pope, the one which sees our saintly Jude Law bring his pontifical dog-and-pony show to a country called Africa? Astounding, in 2017, that you can still get away with this: the anonymous land ruled by a military dictator, where children are starving, dust rises in the heat and there isnt a skyscraper or cellphone in sight. (The Young Pope was actually shot outside Cape Town, which has no shortage of both.) You would not know, from most Western media, that Africans live in a whole range of places, bucolic or bustling  and that Africa is urbanizing faster than anywhere on earth.

title: Trump Budget Guru, Long a Fiscal Hawk, Now Has to Sell Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Making the rounds at the Capitol on a recent evening, Mick Mulvaney, President Trumps budget director, decided to add an unscheduled stop: a meeting of the House Freedom Caucus, the group of hard-line conservatives that once counted Mr. Mulvaney as a founding member.

title: Trump and G.O.P. Work to Win Repeal of Obamas Health Act
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump and House Republican leaders worked Thursday to win conservative support for legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act, offering concessions to speed cutbacks in Medicaid and dismantle more of President Barack Obamas signature health law.

title: Introducing Match Book, a New Literary Advice Column
description: Trying to figure out which book to read next? Searching for a book you loved years ago but cant fully remember? Want to know where to start in a prolific authors oeuvre?

title: Chief Justice Roberts Considers the Case of Tom Sawyer
description: WASHINGTON  Tom Sawyer, Mark Twains fictional rapscallion, turned up on Wednesday night in the ballroom of a fancy Washington hotel. No stranger to adventures and indignities, he was there to endure something new and distinctively American: a lawsuit.

title: Heres How She Planned Her Wedding in a Week
description: Emily Hardman said there were only two times she felt momentary anxiety: when she didnt have a dress, and when she couldnt quite figure out the flow of the reception program. But then I decided to let it go, figuring it would work out, and that people couldnt really be disappointed with five days of wedding planning, she said. Its amazing how fast you can actually plan a wedding.

title: I Planned My Wedding in 5 Days. You Could, Too.
description: It was the day before my wedding, and I still didnt have a dress. In less than 24 hours, family and friends would be gathering to celebrate the occasion, and at this point my something borrowed was going to be an entire church outfit. Was I concerned? Not really, and not for long. I decided to throw a Hail Mary at my mom by asking if she would make a skirt to match the $10 top I found. She did. And it was lovely.

title: Chelsea Clinton to Publish Childrens Book, She Persisted
description: Chelsea Clinton, the daughter of former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and former President Bill Clinton, will release a childrens picture book on inspirational American women titled She Persisted.

title: Immigration Agents Should Not Stalk Courts, California Justice Says
description: LOS ANGELES  Californias top judicial official asked the Trump administration on Thursday to stop immigration agents from stalking courthouses in the state to make immigration arrests.

title: Geert Wilders, Rex Tillerson, Justin Trudeau: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Cautious Optimism in Brazil as Appetite Returns for I.P.O.s
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The three-year drought of initial public offerings in Brazil is finally starting to dissipate, giving hope to investors from So Paulo to New York and Boston. Some expect that more than a dozen deals will be filed by the end of the year.

title: Mark Nathan on Bringing Your Teflon to Get Honest Feedback
description: This interview with Mark Nathan, C.E.O. of Zipari, a health insurance software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Search for Clues to What Causes Whale Strandings
description: Take half a dozen retired Navy dolphins and put them in a huge tank with a trainer and some oversized hula hoops for six months and what do you get? Potential clues to unraveling the mysteries behind why some marine mammals are susceptible to mass strandings, scientists hope.

title: Face to Face, and Ignored, at a Job Interview
description: I recently interviewed with two human resources representatives for a job as an executive assistant to the chief executive of a big company. Both were in their mid-20s. (They gave their ages.) Within five minutes, one pulled out his phone and began scrolling, and texting or emailing, occasionally looking up and making a comment before going back to his phone. Even when he asked a question, he sometimes focused on his phone.

title: Self-Driving Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: Trumps Food, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Assailant Tried in Racially Charged Beating Gets Four Years
description: A Hasidic man convicted of gang assault in the beating of a black student in Brooklyn was sentenced on Thursday to four years in prison. Within hours, however, the sentence was stayed pending an appeal.

title: The Debate Over How to Fix Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A B.D.S. Founder, on Israels Anti-Boycott Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Green Beer and Rank Hypocrisy
description: Does green beer taste better laced with hypocrisy? Does shamrock smell sweeter perfumed with historical amnesia?

title: One Wine Glass to Rule Them All
description: At some point along every wine drinkers arc of discovery, the time comes to invest in a set of glasses.

title: Oversight Committee Releases Documents on Flynn's Trip to Russia
description: The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform released a set of documents on Thursday that revealed new details about a trip Michael Flynn took in December 2015 on behalf of RT, a Russian television network with close ties to the Kremlin.

title: Michael Flynn Was Paid by Russian-Linked Firms, Letter Shows
description: WASHINGTON  Michael T. Flynn, President Trumps former national security adviser, was paid over $65,000 by companies linked to Russia in 2015, according to a letter released on Thursday by congressional investigators.

title: Trump Budget Is Heavy Lift, Even for G.O.P. Congress
description: WASHINGTON  After eight years of chafing under President Barack Obamas fiscal priorities, congressional Republicans were longing for a budget proposal that did the two things that have become the partys mantra: Make broad cuts to federal spending and reduce the federal deficit.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Why Republicans Keep Talking About Health Care Prongs
description: When faced with a tough question about nearly any aspect of the health bill moving through Congress, Republican officials like to mention their plans other prongs.

title: Steve Penny Resigns as U.S.A. Gymnastics President
description: Steve Penny resigned on Thursday as president of U.S.A. Gymnastics, the sports national governing body that is embroiled in a far-reaching sexual-assault scandal.

title: Trump Takes a Gamble in Cutting Programs His Base Relies On
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps proposal on Thursday for deep cuts to the budgets of a broad part of the federal bureaucracy was billed as a tough-minded and necessary corrective to the growth of the governments power. But even members of his own party questioned some of the cuts  and what was not being cut.

title: In Conversation: Jonathan Anderson & Anthea Hamilton
description: This is the most unbelievably comfortable seat, says the Irish fashion designer Jonathan Anderson as he nestles into a Modernist Danish chair at the Hepworth Wakefield gallery in Yorkshire, in the north of England. I could just sit here forever, agrees the Turner-nominated artist Anthea Hamilton softly, as she settles in alongside Anderson. They are immersed in Hamiltons exhibition there, where she explores early British Modernist works from the Kettles Yard house  an art gallery and onetime home of the influential late collector Jim Ede in Cambridge, England. (Hamilton curated pieces from the space, which is currently closed and being remodeled, for the installation, which also includes contemporary works). Her show has a certain stillness  a stark contrast to the gallery rooms next door, where the finishing touches of Jonathan Andersons curatorial debut, Disobedient Bodies, are being put precisely into place.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through March 25. Kravets Wehby Gallery, 521 West 21st Street, Manhattan; 212-352-2238, kravetswehbygallery.com.

title: George Soros: When Hate Surges
description: President Trump has wasted no time in cracking down on immigration. He pledged to build a wall, hire 15,000 new Immigration and Customs Enforcement and Border Patrol agents and speedily deport millions of undocumented immigrants. He justified these actions by claiming that immigrants regularly flout the rule of law and pose a threat. In his first speech to Congress, he directed the Department of Homeland Security to create a new office  Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement, or Voice  dedicated to helping victims of crimes perpetrated by removable aliens.

title: Trump Is Not Above the Courts
description: CHICAGO  So much has happened during these early weeks of President Trumps administration that it is easy to lose sight of the single event that may well have the most powerful and troubling impact on American democratic society.

title: Stolen Etruscan Vessel to Be Returned to Italy
description: A stolen Etruscan vessel will be returned to Italy thanks in part to the efforts of a hunter of looted antiquities.

title: Salve for La Guardias Traffic Troubles: A Temporary Ramp
description: Theres a new way to escape from the traffic that has been jamming La Guardia Airport since an overhaul of its main terminal began last summer.

title: Books Can Take You Places Donald Trump Doesnt Want You to Go
description: LONDON  Whenever I was encouraged by my elders to pick up a book, I was often told, Read so as to know the world. And it is true; books have invited me into different countries, states of mind, social conditions and historical epochs; they have offered me a place at the most unusual gatherings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Reality Is Not What It Seems

title: Review: Netflix Tries to Channel Its Chi With Marvels Iron Fist
description: When Danny Rand can focus his chi and turn into Iron Fist  a superhero with a superpowered, glowing right hand  hes unbeatable.

title: Mount Etna Erupts in Sicily, Injuring at Least 10
description: Mount Etna, Europes largest and most active volcano, has been grouchy in recent weeks, sending up plumes of glowing red lava and ash that could be seen for miles from its peaks in Sicily.

title: Ben Jobe, Southern University Basketball Coach, Dies at 84
description: Ben Jobe, a coach who turned Southern University into one of the highest-scoring college basketball programs in the nation and led them to an upset victory over Georgia Tech in the 1993 N.C.A.A. tournament, died on March 10 at his home in Montgomery, Ala. He was 84.

title: Public Broadcasters Fear Collapse if U.S. Drops Support
description: Public radio and television broadcasters are girding for battle after the Trump administration proposed a drastic cutback that they have long dreaded: the defunding of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Review: Tickling Giants Made It in Egypt, but They Werent Laughing
description: Theres a lot to laugh at, and to learn from, in Tickling Giants, a documentary that starts off by telling the story of one man and ends up speaking volumes about satire, freedom of expression and political pressure.

title: German Authorities Raid U.S. Law Firm Leading Volkswagens Emissions Inquiry
description: FRANKFURT  German authorities searched the offices of the American law firm Volkswagen hired to conduct an internal investigation of its emissions fraud, the carmaker confirmed on Thursday, raising questions about the credibility of the companys efforts to uncover wrongdoing in its ranks.

title: Review: T2 Trainspotting: Time to Pay the Piper
description: Ghosts of the past, both literal and figurative, haunt T2 Trainspotting, Danny Boyles droll and wistful return to the Scottish reprobates who, 21 years ago in Trainspotting, made heroin addiction a blast and bodily waste a metaphor for squandered lives.

title: March Madness
description: Galas were held this week for the Art Production Fund, Williamstown Theatre Festival, Citymeals on Wheels and Human Rights Watch.

title: Review: Mark Morris Shows the Gift of Intricate Simplicity
description: Henry Purcells Dido and Aeneas and Benjamin Brittens Curlew River arent an obvious pair. They may both be short English music dramas centered on the suffering of a woman, but they are otherwise so different that putting them together begs some explanation. The link is Mark Morris.

title: This Weeks Movies: March 17, 2017
description: The New York Times film critics review "Beauty and the Beast, Song to Song and T2 Trainspotting."

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: Galas for the Arts and Human Rights
description: The Art Production Fund raised $500,000 at its March 13 gala at the former Four Seasons restaurant, now called the Landmark Rooms. Also that day, the Williamstown Theater Festival held a gala at Tao Downtown. Citymeals on Wheels held a benefit at Daniel on March 12. And Human Rights Watch held a gala at Cipriani 42nd Street on March 15.

title: Review: A Provocateurs Recounting in The Show About the Show
description: For much of The Show About the Show, its director and star, Caveh Zahedi, talks directly to the camera, briskly recounting the endless misadventures he and others experienced while producing an initially sexually explicit semidocumentary series for the nonprofit cable network BRIC TV. (This movie is in fact a revised compilation of the programs.)

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: District Attorneys Letter on Not Charging de Blasio
description: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, wrote that after an extensive investigation, "this office has determined that the parties involved cannot be appropriately prosecuted.

title: After 29 Years, Kingpin of African Soccer Is Abruptly Shown the Door
description: Cameroons victorious players were still dancing on the field at the Stade de lAmiti in Libreville, Gabon, when Issa Hayatou  African soccers apparently unassailable kingpin  decided he deserved a moment of triumph, too.

title: Manifest of Ship That Carried Pences Grandfather
description: Richard Michael Cawley, the maternal grandfather of Vice President Mike Pence, arrived in the United States in 1923 on the S.S. Andania. The ship's manifest shows his answers to immigration questions. Source: Passenger Arrival Lists, U.S. Customs Service, U.S. National Archives, via Ancestry.com

title: Review: A Return Home Defies a Fathers Wish in P.S. Jerusalem,
description: In P.S. Jerusalem, the filmmaker Danae Elon moves back to the city of her youth, where her father, the Israeli author Amos Elon, begged her never to return. But after his death in Italy in 2009, and shortly after learning she was pregnant again, Ms. Elon left Brooklyn for Jerusalem with her partner, the photographer Philip Touitou, and their small sons. Ms. Elons experiences living in Jerusalem as an insider-outsider are the subject of this essay documentary, which ruminates on how Israel has changed since Ms. Elons youth and how Israel changes Ms. Elons family.

title: I Am an American Because of Him: The Journey of Pences Grandfather From Ireland
description: WASHINGTON  The S.S. Andania, plain and sturdy, pulled into New York Harbor on April 11, 1923, after a slow journey from Liverpool, England. In a third-class cabin was a gray-eyed Irishman named Richard Michael Cawley, fleeing poverty and war.

title: Wells Fargo Leaders Reaped Lavish Pay Even as Account Scandal Unfolded
description: Wells Fargo and its leaders have expressed much contrition about the banks misdeeds, which included setting up as many as 2 million bank accounts without customers consent. Top executives have surrendered more than $90 million in compensation, fired employees at all levels and vowed to clean house.

title: New Concerto, New Leader: A Big Day at the New York Philharmonic
description: Wednesday was a big day for the New York Philharmonic, both onstage and in its offices.

title: Review: Mean Dreams Presents Lovers on the Lam With Quiet Skill
description: Nathan Morlandos Mean Dreams may use a time-honored premise  young lovers on the lam (see: Badlands)  but it does so with such quiet, gently appealing assurance that it makes the template seem fresh again. Jonas (Josh Wiggins, who made an effective screen debut in Hellion in 2014) is a 15-year-old high school dropout working on his parents struggling farm when he meets Casey (the Canadian actress Sophie Nlisse, from The Book Thief), who with her father has just moved in down the road.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: Tested Early, and Again by Draw, Mount St. Marys Says Its Ready
description: BUFFALO  Miles Wilsons first college game was on the road in front of more than 10,000 fans in Morgantown, W.Va., where the West Virginia Mountaineers beat his Mount St. Marys Mountaineers by nearly 30. Eight more road games followed, a trip, designed partly to raise the programs visibility, that left Mount St. Marys with a 1-8 record but also the experience of playing two major-conference champions and six total teams that ended up in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: The False Feminism of Fearless Girl
description: From the moment that Fearless Girl, a bronze statue of a small child, landed in Lower Manhattan to face off against the 7,000-pound sculpture of a charging bull, installed in 1989 as a symbol of Wall Street resilience, there were reasons, it seemed, to feel queasy. Where, for instance, was her nanny? While others saw a narrative of female defiance  the girls torso thrusts forward as if she has a chance  I imagined a poorly paid caregiver fired for leaving her charge unattended, and ultimately trampled to death.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: Review: Ratmanskys Confectionery Shop Also Serves Ballet Poetry
description: COSTA MESA, Calif.  The virtues of Whipped Cream, American Ballet Theaters new two-act creation, are many and important  though its bizarre to speak of importance in a piece about a sweetshop coming to life. Alexei Ratmansky, resident artist with the troupe since 2009, is the choreographer: The world premiere occurred on Wednesday here at the Segerstrom Center for the Arts. The score is Richard Strausss Schlagobers (1924)  surely until now the most generally forgotten ballet music by a major composer.

title: Review: Betting on Zero Tracks a Crusade Against Herbalife
description: The topic of Betting on Zero might initially seem better suited to the business pages. The film chronicles the hedge fund manager William A. Ackmans crusade against Herbalife, a nutritional-products company that sells its goods through a chain of civilian distributors.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: Review: In Atomica, Hunting for Clues in a Nuclear Waste Zone
description: Dagen Merrills sci-fi thriller Atomica comes from Syfy Films, so were not talking about Arrival-level effects or sophistication. Much of it, however, was shot in a former Titan II missile silo, which lends the film a gritty veracity you dont find in a green-screen digital setting. And while its premise and some of its effects may be B-movie grade, Atomica  like the best B movies  delivers an unexpectedly rewarding kick.

title: Why the Whitneys Humanist, Pro-Diversity Biennial Is a Revelation
description: Since moving downtown, the Whitney Museum of American Art has grown up, thanks to a larger, dashing new building, more ambitious exhibitions and new responsibilities brought by rising attendance and membership. No surprise, its biennial has grown up, too. Perhaps less expected: So has the art in it. This shows strength and focus make it doubly important at a time when art, the humanities and the act of thinking itself seem under attack in Washington.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Cultural, economic and social divisions dont just spring up overnight  a point illustrated by three books on our list this week: Joan Didions South and West (notes from a 1970s road trip), Marjorie J. Spruills Divided We Stand (the story of the National Womens Conference of 1977 and its aftermath), and Tressie McMillan Cottoms Lower Ed (a deep dive into students who attend for-profit colleges). Iconic buildings dont just spring up either, as Wendy Lessers engaging biography of the architect Louis Kahn makes clear. Philosophy takes time too: in the 35 years worth of essays and fragments that make up Other People: Takes and Mistakes, David Shields establishes himself as a funny, vulnerable and humane 21st-century Socrates. Had it with gravity? Head for outer space: via Jaroslav Kalfars debut novel, Spaceman of Bohemia (for adventurous adults) and Jon Agees picture book Life on Mars (for adventurous kids).

title: Review: Fiction and Nonfiction Blur in Actor Martinez
description: Acting is weird, says the actor Arthur Martinez, playing an actor named Arthur, in Mike Ott and Nathan Silvers metanovelty Actor Martinez.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Will You Attend the March for Science on Earth Day?
description: Wed like to hear opinions about the march from scientists and people who work in the sciences, those who favor the demonstration as well as those who oppose it..

title: Part of Vermonts N.C.A.A. Team and Hoping, One Day, to Be Able to Play
description: MILWAUKEE  Josh Speidel was late. This happens a lot with Speidel, a redshirt freshman for the University of Vermont, who can be forgetful. The Catamounts coach, John Becker, flagged down Speidel in the breakfast room at the team hotel Wednesday morning, and moments later Speidel limped into the lobby and sat down for an interview, his left hand clamped on a right arm that refused to be still.

title: Trump Digs In on Wiretap, No Matter Who Says Differently
description: WASHINGTON  The former president denied it. So did the former national intelligence director. The F.B.I. director has said privately that it is false. The speaker of the House and the chairmen of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees  all three Republican  see no indications that it happened.

title: Rise and Shine
description: The photographer Sasha Arutyunova is a nocturnal person who rarely sees the sunrise. But she forced herself to engage NYC during its daybreak hours by taking photographs. She completed the project with a grant from the Center for Faith & Work.

title: For Want of a Comma
description: Punctuation matters.

title: Capturing New York City, as It Awakens
description: Some people love the morning, and the joy of rushing out to meet the new day, when all of lifes possibilities are out there to be grasped. And other people are sane.

title: Review: One Couples Promising Taipei Story, Slowly Undermined
description: The too-brief filmography of the Taiwanese director Edward Yang is one of the most vital in all of cinema. Yang, who was in his 30s when he began his filmmaking career in the 1980s, made seven features; his final film, the intimate but also nearly epic Yi Yi (2000), was until recently the only one to have received a proper release in the United States. (He died of cancer in 2007.) His most challenging masterpiece, A Brighter Summer Day (1991), was released in theaters stateside in 2011 and on DVD and Blu-ray last year; now, a restoration of Taipei Story (1985), Yangs spectacular second feature, is having an official theatrical release in the United States before being released on DVD.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: Republicans, Wilders, Tillerson: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Song to Song, Terrence Malicks Latest Beautiful Puzzle
description: One of the loveliest images in Song to Song, the latest from Terrence Malick, is of ripples expanding across a small pool of water, echoes of a womans quick step. Mr. Malick, one of cinemas philosopher kings, embraces fluidity as a visual principle and his films are filled with lifes ebb and flow  its swirling waters, swooping birds, stirring trees, billowing curtains, and gliding people and cameras. He loves silence and stillness, and the image of sunlight caressing a womans motionless face. But he is a searcher, and that searching informs his visual style with its restless, moving pictures.

title: Making a Pro Debut at Boxings Mecca, 126 Pounds of Irish Moxie
description: It sounds like the kind of St. Patricks Day that could only happen in a John Ford movie: parading, pageantry and a pint or two, finished off with an old-fashioned donnybrook.

title: Share Your Story: How Would Trumps Budget Affect You?
description: Would you be directly affected positively or negatively by President Trumps budget proposal? Tell us how.

title: Trumps Budget Cuts Some Agencies to Their Lowest Levels in Decades
description: The presidents plan would cut spending for many agencies to historically low levels.

title: The Stranger in the Woods for 27 Years: Maines North Pond Hermit
description: THE STRANGER IN THE WOODSThe Extraordinary Story of the Last True HermitBy Michael Finkel203 pages. Knopf. $25.95.

title: Ancestral Climates May Have Shaped Your Nose
description: Ask anyone what the nose does, and the reply will most likely be related to smell. We appreciate our noses because they help us experience flowers and fresh-baked cookies.

title: De Blasio Proves That Some Laws Are Made to Be Unbreakable
description: Among the gold medals awarded to Bill de Blasio on Thursday was one for limbo-dancing his way past election laws so he and his allies could funnel money into 2014 state legislative campaigns at a rate 10 times the supposed limit.

title: Trump Takes Nashville
description: NASHVILLE  Fight the power, the Facebook message said. Get two tix for Donald and let the place stay empty!

title: Now Cleared, de Blasio Gets Out of His Own Way in Mayors Race
description: It was the moment the New York political world had been waiting for since last spring, when word of a flurry of state and federal investigations into Mayor Bill de Blasio first emerged: prosecutors had finished their work and no criminal charges would be brought against the mayor or his aides.

title: Roger Federer and Nick Kyrgios Get Ready to Square Off
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  It is an easy sell: Roger Federer versus Nick Kyrgios.

title: Florida Prosecutor Takes a Bold Stand Against Death Penalty
description: MIAMI  In a startling denunciation of capital punishment in a state with one of the nations largest death rows, the new chief prosecutor in Orlando, Fla., said Thursday that her office would no longer seek the death penalty.

title: Scientists Bristle at Trump Budgets Cuts to Research
description: Before he became president, Donald J. Trump called climate change a hoax, questioned the safety of vaccines and mocked renewable energy as a plaything of tree-huggers.

title: Acting U.S. Attorney's Statement on de Blasio
description: Joon H. Kim, the acting United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, issued a brief statement explaining the decision not to prosecute Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: A Dent in Europes Populism
description: Bucking fears that the Netherlands would be the next populist domino after Britains vote to leave the European Union and Donald Trumps election in the United States, the Dutch turned out in record numbers on Wednesday to reject the anti-Muslim platform of the far-right candidate Geert Wilders. The Dutch election was seen as a potential bellwether for elections in France and Germany, where far-right populist parties have gained ground. But it is premature to assume the Dutch result signals the defeat of far-right populism in Europe.

title: Park Honoring Franklin Roosevelt Excludes Disabled People, Suit Says
description: A New York park honoring President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who used a wheelchair for years, is not fully accessible to disabled people, according to a class-action suit filed against the state and the conservancy that runs the park.

title: Id Be Hurt and Upset: Cities Fear Trumps Cuts to Urban Programs
description: BALTIMORE  In a dimly lit church basement, James Gaymon III spent much of Thursday staring at practice questions as he prepared for his high school general equivalency diploma exam. He recently moved into an apartment two blocks from the underpass where he spent 20 years sleeping, and often smoking crack.

title: Ex-Workers at S.E.C. Nominees Firm Urge Him to Denounce Travel Ban
description: Some members of the elite legal community are making an unusual appeal to one of their own, asking that he speak out against the White Houses attempt to restrict travel to the United States by people from several predominantly Muslim countries.

title: Little Brother With Rare Illness Inspires Creighton
description: After Creighton guard Isaiah Zierden hit a 3-pointer Friday night in the semifinals of the Big East tournament, he sent a message back to Omaha. He took an arrow out of an imaginary quiver and fired it toward the sky.

title: Rough Night at the Circus
description: Dear Diary:

title: Reveal of Trump Tax Records Brings Rachel Maddow Record Viewership
description: Rachel Maddows slow-walk reveal of President Trumps decade-old tax records on Tuesday night did not earn her much journalistic praise.

title: Edge or Liability? White House Ties May Cut Two Ways for Goldman
description: During a recent meeting with stock analysts to discuss a huge loss, the chairman of the Royal Bank of Scotland sought to inject some levity.

title: James Cotton, Blues Harmonica Legend, Dies at 81
description: James Cotton, a pioneering harmonica player who worked with Muddy Waters and Howlin Wolf and helped establish his instrument as an integral part of modern blues, died on Thursday in Austin, Tex. He was 81.

title: A Broadway Musical Brings Out Canadian Soft Power
description: They are streaming into New York from Calgary, Montreal and, of course, Newfoundland. Some wear red, stay warm in gloves adorned with the maple leaf, or carry a provincial flag.

title: Trump Adviser Gary Cohn to Sell Stake in Chinese Bank Giant
description: The White House economic adviser Gary D. Cohn is selling a significant holding in the worlds largest bank  which happens to be in China  as he clears potential conflicts of interest to serve in his new role.

title: Louise Erdrich, Matthew Desmond Among Winners of National Book Critics Circle Awards
description: Louise Erdrichs novel LaRose, which centers on two Native American families in North Dakota whose lives are upended by a horrific hunting accident that kills a 5-year-old boy, won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction on Thursday.

title: Text to Text | Edward Hopper and Roald Dahl
description: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

title: Delicate but Critical Dance for New U.N. Leader and New U.S. Envoy
description: UNITED NATIONS  Hes the new leader of the United Nations, an international diplomat who spent years focused on the plight of the worlds refugees. Shes a diplomatic neophyte representing an America First administration that seeks travel bans for refugees and mocked the United Nations.

title: New York City E.M.T. Is Killed in Ambulance Theft in the Bronx
description: One member of New York Citys emergency medical services was killed and another injured when a man got into the drivers seat of their ambulance and ran over one of them in the Bronx on Thursday night, the authorities said.

title: With E.P.A. Cuts, States Would Lose Help in Emergencies
description: WASHINGTON  Late one Friday night in 2014, Ohios environmental agency received word of a frightening test result from Toledos water supply: A toxic greenish substance had rendered the drinking water of half a million Toledo residents unsafe to drink.

title: From a Placid Judge, a Cutting Rejection of Trumps Travel Ban
description: Judge Derrick K. Watsons language was stern, even biting: In an order on Wednesday that blocked President Trumps travel ban from taking effect, he rebuked the government for its illogic and for presenting arguments he bluntly called not true.

title: Mr. Trumps Tear-Down Budget
description: The White House budget director, Mick Mulvaney, defended the presidents budget proposal for 2018 by saying it puts numbers on Mr. Trumps campaign promises.

title: A Shift From Soft Power Diplomacy in Cuts to the State Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson was on the other side of the planet on Thursday when the Trump administration announced that it would slash his departments budget by 31 percent, potentially eliminating thousands of jobs.

title: Womens National Team Stands Firm in Face of U.S.A. Hockeys Deadline
description: After members of the United States womens national hockey team decided Wednesday to boycott the approaching world championship over stalled negotiations for increased wages and support, U.S.A. Hockeys executive director, Dave Ogrean, announced that he looked forward to continuing our discussions with the players.

title: Buoyed by Trump Budget Plan, Pentagon Draws Up a Shopping List
description: WASHINGTON  The biggest beneficiary in President Trumps budget  the Defense Department  released a broad wish list on Thursday, signaling what it would do with its proposed $54 billion windfall, filling its shopping cart with desires including Apache helicopters for the Army, anti-submarine planes for the Navy, fighter jets and more training for selected personnel.

title: Hacker Is a Villain to Russia and the United States, for Different Reasons
description: MOSCOW  Before United States prosecutors accused him of having orchestrated one of the largest computer thefts, Dmitry A. Dokuchaevs legal problems were deepening in Russia, where he was once known by the hacker alias Forb and specialized in purloining credit card numbers.

title: Sheldon Silver Appeal Looks to New Definition of Corruption
description: A lawyer for Sheldon Silver cited a unanimous Supreme Court decision that narrowed the definition of what kind of conduct can serve as the basis for a corruption prosecution, as he argued on Thursday that the disgraced former speaker of the State Assembly should be acquitted or granted a new trial.

title: Campaign Pledges Haunt Trump in Court
description: WASHINGTON  In quick succession on Wednesday night, federal judges in Hawaii and Maryland blocked President Trumps revised travel ban. They said statements Mr. Trump had made as a presidential candidate, including his call for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States, helped doom the executive order.

title: Quotation of the Day: Researchers Bristle at Extent of Cuts
description: As to climate change, I think the president was fairly straightforward: Were not spending money on that anymore.

title: Irish Premier Uses St. Patricks Day Ritual to Lecture Trump on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  On a calendar of foreign visitors that includes President Xi Jinping of China and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, the annual visit by the taoiseach of Ireland to mark St. Patricks Day should have been a delightful distraction for President Trump.

title: Zack Wheeler, Mets Big Question Mark, Provides Some Answers
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  The biggest question on the Mets pitching staff took the mound Thursday afternoon for the second time this spring. In his second outing, after sitting out for two seasons, Zack Wheeler allowed two runs on three hits in two and a third innings. He threw 50 pitches, walked one and struck out two.

title: Tanner Glass, Called Up by Rangers, Adds Physical Element at Forward
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault found himself with 15 healthy forwards at practice on Thursday  so many that he decided to assemble a fifth line and told them to dress in green jerseys. They stood out from the rest of the group not only because they looked different, but also because  for the moment  they were on the outside looking in.

title: Well-Built
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I really love a tough Friday puzzle, if only after the fact. Its like taking one of those functional fitness classes at the gym where straps, heavy balls and pushing a weighted sled are involved and you think youre about to die at the moment the instructor declares warm-up over! This grid by Jacob Stulberg had some of everything like that: super-long entries, hardly any breaks in difficulty and even a clever little theme cluster that I didnt get until the puzzle helpfully explained it to me in the far southeast corner, at 49D.

title: Review: Brothers Joined by Fate and Furniture in The Price
description: Arthur Millers The Price, from 1968, is a tragedy disguised as a rummage sale. It plucks the slipcovers off the autobiographical material that Miller worked over for so much of his career  what sons owe to fathers, what brothers owe to each other, what the world owes to men of reasonable integrity. Women might owe things, too, but that was rarely Millers concern.

title: Brooklyn NYPD Bribery Scheme Said to Be Even More Widespread
description: A member of a neighborhood watch group in Brooklyn who obtained dozens of handgun permits by bribing officers in the New York Police Departments gun-licensing division also handed out cash and gifts to other officers assigned across Brooklyn, prosecutors said Thursday.

title: What Trumps Budget Could Mean for the Affected Agencies
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps first federal budget proposal calls for spending billions of dollars on the military and border security while imposing deep cuts to government departments that deal with the environment, diplomacy, the arts, science and cities.

title: Canadians Fear Trumps Budget Will Devastate Great Lakes
description: The Trump administrations proposal to eliminate funding for a program that addresses major environmental and health threats in the Great Lakes would have a devastating impact on millions of Canadians, officials and environmental groups said on Thursday.

title: The People From Government Sachs
description: During World War II, President Franklin D. Roosevelt selected Sidney J. Weinberg, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, to serve as the assistant director of the War Production Board. Mr. Weinberg was one of the few men on Wall Street to support Roosevelt in the 1932 election, and he went on to advise Presidents Harry S. Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Joseph Nicolosi, Advocate of Conversion Therapy for Gays, Dies at 70
description: Joseph Nicolosi, a clinical psychologist whose advocacy of conversion therapy to diminish peoples same-sex attraction made him a vocal part of the ex-gay movement but marginalized him within the mental-health profession, died on March 8. He was 70.

title: Merkels Playbook for Trump
description: Angela Merkel and Donald Trump couldn't be more different. They disagree on immigration, NATO, the European Union and trade. As they meet for the first time as world leaders, here are the factors that may shape their relationship.

title: Knicks Continue Tailspin by Falling to Nets for Second Time in Five Days
description: As the Knicks walked off the court at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, slumping their shoulders and giving halfhearted hugs to the conquering Nets, a familiar reality set in. With their 121-110 loss to the Nets, they clinched their fourth straight losing season, and their 13th in the last 16 years.

title: U.S. Military Denies Reports It Bombed Mosque in Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military said that it had carried out an airstrike against a meeting of Qaeda militants on Thursday in Syria and that a number of the extremists had been killed.

title: Corrections: March 17, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Fed Acts. Workers in Mexico and Merchants in Malaysia Suffer.
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  Francisca Hervis Reyes and her family have persevered on the border, working in factories more than 1,300 miles from their hometown. They remained even as deadly warfare between drug cartels turned this city into one of the most dangerous on the planet.

title: Will Taylor, a Design Blogger Whos Not Afraid of Color
description: Name Will Taylor

title: Pushed Into the Future When Illness Strikes (in an Unlikely Place)
description: There I was, in a drab hospital room with some drab pornography, trying my best to produce a sperm sample. At 24, I wasnt exactly at an age when a man should be concerned about his fertility. But somehow I had gotten the mumps. And the mumps had caused a rather obscene amount of swelling in a place other than my cheeks. A place that is essential to fertility.

title: Northwestern Makes Its N.C.A.A. Debut a Winning One
description: Follow our live coverage of the N.C.A.A. tournament here.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Everybody Wants Some!! and Charles Manson
description: Everybody Wants Some!!, Richard Linklaters nostalgic campus comedy, arrives on Amazon. And ABC presents Truth and Lies: The Family Manson, a two-hour documentary about Charles Manson and the murders by cult members in 1969.

title: Geert Wilders, Donald Trump, France: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Purdues Caleb Swanigan Slims Down and Sees His Prospects Soar
description: Caleb Swanigan, Purdues dominant power forward, is good at jumping. On the basketball court. Off the basketball court. In so many ways, it is hard to count them. It is also hard to imagine them, given where he came from.

title: From Chorus to Lead in Miss Saigon
description: When "Miss Saigon" first looked to Broadway in 1990, controversy erupted over the fact that a white man was portraying a lead role. Jon Jon Briones, who is Asian, was in the chorus then. Today, he is one of the show's stars.

title: Tefaf Maastricht, While Softer, Still Impresses
description: For 30 years, Tefaf Maastricht in the Netherlands has been the worlds pre-eminent fair for art and antiques. But in recent years, collectors tastes have shifted from the old to the new, and Europe has experienced terrorist attacks and political instability. Tefafs reputation as a destination event faces challenges, particularly now that the fair, run by a nonprofit foundation, has established smaller  spring and fall editions in New York.

title: Bucket List
description: Whats on your bucket list, or wish list of things you want to do before you die?

The Week in Pictures: March 17, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: The Week in Pictures: March 17, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: Questions for: Museums Tell Teenagers: Were Here for You
description: Article: Museums Tell Teenagers: Were Here for You

title: The Seasons Arent What They Used to Be
description: SEWANEE, Tenn.  Sexual energies were loosed early this year in Tennessee, then quashed. In February, spring peepers made my ears ring as I walked through wetlands east of Nashvilles honky-tonks. These frogs were a month ahead of their normal schedule.

title: Conservative Fantasies, Colliding With Reality
description: This week the Trump administration put out a budget blueprint  or more accurately, a budget blueprint. After all, real budgets detail where the money comes from and where it goes; this proclamation covers only around a third of federal spending, while saying nothing about revenues or projected deficits.

title: Let Bannon Be Bannon!
description: I continue to worry about Steve Bannon. I see him in the White House photos, but he never has that sprightly Prince of Darkness gleam in his eye anymore.

title: Even on Their Special Day, Irish Immigrants in America Have Reason to Fear
description: On this St. Patricks Day, the closest thing America has to a national holiday of immigration, unless you count Thanksgiving, feast of the undocumented Pilgrim, let us pause to honor the immigrants everybody loves.

title: When the Irish Invaded Canada
description: We let these people into our country, and what did we get but an epidemic of cholera and criminals. They filled the jails and mental hospitals, the orphanages and poor houses. More than half of those arrested in New York City, just before the Civil War, were Irish.

title: Trumpcares Lonely, and Seedy, Supporter
description: The Republican health bill doesnt have many outside supporters. Groups representing doctors, nurses, hospitals, retirees, patients of various diseases and even insurers have all criticized it. Some of the only outside praise has come from the chief executive of Anthem, the countrys second largest insurer.

title: Which Photograph Stays In Your Memory?
description: Of the millions of photographs or images you have viewed in your lifetime, are there any that stand out? Is there just one that pops into your mind? Why?

title: Jimmy Kimmel Thinks Trump Should Watch Sesame Street
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: How to Get on an Arenas Kiss Cam
description: Dress in the home teams gear. We want to feature fans who are wearing team apparel, who are in Kings jerseys and hats, thats first and foremost, says Brooklyn Boyars, the senior director of game presentation and events for the Los Angeles hockey team. (The Kings tend not to put fans rooting for the opponent on their video screen, she adds, but if we do, we might poke fun at them.) Or decorate yourself conspicuously in over-the-top costumes, hair or face paint. We have a gentleman who wears a full European-type cape and crown, and he carries a goblet, Boyars says. It has absolutely nothing to do with the Kings, but thats why we like it.

title: Judge John Hodgman on the Limited-Edition Peanuts Monopoly Set
description: Jamie writes: My friend Lori, a big fan of Snoopy, bought a limited-edition Peanuts Monopoly set for $10 at an estate sale. She looked up the price online, discovered it sells for $99 and now wants to resell it. I want her to enjoy it as shed planned. Please order her to play Monopoly with me.

title: Well Go No More a Roving
description: This poem takes its title from a poem by Lord George Byron, the most notorious of the 19th-century English Romantic poets. Byron wrote his poem  at age 29  to lament his weariness and loss of energy for youthful misbehavior. McCraes poem adapts the poems basic structure to explore a different sort of weariness: His seems to be a song of postelection despair, an exhausted giving up on the possibility of ever escaping the legacy of slavery.

title: The 3.5.17 Issue
description: RE: DEPARTMENT OF JUSTIFICATION

title: The Battle of Miss Saigon: Yellowface, Art and Opportunity
description: Miss Saigon started with an audacious idea  create a musical that explores the end of the Vietnam War through an ill-fated romance between a virginal Vietnamese bargirl and a hunky American G.I.

title: Norman Podhoretz Still Picks Fights and Drops Names
description: These parties I mentioned, Norman Podhoretz said the other day, everybody gave parties. And there was a lot of drinking. Some visiting literary celebrity would show up, Partisan Review would make a party or I would make a party. Everybody came. And it was a really passionate intellectual life. Its hard to imagine today, but people actually came to blows over literary disagreements.

title: Stories
description: THE DARK AND OTHER LOVE STORIESBy Deborah Willis254 pp. Norton, $24.95.

title: Putting a Faithful Friend to the Test
description: I moved to Qatar a few years ago, after being invited to study at one of the schools there. Born and raised in Pakistan, I was excited for the experience of living in Doha, although there were a few things I was concerned about. For one, the heat: In August, when I was to arrive, the sun scorches the earth with temperatures well above 100 degrees. I had also heard that in Qatar, my faith might cause problems.

title: Snoop Dogg, Bow Wow and an Ill-Advised Retweet
description: Amid the thousands of tweets that fly from the keyboards of journalists every day, occasionally comes one that sets off an alarm: Whoops. Should I have said that? Wednesday afternoon, that bell should have sounded shortly after a New York Times culture writer, Sopan Deb, reacted to a vulgar tweet by the rapper Bow Wow with a comment Deb now wishes he hadnt made.

title: Trump and Ryan: Health Bill May Test Marriage of Convenience
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, once the master pitchman for namesake vodka, steaks and now-moldering casinos, seems disinclined to attach his surname to the health care bill some allies have derided as Ryancare.

title: Friday Mailbag: Where Are the Women?
description: This week letters to our inbox came in at a leisurely clip. Perhaps our East Coast readers were busy shoveling their driveways and sidewalks  not that were complaining. But it left this weeks mailbag short and sweet. If you missed them, the public editors column addressed two issues this week.

title: Navigating Our Shameful, Maddeningly Complex Student Aid System
description: This month, the federal government switched off a tool that student financial aid applicants used to import their tax data into forms, adding laborious steps to a process that the tool was supposed to simplify. The possibility of identity theft was the stated reason, big enough to shut down the tool in the middle of the busy season for people seeking aid.

title: How to Pick the Right New York City Suburb
description: Alison and Scott Simon saw many benefits to living in Manhattan. There was the diversity they loved, the easy commute, along with great bars, restaurants and cultural sites within walking distance or a subway ride.

title: With Their Leaders at a Loss, Marine Veterans Fight Abusers
description: As a Marine infantry sergeant, James LaPorta once led an intelligence team in Afghanistan. Now, as a private citizen, he is doggedly tracking the moves of an online group that has been secretly compiling and sharing nude photos of hundreds of women in the Marine Corps.

title: Why Are Basketball Games So Squeaky? Consider the Spiny Lobster
description: It is the unofficial soundtrack of basketball, a noise consistently heard but rarely considered  rubber-soled shoes squeaking on the hardwood.

title: Burrowing Under Luminous Ice to Retrieve Mussels
description: KANGIQSUJUAQ, Quebec  For eight months a year, the flat bay around the village of Kangiqsujuaq in far northern Quebec freezes beneath a white expanse of ice and snow, leaving ravens and foxes as rare signs of life, along with Inuit and their dogs. Throughout the winter the Inuit hunt seal and caribou, and they fish through the ice for arctic char.

title: A Harvest Underneath the Ice
description: For one hour, as the tide goes out, ice caves in northern Quebec yawn open with an abundance of mussels. Travel under the ice in 360 with the Inuit who harvest the mussels before the tide floods back in.

title: Teaching With: Kim Suozzis Last Wishes
description: Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind. This film, and Kims quest, raise important questions about the inevitability of death, the value of hope and the possibilities of science.

title: Donald Trump, N.C.A.A. Basketball, St. Patricks Day: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Tai Chi Encourages Calm. So Why Are Its Chinese Fans Stressing Out?
description: BEIJING  Last year, Indian yoga made Unescos list. In 2011, South Koreas taekkyeon became the first martial art so honored.

title: Morning Agenda: Mnuchins Global Debut, and the Goldman Connection
description: Steven T. Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, makes his first appearance on the global stage today.

title: Not My Mothers Yoga
description: My mother used to chant in Sanskrit in her study before sunrise every morning. Though she died when I was 16  22 years ago  I always hear her voice that way. Off-key, but strangely hypnotic, the language both complicated and pure, reverberating around our house.

title: In Vietnam, a Doyenne of Food Expands to Tasteful Lodging
description: Doubles from $120.

title: where have classical musics uppercase letters gone?
description: Composers of what is known, for better or worse, as classical music have broken over time with sonata form, tonality, serialism and minimalism. And in recent decades, quite a few have also broken with the shift keys on their keyboards.

title: A Restaurant That Brings the Italian Coast to Miami Beach
description: Forte dei Marmi is a tale of three seaside resort towns. You have Miami Beach, home to this pale, airy and nicely tailored restaurant that opened in late 2016. Then there is its name, which comes from a popular Tuscan beach town. Finally, there is Nerano, down on the Amalfi Coast, where the chef, Antonio Mellino, has had a restaurant since 1983. It all adds up to food kissed by a sea breeze, always a good idea in a sun-drenched location.

title: Misfits Burn Fast and Bright in This Tale of 80s Athens
description: RUNNINGBy Cara Hoffman271 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.

title: Machiavelli Runs Up Against the Borgias
description: IN THE NAME OF THE FAMILYBy Sarah Dunant429 pp. Random House. $28.

title: A Pessimist and an Optimist, Building a Life in Sync
description: She is a Russian-born mezzo-soprano.

title: Graham, Taylor, Cunningham: Three Titans. One Stage. One Night.
description: The modern dance tree has many branches, but three of its sturdiest belong to the groundbreaking choreographers Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor. Their influence  on stages, in studios and in schools  is just as crucial as ever. Squabbles aside  and, yes, theyve had a few  Graham, Cunningham and Mr. Taylor are tied by choreographic blood.

title: New York Today: Defining St. Patricks Day
description: Updated, 11:52 a.m.

description: THE LUCKY ONESBy Julianne Pachico254 pp. Spiegel & Grau. $26.

title: In-Flight Question: Shouldnt That Propeller Be Moving?
description: Maybe I have too much time on my hands, but there have been moments I have wondered if in an emergency I would be the one to scream, Oh, no, were all going to die!

title: What if Sociologists Had as Much Influence as Economists?
description: Walk half a city block in downtown Washington, and there is a good chance that you will pass an economist. People with advanced training in the field shape policy on subjects as varied as how health care is provided, broadcast licenses auctioned or air pollution regulated.

title: The Life of Her London Parties, Now Out to Save Them All
description: LONDON  In the 25 years since she moved to London from her native New Jersey, Amy Lam has staged a late-night manifesto on protected sex in one of the citys most notorious gay cruising zones, and created and hosted a sex and sexuality-themed TV game show. She has also emceed a cabaret night whose guests have included a flame dancer, a hula hoop artist and a stripping dwarf.

title: A Woman in Charge: A Biography of Liberias President
description: MADAME PRESIDENTThe Extraordinary Journey of Ellen Johnson SirleafBy Helene CooperIllustrated. 320 pp. Simon & Schuster. $27.

title: Rex Tillerson Rejects Talks With North Korea on Nuclear Program
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson ruled out on Friday opening any negotiation with North Korea to freeze its nuclear and missile programs and said for the first time that the Trump administration might be forced to take pre-emptive action if they elevate the threat of their weapons program to an unacceptable level.

title: 13 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: Japanese Government and Utility Are Found Negligent in Nuclear Disaster
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government and the electric utility that operated the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant were negligent in not preventing the meltdowns in 2011 that forced thousands of people to flee the area, a district court in eastern Japan ruled on Friday.

title: Tom Ford and Thakoon Give Up on See-Now, Buy-Now
description: Fighting the fashion system is hard.

title: Man Charged With Murder in Death of Emergency Worker in the Bronx
description: They lived on the same Bronx block, but on opposite ends of the citys system for treating the sick and emotionally disturbed.

title: California Today: The 29-Year-Old Taking Over for Vin Scully  No Pressure
description: Good morning.

title: Debunking a Myth: The Irish Were Not Slaves, Too
description: It has shown up on Irish trivia Facebook pages, in Scientific American magazine, and on white nationalist message boards: the little-known story of the Irish slaves who built America, who are sometimes said to have outnumbered and been treated worse than slaves from Africa.

title: Airstrike Kills Dozens of Somali Migrants Off Yemens Coast
description: SANA, Yemen  More than 30 Somali migrants, including children, were killed in the Red Sea on Friday when a military helicopter opened fire on their boat, according to Yemeni and United Nations officials.

title: How Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee, Cancer Expert, Spends His Sundays
description: Working as a cancer physician, researcher and assistant professor at Columbia University doesnt seem to be enough action for Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee. He is also a renowned science writer, having won the Pulitzer Prize in 2011 for The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer. His latest book, The Gene: An Intimate History, will be released in paperback in May. Dr. Mukherjee, 46, lives in the Flatiron district, with his wife, Sarah Sze, 48, a sculptor; their two daughters, Leela, 11, and Aria, 7; and their Papillon, Ginger.

title: Home Sales Brisk in New York Citys Suburbs
description: Real estate market temperatures in the commuter suburbs around New York City range from warm to sizzling, having never really cooled down for the winter.

title: Cholesterol-Slashing Drug Can Protect High-Risk Heart Patients, Study Finds
description: The first rigorous test of an expensive new drug that radically lowers cholesterol levels found that it significantly reduced the chance that a high-risk patient would have a heart attack or stroke. These were men and women who had exhausted all other options.

title: George Osborne, Ex-Finance Chief of U.K., to Become Editor of Evening Standard
description: LONDON  Britain is no stranger to its leading figures moving between journalism and politics. Now, George Osborne, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, is set to be prominent in both spheres at once.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Drinking, Weight Loss and a 2-Hour Marathon
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: How to Do Cobra Pose
description: This back-bending pose can help strengthen the back muscles, increase spinal flexibility and stretches the chest, shoulders and abdomen.

title: Taraji P. Henson: Talking Cookie, and the Impact of Hidden Figures
description: If you love Taraji P. Henson as the music executive Cookie Lyon in the Fox drama Empire or as the mathematician Katherine Johnson in the Oscar-nominated film Hidden Figures, savor those performances, because you likely wont see anything like them again.

title: Trump Offers No Apology for Claim on British Spying
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump provoked a rare public dispute with Americas closest ally on Friday after his White House aired an explosive and unsubstantiated claim that Britains spy agency had secretly eavesdropped on him at the behest of President Barack Obama during last years campaign.

title: Want to Make Budget Cuts? Start Here
description: The Trump administration on Thursday provided an outline of its first budget, a proposal that will dramatically reshape how the United States spends money on national security and defense. There is no question that the United States security spending patterns need to be rebalanced to better address urgent security challenges. The Trump budget will not do that.

title: What My Red State Sees in Me
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  I saw my first loose gun in 2014 here in Austin. I was headed to lunch with a friend at a homey Mexican place near the University of Texas campus, where I was a graduate student. As we pulled into a parking spot on the side of the road, I noticed a white man  tall, with dirty yellow hair and crumpled white clothes  on the sidewalk. Seconds later, he had pulled out a pistol and was waving it at someone outside the restaurant. My friend ducked. I backed out, spun the car around, and drove off.

title: Turkeys Quarrel With Europe
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has escalated a war of words with Germany and the Netherlands.

title: What Is This Iron Fist Controversy? (Also, What Is Iron Fist?)
description: With a racially-tinged controversy and terrible early reviews, few Netflix projects have had as bumpy a rollout as the new Marvel series Iron Fist. The fourth Marvel-Netflix collaboration, after Daredevil, Jessica Jones and Luke Cage, Iron Fist introduces the final character in the coming Avengers-style superhero crossover series, The Defenders. All 13 episodes of Iron Fist arrive on Netflix on March 17, so before deciding whether or not to watch, familiarize yourself with the character, the controversy and what people are saying about the series.

title: Everyday Design Objects Get a Sleek Upgrade
description: An unexpected finish or material transforms the utilitarian into something exceptional.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Irvine Welsh
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Irvine Welsh, the author of the book Trainspotting, which became a film in 1996. T2 Trainspotting, the sequel, opens in theaters today.

title: An Unorthodox Gift to Notre Dame from Muslim Philanthropists
description: Rafat and Zoreen Ansari, medical doctors who were born in Pakistan, have spent the last four decades working and raising their three children in a suburb of South Bend, Ind., where they also have earned a reputation as civic leaders.

title: Illustrated Interview | David Adjaye
description: The Ghanaian-British architect, who will be knighted by Queen Elizabeth II this year and whose current projects include the new Studio Museum in Harlem, sketched his answers with a Paper Mate Flair felt-tip pen.

title: A Venice Apartment by Fabrizio Casiraghi
description: The architect and designer brought together African masks, French bamboo chairs and Chinese screens  all in a single eclectic space.

title: Reimagining the Venice Apartment
description: When the architect and designer Fabrizio Casiraghi was in school, he studied urban planning. It turns out this comes in handy for projects that are worlds in and of themselves.

title: 135 Years Ago, Another Travel Ban Was In the News
description: And as for the assertion that we have no moral right to say who shall and who shall not come into the country, no true American will for one moment admit a doctrine so dangerous, or make a confession so weak.

title: What Happened on Day 2 of the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Stay here for live updates, scores and analysis from the first round of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Derek Walcott, Poet and Nobel Laureate of the Caribbean, Dies at 87
description: Derek Walcott, whose intricately metaphorical poetry captured the physical beauty of the Caribbean, the harsh legacy of colonialism and the complexities of living and writing in two cultural worlds, bringing him a Nobel Prize in Literature, died early Friday morning at his home near Gros Islet in St. Lucia. He was 87.

title: Real Madrid Draws Bayern Munich in Champions League Quarterfinal
description: The defending champions Real Madrid will play Bayern Munich in the quarterfinals of this seasons Champions League, as Fridays draw pitted two of the competitions favorites against each other.

title: New York Has 77 Police Precincts. Why Do Their Numbers Go Higher?
description: Q. There are 77 police precincts in New York City. How then can there be precincts with numbers 109 (Flushing) and higher? Why dont the precinct numbers end with 77?

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MOST WANTED MAN IN CHINA: My Journey From Scientist To Enemy Of The State, by Fang Lizhi. Translated by Perry Link. (St.Martins Griffin/Holt, $17.99.) Before his death in 2012, Fang was one of Chinas most noted scientists and an outspoken critic of the Communist government. His memoir, detailing the regimes absurdities and hypocrisies, was written during 13 months spent at the American Embassy after the Tiananmen massacre.

title: What Are the Best Snacks Before Bedtime?
description: Q. I know its not good to eat close to bedtime, but I get hungry. What are the least harmful things I can eat  or drink  say, an hour or two before going to bed?

title: Want a Feminist Daughter, Dad? Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie Has Advice for You, Too
description: Father, Heal Thyself: The Nigerian novelist and feminist thinker Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie has a new book on the hardcover nonfiction list  Dear Ijeawele: Or, A Feminist Manifesto in 15 Suggestions debuts at No.4. The book began as a letter to a childhood friend, who wondered how she might raise an empowered daughter. Adichies customarily direct advice was, more or less, to overthrow the system: Teach her that the idea of gender roles is absolute nonsense, she writes. Do not ever tell her that she should or should not do something because she is a girl. Because you are a girl is never a reason for anything. Ever.

title: 1892: Strained Relations Between England and Turkey
description: CAIRO  The presence at Alexandria since yesterday of nine English ironclads with 3,400 men on board, while the Turkish ship carrying the Sultans envoy has neither arrived nor is officially signaled, has called forth some comment in the political world, and has revealed the somewhat strained relations between England and Turkey.

title: Hand Me the AUX Cord
description: Q. I just bought a Chevy Bolt. It has no CD player. I have a music history course on 48 CDs, and other courses on CDs. I am only going to listen to these once, so I dont want to have to transfer the audio to a USB device. Is there a CD player that I can hook up to a Bolts audio system?

title: What Do Trumps Tax Forms Mean to You?
description: The revelation this week of pages from President Trumps 2005 tax forms provided a glimpse at documents that he has refused to disclose, breaking with decades of tradition. The disclosure elicited some strong responses from taxpayers across the country as the April 15 filing deadline approaches. The New York Times spoke with a few people from either side of the partisan divide. Here are excerpts.

title: Syria Fires Missiles at Israeli Warplanes
description: JERUSALEM  The Syrian armed forces fired antiaircraft missiles at Israeli warplanes that had struck targets deep in Syria early Friday, in what appeared to be the most serious clash between the two militaries since the start of the Syrian civil war six years ago.

title: Ways to Save (and Not Spend) Your Tax Refund
description: More than 70 percent of taxpayers are expected to get refunds this year, the Internal Revenue Service reports. That represents a big opportunity, according to savings advocates and financial advisers, since many Americans struggle to set aside cash for emergencies.

title: How Much Is Your House Worth Per Minute?
description: Suburban home buyers can get a lot more house for the money compared with city dwellers. Sales prices tell us how much money people spend for their space, and train schedules tell us how much time. Together they give us a sense of what a suburban home is worth in a cost-per-minute figure.

title: Malted Milk Fudge Ripple Ice Cream
description: Malted and streaked with fudge, this frozen treat is sweet nostalgia in an ice cream bowl.

title: A Chocolate Malted You Can Scoop
description: The summer after I moved back to Brooklyn from Manhattan, I created a weekly ice cream ritual.

title: Jayson Tatum Is the Breakout Star of Dukes Freshman Class
description: Every skill that drew recruiters to Jayson Tatum in high school in the St. Louis area, every one that draws N.B.A. scouts to see him today, was on display during Dukes run last week at the A.C.C. tournament in Brooklyn.

title: Its Point Guard Injured, Creighton Turned to Justin Patton, Its Freshman Center
description: When Creighton lost its star point guard, Maurice Watson Jr., to a season-ending knee injury in January, its season almost went down with him.

title: Dave Chappelle on Trump, Cosby and His Netflix Deal
description: Whether lambasting racial inequity with his trademark eccentricity, or putting on a Jheri curl wig for a now-legendary parody of Rick James, Dave Chappelle has long been considered one of the most exciting stand-ups in comedy. But he hasnt issued a special or album since his infamous decision to walk away from the critically acclaimed Chappelles Show on Comedy Central  and a $50 million contract  in 2005.

title: A New Film Series Will Show Movies From Countries Affected by the Travel Ban
description: In a protest against Islamophobia, a new film series, to be shown across the country in May, is to feature movies from countries affected by President Trumps latest travel ban, which has been blocked by the courts.

title: 350 Square Feet, Two Kids, Two Cats and a Rabbit
description: Maligned though New Yorks rental market may be, a fortunate few do manage to stumble onto the ideal apartment early and easily. Such was the case with Sacha Moore, who scored a charming one-bedroom with a working fireplace in Brooklyn Heights (with the help of her sister) when she and her husband moved back to the city from New Orleans in 2003.

title: Iranian Pilgrims Can Participate in Hajj This Year, Saudi Arabia Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia said on Friday that Iranians would be able to participate in this years hajj pilgrimage to the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, a rare bright spot in relations between the two regional rivals.

title: For Refugee Agencies, a Court Stay Only Adds to the Confusion
description: Last month, in anticipation of the Trump administration shutting down the flow of refugees entering the United States, Church World Service, one of the groups that handles resettlement, took drastic measures. It laid off all but 40 of the 600 employees at its African center that prepared refugees for travel.

title: Bombing Foiled After Lull in Bangladesh Attacks Ends
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  The police in Bangladesh said they foiled an apparent bombing attempt at a checkpoint of Bangladeshs elite police force on Saturday, less than a day after an attempted suicide attack outside another police facility.

title: Going From Marginalized to Welcomed in the Workplace
description: When Michaela Mendelsohn, the owner and chief executive of the Pollo West Corporation, arrived at her restaurant companys holiday party in 2006, it had been a year since she had seen most of her 500 employees. In that time, she had worked from her home in the Conejo Valley of Southern California and was in contact with only a handful of staff members.

title: In Rural Michigan, Harvesting Sounds Instead of Soybeans
description: Heartland harvest

title: Penn State Hockey, Still New to Division I, Chases First Tournament Berth
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa.  Five years ago, the only hockey team on campus here was the Penn State Icers, a perennial club hockey power in the top division of the American Collegiate Hockey Association. They competed against the likes of Ohio University, Lindenwood and Delaware.

title: Left-Leaning Documentary World Seeks Right-Wing Perspective
description: Three of the 10 top-grossing political documentaries ever are the work of the right-wing polemicist Dinesh DSouza. The most powerful documentarian in the country is the White House adviser Stephen K. Bannon. Still, the rap on documentaries is that they preach to a left-leaning choir, one still trying to figure out how Donald J. Trump became president.

title: For Former Hockey Champions Michigan and Michigan State, Unaccustomed Struggles
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  In college hockey, Michigan and Michigan State are storied programs with much in common.

title: When the Boss Is Half Your Age
description: Christine Sabo had three decades of fund-raising experience behind her when, three years ago, she was hired as the vice president for major giving at a nonprofit in South Florida. But right about the time Ms. Sabo came aboard, the chief executive had accepted a new position elsewhere.

title: Sending Students to the Corner (of Their Screens)
description: Stephanie Steenstra, 41, is an online teacher at California Connections Academy in San Juan Capistrano.

title: Montreal Chefs Are Fuming Over a Casinos French Import
description: MONTREAL  The part of Quebecs government responsible for luring tourists to this city singles out one star attraction in particular.

title: Tech Roundup: Portrait of a Russian Hacker
description: A day after federal officials indicted four men  two of whom were Russian intelligence agents  on charges they hacked into the internet company Yahoo and breached 500 million customer accounts, a portrait emerged of one of the suspects.

title: Suburban? Just Dont Call Her a Jersey Girl
description: In the quarter century since I moved out of my parents house in Newton, Mass., I have spent approximately zero seconds thinking Id like to move back to such a suburban idyll.

title: Big City Book Club Returns With Paul Austers 4321
description: After a long hiatus, the Big City Book Club is returning with a bang.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: British Police Net a Butterfly Killer, and Now He May Face Jail
description: LONDON  The killer, a former body builder, stalked his frail victims at nature reserves, in one case clambering over a locked gate armed with a net, before he chased them down, trapped them and carried them away, dead or alive.
