description: THE DEATH OF EXPERTISEThe Campaign Against Established Knowledge and Why It MattersBy Tom Nichols252 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Trump Lays Plans to Reverse Obamas Climate Change Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump is poised in the coming days to announce his plans to dismantle the centerpiece of President Barack Obamas climate change legacy, while also gutting several smaller but significant policies aimed at curbing global warming.

title: Jerry Krause, Who Gave Michael Jordan His Supporting Cast, Dies at 77
description: Jerry Krause, the general manager who orchestrated the Chicago Bulls dynasty of the 1990s, assembling the teams that Michael Jordan led to six N.B.A. championships, has died. He was 77.

title: Family of C.I.A. Consultant Sues Iran Over His Disappearance
description: The family of a part-time consultant for the C.I.A. who vanished a decade ago in Iran filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against that country, claiming that it had used a campaign of deception and lies to conceal its role in his imprisonment.

title: Didi Gregorius of Yankees Is Expected to Miss First Month of the Season
description: Yankees shortstop Didi Gregorius will begin the season on the disabled list with a shoulder injury that is expected to sideline him until May, General Manager Brian Cashman said Tuesday.

title: Rostros de la guerra: retratos del ELN
description: Esta serie de fotos de Ramn Campos Iriarte, fotgrafo colombiano,exploran las complejidades de un territorio controlado por el ELN en Choc.

title: Review: Shakespeare Meets Black Power in Caesar/X
description: Its not very often that a family show concludes on a stage littered with corpses. But then, there is no way to sugarcoat the brutality of Julius Caesar, and this new, abridged production, from the Acting Company, is kid-friendly mostly by virtue of context: It is being presented at the New Victory Theater, where audience members often need booster seats rather than a well-stocked bar.

title: A Test for Tillerson, and for U.S. Strategy on ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  If President Trump has a secret plan to defeat the Islamic State, as he promised during the presidential campaign, then his international allies in that fight are hoping to get a glimpse of it on Wednesday.

title: In a Rare Survey, Cubans Express a Hunger for Economic Growth
description: MEXICO CITY  A hunger for economic opportunity. An embrace of tourism. Hope in a new era of normalized relations with the United States.

title: Where Does Gorsuch Stand on Torture? Its Hard to Say
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee grilled Judge Neil M. Gorsuch on Tuesday about torture and presidential power. It was in reference to President George W. Bushs claim in December 2005 that, as the commander in chief, he could bypass a statute in which Congress had tightened anti-torture rules. The recurring questions on this issue at Judge Gorsuchs Supreme Court confirmation hearing renewed interest in an unresolved dispute over the scope and limits of presidential power in national security matters.

title: How Would the Repeal of Obamacare Affect You?
description: We would like to know.

title: Medicaid Fight Lands in New York, Crossing Party Lines
description: ALBANY  The governor likened it to an act of war. A Democratic congresswoman called it a brazen case of theft. And a Republican legislative leader suggested it could be a crisis on the level of 9/11.

title: Philadelphia Prosecutor Indicted on Corruption Charges
description: R. Seth Williams, the embattled district attorney for Philadelphia, was indicted Tuesday on bribery and fraud charges, a remarkable turn for the citys top prosecutor, who was considered a rising Democratic star before he became embroiled in scandal and ethics violations.

title: Coincidence or Message? A Timeline of Provocative Acts by North Korea
description: North Korea is well known for provocative acts aimed at its most immediate adversaries  South Korea, the United States and Japan. But Kim Jong-un, the 33-year-old leader who took over in 2012 after his father died, also has sent increasingly blunt messages of defiance and even hostility to China, the Norths ally, protector and provider, vexing the Chinese as well.

title: Bruno Le Roux, French Interior Minister, Resigns Amid Financial Inquiry
description: PARIS  Frances interior minister, Bruno Le Roux, announced on Tuesday that he was stepping down, after a financial prosecution office said it was opening a preliminary investigation into parliamentary jobs he gave to his daughters.

title: If You Like the Arts, Save the N.E.A., Advocates Tell Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Just before 9 a.m. on Tuesday, Grace Alt, an 18-year-old from Wyndmoor, Penn., stood outside Senator Bob Caseys office door. Wearing a sash inscribed with the word Thespian, she was among 700 people who traveled here to ask lawmakers to oppose President Trumps proposal to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Dole Case Illustrates Problems in Shareholder System
description: The share ownership system in the United States is fraying. And while its shortcomings have been largely behind the scenes, now they are going to cost some innocent shareholders money.

title: Standard Morning Fare, on the Go
description: Dear Diary:

title: Supreme Court Limits Presidents Power to Fill Vacant Posts
description: The Supreme Court on Tuesday restricted a presidents options in temporarily filling vacant government posts, a crucial matter when partisan tensions make it hard to win Senate confirmation for appointees.

title: After Failed Cabinet Bid, Puzder Leaves Restaurant Post
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The fast-food magnate Andrew F. Puzder, who last month withdrew his nomination to be President Trumps secretary of labor amid bipartisan opposition, is now giving up the top job at his restaurant company, too.

title: 9 Deaths Are Linked to Rare Cancer From Breast Implants
description: A rare cancer first linked to breast implants in 2011 has now been associated with nine deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday.

title: In Stark Terms, Ex-Chairman of Dean Foods Describes Passing Along Tips
description: The former chairman of Dean Foods testified in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday that he had provided an enormous amount of inside information about the company to a friend and golfing partner, the Las Vegas sports gambler William T. Walters.

title: Barred From Canadian Embassy Parties: Cardboard Trudeau
description: He was the consummate politician: tall, dapper and always willing to be trotted out for public appearances, even when someone licked his face. The only problem? Hes made of corrugated paper.

title: Uber Board Stands by Travis Kalanick as It Reveals Plans to Repair Its Image
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The board of Uber is confident in its chief executive, Travis Kalanick, board member Arianna Huffington said on Tuesday, providing a show of support as the embattled ride-hailing company seeks to repair its reputation.

title: Fact Check: Democrats Critiques of the Republican Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  With the House vote on the Republican health care bill looming on Thursday, Democrats are unified in their opposition.

title: A Republican Health Care Bill in Search of a Problem
description: Republican leaders in the House have been huddling over the last few days in a frantic search for enough votes to win passage of their proposed revision of Obamacare, in the process making an already flawed bill even worse. One measure of their desperation was a cynical last-minute provision that would shift Medicaid costs from New Yorks rural and suburban counties to the state government, pleasing upstate Republicans who represent those counties but reducing coverage provided by the state.

title: Why Letting Go, for Trump, Is No Small or Simple Task
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump is a man seriously susceptible to snagging himself in the nettles of obsession. In the last three weeks, no compulsion has so consumed his psyche, and his Twitter account, as the deeply held and shallowly sourced belief that President Barack Obama tapped his phones.

title: Spicer Says Maryland Rape Case Shows Need for Illegal Immigration Crackdown
description: Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, elevated a rape case at a Maryland high school in which an undocumented immigrant has been charged to national attention on Tuesday, saying in response to a reporters question that it was an example of why the Trump administration was committed to a crackdown on illegal immigration.

title: Harder for Homeless to Enter N.Y.C. Shelters, Report Finds
description: More homeless families are being denied permanent shelter in New York City, and many are being forced to reapply multiple times before the city finds them eligible to enter the system  two trends that burden already fragile families, according to a new report by the Coalition for the Homeless.

title: Mound Is a Microcosm of the Disparity Between the Yankees and the Red Sox
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The pitching matchup at Steinbrenner Field on Tuesday said a lot about the state of the two teams present. The Boston Red Sox started Chris Sale. The Yankees started Bryan Mitchell.

title: Review: In Spill, an Oil Disaster Seems Too Big for the Stage
description: Spill, written and directed by Leigh Fondakowski at Ensemble Studio Theater, is an impassioned and overloaded documentary drama exploring the Deepwater Horizon disaster of 2010. Zealously researched and intellectually rangy, it reckons with tragedies both human and environmental. This is a play to make you clutch at your program and then rush to recycle it.

title: Gorsuch Says Hed Rule Against Trump if Law Required It
description: WASHINGTON  Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trumps Supreme Court nominee, sought to assure the Senate and the nation on Tuesday that he would be a fair-minded and independent justice. He said he would not hesitate to rule against Mr. Trump if the law required it, and he repeated his earlier private criticism of Mr. Trumps attacks on judges who had ruled against the administration.

title: Colin Dexter, 86, Dies; Creator of Inspector Morse, a Sleuth on Page and Screen
description: Colin Dexter, a British mystery writer whose irascible, poetry-loving detective, Chief Inspector Morse, pursued clues and cask-conditioned ale through 13 novels and a popular television series, died on Tuesday at his home in Oxford, England. He was 86.

title: Market Dip Bucks a Streak of Trump-Inspired Optimism
description: It had been one of Wall Streets more confounding streaks.

title: U.S. Military Investigating Reports of Civilian Deaths in Syria Airstrike
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military has begun formally investigating an American airstrike in Syria that officials said targeted dozens of Qaeda operatives at a meeting place that activists and local residents maintain was part of a religious complex where 49 civilians were killed.

title: Quotation of the Day: Becoming Rodrigo Duterte, Strongman in the Philippines
description: Violence in the house, violence in the school and violence in the neighborhood. That is why he is always angry. Because if you have pain when you are young, you are angry all the time.

title: Lawyer for Family of Sergei Magnitsky, Dead Russian Whistle-Blower, Is Seriously Injured
description: MOSCOW  A lawyer representing the family of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a Russian auditor and lawyer who died in prison in 2009 after uncovering a $230 million fraud targeting an American-born financier, suffered severe head injuries on Tuesday after plunging from his Moscow apartment building.

title: Fresh Airs Opposite
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Have you ever been witness to something absolutely amazing, like those people who can spin plates on sticks, and wondered just how long they could keep this amazing thing going?

title: Devils Sink the Rangers in Overtime
description: NEWARK  Entering their game on Tuesday, the Rangers had a 99.99 percent chance of making the playoffs, compared with a 0.000003 percent chance for the Devils, according to SportsClubStats.com. Despite that gap, 14 gloves and seven sticks had to be picked up after a brawl between these rivals that night.

title: Turkey Halts Campaign in Germany to Court Voters
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys governing party said on Tuesday that it would no longer send representatives to Germany to campaign for a constitutional amendment to drastically strengthen the Turkish presidents powers, raising the possibility of a de-escalation of a dispute between the two countries.

title: The Americans Season 5, Episode 3 Recap: More Than This
description: And on the third week The Americans said, let there be Martha. And there was.

title: Ill Criticize Judges, Trump Says, Hours After a Scolding for Doing Just That
description: WASHINGTON  Not even a public scolding from Judge Neil M. Gorsuch could get President Trump to stop bashing federal judges.

title: At Chatsworth House, a Tale of Five Centuries
description: LONDON  If walls could talk, Chatsworth House, with its sublime Painted Hall, Sculpture Gallery and endless parade of gilded staterooms, would have some tales to tell.

title: North Korea Launches Missile, but Test Appears to Fail
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea fired a missile off its east coast on Wednesday, but the test apparently failed, South Korean and American military officials said.

title: Rome Defies New Anti-Establishment Mayor With the Same Old Problems
description: ROME  It has not been an easy nine months for Virginia Raggi since she was elected Romes first female mayor on the promise of cleaning up city hall and ushering in transparent governance.

title: Tips From an Ambassador for Israeli Cuisine
description: Michael Solomonov has become an ambassador of sorts for Israeli cuisine. The chef is an owner of five restaurants in Philadelphia, including Zahav, his award-winning flagship, and is the co-author of Zahav: A World of Israeli Cooking. He is also the host of the documentary In Search of Israeli Cuisine, directed by Roger Sherman, which just opened in New York and will be shown in many cities in the next few months. Shot in restaurants, home kitchens, farms and markets across the country, the film shows the radical shift in modern Israeli cuisine, as cooks embrace local ingredients and the countrys myriad cultures.

title: Corrections: March 22, 2017
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Wednesday: Shots Fired and Julieta
description: Shots Fired, a new series, complicates the debate over police violence. Pedro Almodvar presents another woman on the verge.

title: Syria, France, Donald Trump: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: U.S., Exploiting Japans Miscues, Reaches First W.B.C. Final
description: LOS ANGELES  If not quite an embarrassment, it had been something of an indignity to the United States team that Japan, South Korea, Cuba, the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico had all reached the title game of the World Baseball Classic.

title: Word + Quiz: grouse
Should Extinct Animals Be Resurrected? If So, Which Ones?
description: Watch the short video below about Martha, the last Passenger Pigeon, who died in 1914.

title: Robots Have Existential Crises, Too
description: Max Aguilera-Hellwegs new book, Humanoid, is a deep dive into the world of robots and artificial intelligence, and an extension of his own inquiry into the nature of life and consciousness.

title: Chuck Barris, Producer and Personality of Gong Show Fame, Dies at 87
description: Chuck Barris, the Gong Show creator, songwriter and novelist who sought to add to his already eclectic rsum with a made-up  or was it?  story about being an assassin for the C.I.A., died on Tuesday at his home in Palisades, N.Y. He was 87.

title: Cure Me? No, Thanks
description: Near the end of last year, the Food and Drug Administration approved the first drug for the treatment of spinal muscular atrophy.  A number of my Facebook friends rejoiced. A Christmas miracle! one of them declared. But I am not so sure.

title: Mr. Trump Goes After Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
description: Shortly after Inauguration Day, the Trump camp indicated it had no immediate plan to fire Richard Cordray, the Obama-appointed director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, whose term runs until July 2018. The administrations restraint was a welcome contrast to congressional Republicans  unrelenting efforts to weaken the bureau, including calls to get rid of Mr. Cordray, an effective leader, on the ground that he had become a dictator.

title: How a Trump Turnabout on Gay Rights Hurts Republicans
description: CODY, Wyo.  During Donald Trumps campaign, he repeatedly cast himself as a supporter of L.G.B.T. rights. As president, however, he is being urged by fringe-right groups and raging extremists to sign a religious liberty executive order that would allow discrimination against gays, women and religious minorities.

title: Rex Tillerson Has Shown No Illusions About North Korea
description: One thing that came through loud and clear in Secretary of State Rex Tillersons recent trip to Asia is that he is under no illusions about the urgency of the North Korean nuclear and missile threat.

title: White Pride and Prejudice
description: My dear Mr. Douthat, said the internet one day. Have you heard that the alt-right has laid claim to Jane Austen?

title: Tweeting Toward Oblivion
description: Donald Trump faces a stark choice. He can tweet, or he can govern.

title: Calling On a Few Good Men
description: Memo To: Secretary of Defense James Mattis, National Security Adviser H. R. McMaster, Secretary of Homeland Security John Kelly, C.I.A. Director Mike Pompeo and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson

title: Why Trumps N.I.H. Cuts Should Worry Us
description: Last week I was in London to participate in a scientific symposium. During coffee breaks, many British colleagues asked me and other American visitors to explain the bewildering news that President Trump had announced his intention to cut the budget for the National Institutes of Health by 18.3 percent, about $5.8 billion.

title: Why People Continue to Believe Objectively False Things
description: Everyone is entitled to his own opinion, but not his own facts, goes the saying  one that now seems like a relic of simpler times.

title: Escape
description: What do you do, and where do you go, when you need to escape your problems? How do you find escape in your ordinary life?

title: Survival of Sears and Kmart Is in Doubt, Owner Warns
description: The corporate owner of Sears and Kmart said on Tuesday that there was substantial doubt that it could continue operating, as brick-and-mortar stores continue to face challenges in an e-commerce world.

title: Questions for: New Crop of Young Adult Novels Explores Race and Police Brutality
description: Article: New Crop of Young Adult Novels Explores Race and Police Brutality

title: A.I. Expert at Baidu, Andrew Ng, Resigns From Chinese Search Giant
description: HONG KONG  In 2014, Baidu announced a hiring coup in the world of artificial intelligence: It had brought in the Stanford and Google alumnus Andrew Ng to lead a new research lab in Silicon Valley.

title: What Should You Do With Your Fathers Nazi Keepsake?
description: A few years ago, before my father died, my two brothers and I were going through his things with him. He wanted to have some say in where his belongings went. We agreeably found a home for most of the things: Brother No. 2 has children; Brother No. 3 and I have no children. When it came to my fathers World War II box, which had not been opened for years, we thought it best to give his Bronze Star, Purple Heart and other military decorations to Brother No. 2, so they could be passed down.

title: Reza Aslan Thinks TV Can End Bigotry
description: On your new show, Believer, you examine niche, sometimes extreme, global religious traditions. Do you think this is the best time for a show like this? It is the most perfect time possible. There is no medium on this earth that has more power to transform the way that people think about others than television.

title: Security Lines and Flight Delays? This Kids in Paradise
description: I used to think there were two types of people in this world: those who are so nervous about making their flight that they are only truly happy if they get to the airport four hours early, and those who are so blas about making their flight that they are only truly happy if they get to the airport just minutes before takeoff.

title: Why Does Mount Rushmore Exist?
description: Nothing about our trip to Mount Rushmore went according to plan. Our flight was delayed. We found ourselves stranded in the Minneapolis airport for four hours. Minneapolis airport four hours, we typed into Google, and the internet responded by persuading us to take a train to the Mall of America. The entrance was shabby; the elevators were slow and small and confusing; locals walked around in the freezing weather wearing short sleeves. It was not just a mall but an elaborate fun house of malls  malls within malls within malls within malls  at the center of which was, somehow, a gigantic amusement park. My children watched in jealous awe as another family floated by on a log ride. I could see their child-minds recalibrating the relative scales and possibilities of American experience. How big could one thing be while still fitting inside another?

title: An Improbable 6,000-Mile Boat Trip Around the East Coast
description: Before I set sail with Tim and Karen Bartel on their 52-foot Bluewater yacht, Let It Ride, I didnt tend to think of water as a place. I learned my geography by that wooden map of the United States  the jigsaw puzzle of the lower 48 with the inset Hawaii and Alaska to the side. The puzzle-piece states were the places to go, and everything else was just negative space. You could not visit the compass rose in the corner, nor the unvarnished pine off the coast of Oahu. The winding Mississippi and proboscoid Great Lakes gave shape to the puzzle but didnt qualify as destinations themselves. In a nation transfixed by the dream of the road trip, a river is just a reason for a tunnel or a bridge.

title: U.S. General Urges Nuclear Upgrade as Russia Grows More Aggressive
description: The general who oversees the United States atomic weapons arsenal has expressed concern over what he described as much more aggressive behavior by Russia in recent years, saying it justifies the need for a strengthened and modernized nuclear deterrent force in this country.

title: Highlights From Judge Gorsuchs Confirmation Hearing
description: Here are highlights from Judge Neil M. Gorsuchs third day at his Senate confirmation hearings:

title: Indias Phone Romeos Look for Ms. Right via Wrong Numbers
description: LUCKNOW, India  In a glass-sided call center, police constables clicketyclack on computer keyboards, on the trail of a particularly Indian sort of criminal.

title: Trump Says Regulations Impede. Perhaps Not in the Electric Car Business.
description: President Trump is not fond of regulations. Within weeks of taking office, he and his appointees began to roll back rules that govern the financial industry, guns, the energy business and broadband internet providers.

title: Where Halls of Ivy Meet Silicon Dreams, a New City Rises
description: To see higher education in New York City being transformed, you have only to pick your vantage point.

title: Turkish Trump, a Hotel Plan and a Tangle of Foreign Ties

description: Gov. Matt Bevin of Kentucky was unrestrained in his praise for President Trump: Opening for him at a rally on Monday, Mr. Bevin, a conservative Republican, echoed Mr. Trumps America First slogan and only gently noted the nagging divisions in their party.

title: Two Female Playwrights Arrive on Broadway. What Took So Long?
description: They are two of the nations pre-eminent playwrights. Each has won nearly every award their field has to offer, including the Pulitzer Prize. Each has written works that are staged around the world and have become required reading in college classes. And each has earned an admired position in the academy, teaching aspiring dramatists at Ivy League institutions.

description: Paul Higgins and his wife, Michelle, moved into a one-bedroom third-floor walk-up on Third Avenue in the Lenox Hill neighborhood two years ago, attracted by the abundant public transportation as well as the rent, a little over $2,000 a month.

title: Coming Out in Droves for Free Health Care
description: A nonprofit sets up temporary clinics that provide free medical services to people in rural areas of the United States. For the hundreds that showed up in Cookeville, Tenn., this was a chance to get a checkup, dental treatment or eye care.

title: Should 15,000 Steps a Day Be Our New Exercise Target?
description: Taking 10,000 steps per day is often suggested as a desirable exercise goal for people who wish to improve their health. But a new study of postal workers in Scotland suggests that that number could be too conservative and that, to best protect our hearts, many of us might want to start moving quite a bit more.

title: How to Be Mindful at the Gym
description: Whether you are a regular at the gym or only go occasionally, mindfulness can improve your workout. Its easy to focus on how far we are from our perfect weight or shape. Instead, use your workout to cultivate physical strength, awareness and acceptance.  MaryGrace Naughton, yoga and meditation supervisor at Miraval Resort & Spa in Tucson, Ariz.

But do they know that scientific data shows that the Earths climate is already changing? And do they know that people and communities are already being affected by these changes?

description: The home has three bedrooms and two bathrooms, is in the Alter Hof, or the Old Court, which served as the first fixed imperial seat of government in Germany.

description: A LOFT PENTHOUSE IN THE HEART OF MUNICH

title: They Smashed Banks for Pol Pot. Now Theyre Founding Them.
description: MALAI, Cambodia  For years, Tep Khunnal was the devoted personal secretary of Pol Pot, staying loyal to the charismatic ultracommunist leader even as the Khmer Rouge movement collapsed around them in the late 1990s.

title: Selena Gomez (and Others) on Adapting Thirteen Reasons Why for Netflix
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  In 2008, Mandy Teefey, the mother of the pop star and actress Selena Gomez, was browsing at a Barnes & Noble when she spotted Thirteen Reasons Why by Jay Asher. The best-selling young adult novel tells the story of Hannah Baker, a high school girl who kills herself, leaving behind cassette tapes detailing the 13 people she blames for driving her to suicide. Its no surprise that, standing in the bookstore, Ms. Teefey was compelled to read it: Woven into Hannahs dark account of isolation, adolescent betrayal and sexual stigmatizing are messages of acceptance and compassion, yet it unfolds like an emotional thriller. Not much later, Ms. Teefey and Ms. Gomez were eating sushi with Mr. Asher, negotiating for the rights.

title: The Problems With Originalism
description: At Judge Neil M. Gorsuchs confirmation hearing on Monday, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, started the ball rolling by remarking that she found his originalist judicial philosophy to be really troubling. Troubling it is.

title: The Truth About New York Citys Elite High Schools
description: This month, a select group of eighth graders in New York City found out that they were being offered a spot at some of the nations best high schools, the eight specialized city public high schools that include Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn Tech and Bronx Science. About 28,000 students took the multiple-choice test required for admission, and 5,078 did well enough to secure a place.

title: Deadly Attack Near U.K. Parliament; Car Plows Victims on Westminster Bridge
description: LONDON  A knife-wielding assailant driving a sport utility vehicle mowed down panicked pedestrians and stabbed a police officer outside Parliament on Wednesday in a deadly assault, prompting the hasty evacuation of the prime minister and punctuating the threat of terrorism in Europe.

title: You Cannot Have Peace if You Dont Listen to Women
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  Marie shuffled seven chairs to fit around the table in her courtyard, placed down a tray of tea, and poured water into glasses. When her friends arrived, she hugged each of them.

title: China Bets on Sensitive U.S. Start-Ups, Worrying the Pentagon
description: HONG KONG  When the United States Air Force wanted help making military robots more perceptive, it turned to a Boston-based artificial intelligence start-up called Neurala. But when Neurala needed money, it got little response from the American military.

title: Harlots, on Hulu, Has Sex. But Settle Down, Guys.
description: Let the bodices rip, Downton Abbey zealots: Lady Sybil is now a whore. Or rather, the actress Jessica Brown Findlay is portraying one in Harlots, debuting Wednesday, March 29, on Hulu. Set in Georgian England  when, historians estimate, as many as one in five women worked in the sex trade  the series stars Samantha Morton as Margaret Wells, a London brothel owner; Ms. Brown Findlay as Charlotte, her older daughter and the citys courtesan nonpareil; Eloise Smyth as Lucy, her younger, whose virginity she intends to auction off to the highest bidder; and Lesley Manville as Lydia Quigley, her rival madam.

title: Sparkly Eye Shadow? These (Male) Beauty Bloggers Are Experts
description: These beauty bloggers have nailed the perfect cat eye and the art of contouring. They help millions of followers navigate the rocky shoals of choosing the best mascara and the longest-lasting foundation. Some now earn six-figure incomes from their adoring audiences, thanks to partnerships with major brands eager to profit from their street cred.

title: When a Basic Laptop Will Do: Our Top Budget Picks
description: Ever since the advent of the iPhone and iPad, some people have been using their laptops a lot less. It made me wonder if I need one at all. So I asked Kimber Streams, who tests laptops at The Wirecutter, a product reviews website owned by The New York Times, for some advice.

title: Paula Wolferts World
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Erwin Wurm Brings One Minute Sculptures to Lehmann Maupin
description: Why is that man wearing a wooden bench? Why does that woman have her head in a lounge chair? These are among the questions raised by the Austrian artist Erwin Wurms Ethics demonstrated in geometrical order, a new series of his One Minute Sculptures that goes on view Thursday, March 30, at the Lehmann Maupin gallery.

title: Mitsuko Uchida at Carnegie Hall Is a Start to a Big Week
description: Five concerts in two days, and in a perfect world youd be able to hear them all: The coming week brings a reminder of why Carnegie Hall, with its three stages, is essential. On Thursday, March 30: the great pianist Mitsuko Uchida, in Mozart, Schumann and a new work by Jrg Widmann; Ensemble Signal playing John Adams (Shaker Loops) and Terry Riley (In C) to open Steve Reichs Three Generations series, exploring Minimalisms lineage; and Simone Lamsma, with the premiere of a violin sonata by James MacMillan.

title: Jay Som Brings Her D.I.Y. Bedroom Pop to Brooklyn
description: The Oakland, Calif., singer and songwriter Melina Duterte, who calls her D.I.Y. bedroom pop project Jay Som, does it all. After gaining notice for sketching fuzzy drafts on her Bandcamp page  composing, arranging, playing and producing every part  Ms. Duterte, 22, leveled up on Everybody Works (Polyvinyl), her proper debut album released this month.

title: Doug Varone and Dancers Swirl Into the Brooklyn Academy of Music
description: Doug Varones dances swirl with steps, and those propulsive steps swirl with ideas and emotions. Just consider the ever-shifting kinetic imagery in the three works being presented by Doug Varone and Dancers in performances at Brooklyn Academy of Music beginning Wednesday, March 29, as part of the companys 30th anniversary season. The movements in Folded, an intimate duet, unfold with questions about  and contradictions in  personal beliefs and behavior. The restlessness of ReComposed pays tribute to the vivid hues and bold brush strokes of Joan Mitchell, an American abstract expressionist artist whose paintings can seem like whirlwinds of color. And Possession is inspired by the changing relationships in A. S. Byatts novel of the same name, in which two contemporary literary scholars find themselves increasingly caught up in the emotional predicaments of the two Victorian poets whose personal lives they are researching. (Through April 1, Harvey Theater, Fort Greene; bam.org.)

title: The Little Foxes: A Reconsideration
description: Does Lillian Hellman belong in the same elite club of 20th-century masters as Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller? The Washington Posts chief theater critic, Peter Marks, suggested as much in a review last year of Arena Stages revival of The Little Foxes, a Hellman play receiving a starry new production on Broadway.

title: Buuel in France at the Metrograph
description: Despite his early Surrealist triumphs and outrageous images  Un Chien Andalou and its razor-sliced eyeball, LAge dOr and its lovers writhing in the mud  it wasnt until the eternally avant-garde Luis Buuel was in his 60s that he made many of his best films. The Metrograph series, Buuel in France, starting Friday, March 31, and running through April 3, features a handful of them.

title: How Neil Gorsuch Interprets the Constitution
description: Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trumps choice for Supreme Court justice, adheres to originalism, a judicial approach that would deeply affect how he would make decisions from the bench.

title: Social Circuit Crisis: With the Waldorf Closed, Where to Hold That Gala?
description: When the Waldorf Astoria shut its doors on March 1 for two to three years, hotel guests and visiting heads of state werent the only ones trying to find alternative accommodations.

title: Compounding Pharmacy Owner Not Guilty of Murder After 60 Meningitis Deaths
description: BOSTON  The frightening pattern of sick patients emerged in 2012. First, two people died. Then it was eight. Then more. It was an outbreak of fungal meningitis, a rare disease that investigators linked to injections from a compounding pharmacy outside Boston.

title: What to Do With a Full Phone
description: Q. My phone has run out of space and I cannot download new apps. For a new phone, what should I look for when asking about storage space? I already store all my photos in the cloud, but I still have no room left.

title: Travel Ban Threatens a Lincoln Center Festival Play
description: This summers Lincoln Center Festival is about crossing borders. But its plan to present the North American premiere of a work by the Syrian playwright Mohammad al-Attar risks being stopped at the United States border if President Trumps travel ban is upheld.

title: Oversize Pearls  in Unusual Shapes and Sizes
description: On rings, bracelets and necklaces, organic pearls make a boldly idiosyncratic statement.

title: A Sight to See: Jodhpurs Newly Restored Stepwell
description: The revival of Jodhpur, also known as the Blue City for its cerulean-painted houses, began seven years ago with the opening of the Raas hotel, which was conceived by Dhananajaya and Nikhilendra Singh. Now, the brothers are turning their attention to the nearby Toor ji ka Jhalra stepwell  an ancient type of well that often takes the shape of an inverted pyramid  whose two-year restoration may prove to be the citys tipping point. For decades, the well sat filled with stagnant water, until the Singhs, with help from Jodhpurs maharajah, purified the pool and sandblasted the steps. The days light hits them in a way that makes the place an architectural destination in its own right, but, as of this winter, there are also a dozen or so worthy shops and cafes around the wells perimeter, from the sustainable design emporium Good Earth to an outpost of the Jaipur-based Gem Palace.

title: What 8 New Yorkers Wore to First Saturday at the Brooklyn Museum
description: First Saturdays at the Brooklyn Museum are festive affairs. Despite the frigid temperature outside, the tone inside was no different for the first Saturday this month, when attendees flocked to the new Georgia OKeeffe exhibition, which features the artists wardrobe along with key paintings and photographs. Families and museum supporters took advantage of the free admission to bask in the warmth of their winter coats and community spirit.

title: Brussels Commemorates Attack Anniversary With Both Silence and Noise
description: Belgians of all political stripes and backgrounds united in their small, divided country on Wednesday to commiserate and remember the coordinated suicide bombings that struck Brussels one year ago, killing 32 people and injuring more than 320. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks.

title: Bring Out the Barf Bags and Other Promotional Stunts
description: Theres no publicity like barf bag publicity.

title: Search for Secret Service Leader Intensifies as White House Security Is Tested
description: WASHINGTON  In the century or so since Congress first assigned the Secret Service the task of protecting the president of the United States, its top job has always gone to an agency veteran.

title: Attack Makes London Europes Latest Target
description: Shots were heard near Britains Parliament on Wednesday, and an officer was stabbed. Pedestrians were also hit by a vehicle on the nearby Westminster Bridge.

title: At Home With Oliver Gustav
description: The 18th-century architecture of remains remarkably unchanged, providing a pleasing backdrop for the designers spare decor.

title: An All-Gray Apartment Thats Not Blah  But Not Hygge Either
description: In the paintings of the 19th-century Danish artist Vilhelm Hammershoi, the color gray achieves a beguiling incandescence. His introspective interiors, which feature the simple, classical architecture of 18th-century Copenhagen apartments bathed in Scandinavias soft northern light, present havens of timeless tranquillity. Entering Oliver Gustavs home is not unlike stepping into one of Hammershois paintings. For one thing, it is in a building quite similar to Strandgade 30, where the painter and his wife lived for 10 years, and which served as a setting for his most important works. But its also the stillness and the way the light softens the sharp angles of each room.

title: London Terrorist Attack: What We Know and Dont Know
description: This article was last updated at 1:30 p.m., Thursday. Visit this page for full coverage of the attack.

title: His Idea for Fighting Terrorism? Funny Plays
description: BRUSSELS  As the lights go dark in a theater here, gunfire and explosions are heard. Some in the audience gasp, including several women wearing head scarves. Onstage, a Muslim terrorist in an orange prison jumpsuit appears. During the play, we learn that he has killed people at a Jewish school whom, in other circumstances, he might have befriended, we come to understand.

title: Trumps ISIS Plan, as Described by Tillerson, Sounds Like Obamas
description: WASHINGTON  On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump falsely accused President Barack Obama of founding the Islamic State. He said Mr. Obama did not get it, in terms of fighting the extremist group that is based in Iraq and Syria, and vowed to obliterate them on the battlefield.

title: House Republicans, Deeply Divided, Face Painful Choice on Health Vote
description: WASHINGTON  For the House Republicans who have never served under a Republican president  roughly two-thirds of them  the vote scheduled for Thursday on a measure to replace President Barack Obamas health care law is a legislative fantasia, the culmination of seven years of campaign promises impeded by Mr. Obamas veto pen.

title: If Health Bill Is Killed in the House, Ideology Will Be the Main Reason

description: Its official. Ubers senior management team is not entirely men.

title: A Scholarly Sting Operation Shines a Light on Predatory Journals
description: The applicants nom de plume was not exactly subtle, if you know Polish. The middle initial and surname of the author, Anna O. Szust, mean fraudster. Her publications were fake and her degrees were fake. The book chapters she listed among her publications could not be found, but perhaps that should not have been a surprise because the book publishers were fake, too.

But on Wednesday, Mr. Trump got an assist from a powerful House Republican who said the president or his closest associates may have been incidentally swept up in foreign surveillance by American spy agencies.

title: Jury Awards Millions in Case of Man Left to Die of Broken Neck in Oklahoma Jail
description: A federal jury awarded $10.25 million this week to the family of an Army veteran who spent his final days immobilized in an Oklahoma jail as guards and medical providers doubted his claims that his neck was broken.

description: After a season that saw temperatures soar at the North Pole, the Arctic has less sea ice at winters end than ever before in nearly four decades of satellite measurements.

title: Manhattan Theater Club Announces Two New Plays by Women
description: Lucy Kirkwoods drama The Children, which earned critical acclaim in London last year, will open on Broadway during the 2017-18 season, Manhattan Theater Club announced on Wednesday.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Education Minimum Applied by Gorsuch
description: WASHINGTON  Schools may not settle for minimal educational progress by disabled students, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday, rejecting a standard that some lower courts have applied, and that the nominee to join the high court, Neil M. Gorsuch, has been criticized for using.

title: Review: Mahan Esfahani, a Harpsichordist With a Chip on His Keyboard
description: Attitude may not be the trait you most expect to find in a harpsichordist. Yet the Iranian-born Mahan Esfahani, 32, often seems to be spoiling for a fight.

description: Thousands of Christian pilgrims and members of the clergy gathered at a modest shrine in Jerusalems Old City on Wednesday to celebrate the completion of a monthslong effort, hundreds of years in the making: the restoration and repair of Jesus tomb.

description: Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, who has not played since March 7 because of a hip muscle strain, said he would return during the teams coming California trip.
