title: Following the Russian Money
description: Counterintelligence is long, hard work. Investigators need time to string along suspects  seeking the who, what, when, where and why of the case. The Federal Bureau of Investigation tries to build 3-D chronologies of who did what to whom. Agents usually follow the money, the best evidence. Thats how the feds got Al Capone: for tax evasion.

Please order him to cease his crusade against this harmless expression.

title: March
description: The key to this poem is its title, which makes each element of the poem part of a faintly ominous definition of that month between winter and spring, when things are not quite right. The poem summons up the contradictoriness of March and overturns the familiar, clichd representations of spring as a season of renewal. Here, spring is as much a time for private regrets and a lurking obsession with the past. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

title: How to Lower Your Heart Rate
description: Find out why your resting heart rate is so high in the first place, says Dr. John Elefteriades, who directs the Aortic Institute at Yale University. Someone struggling with heart or lung problems, for example, will have an elevated pulse that needs to be corrected immediately with medicine. But even with no serious health problems, lowering the number of times your heart beats in a minute can decrease its burden. Once you determine your resting heart rate by making several measurements  count the beats for 30 seconds, then double that number  start exercising regularly for a long period of time. If youre a couch potato, your pulse rate might go up just by doing normal activities, Elefteriades says.

title: Reese Witherspoon and Laura Dern, Wildly Close
description: A mutual friend introduced Reese Witherspoon and Laura Dern in front of a restaurant in the Brentwood Country Mart complex in Santa Monica, Calif. They were already aware of each other; it was 2011, and both were movie stars of many years. They had also each played antiheroines in back-to-back late-1990s Alexander Payne films to unforgettable effect: Ms. Dern as Ruth Stoops in Citizen Ruth and Ms. Witherspoon as Tracy Flick in Election. But it was merely a quick hello.

They arrived at the courthouse well dressed. The husband was large and stocky, and the wife was in slacks and a blouse, thin and fair-skinned, with curly hair and a delicate face. title: How to Entertain Children on the Road
description: Vacationing with your children, whether theyre toddlers or teenagers, is a chance to create cherished family memories. But the journey to and from your destination, be it in a car or on a plane, may be a memory you will want to forget. Children can get impatient and cranky when theyre traveling, which makes parents cranky and that trip unpleasant, said Eileen Ogintz, who writes a syndicated weekly column on family travel called Taking the Kids and has an online magazine with the same name.

title: Tony Conrad Was Such a Good Minimalist, He Was Almost Forgotten
description: In February 1963, a 22-year-old experimental violinist named Tony Conrad stood outside Philharmonic (now David Geffen) Hall in New York wearing a signboard that read Demolish Lincoln Center! With the composer Henry Flynt and the filmmaker Jack Smith, Mr. Conrad formed a three-man picket line that spent a day marching at the center, the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They were protesting, Mr. Conrad later recalled, the imperialist influences of European high culture and gesturing toward the dismantling and dispersion of any and all organized cultural forms.

title: Bao Bao, an American-Born Panda, Steps Out in China
description: CHENGDU, China  Strange food. Unintelligible natives. These are just some of the things that Bao Bao, the 3-year-old panda from the National Zoo in Washington, has grappled with since moving to China last month. But the culture shock is fading, her handlers say, as she settles into the land of her ancestors.

title: California Today: Henry Rollins Strikes Chord as a Columnist
description: Good morning.

title: A Health Care Victory. For Now.
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: How Mick Rock, Music Photographer, Spends His Sundays
description: There is no slowing down for the British photographer Mick Rock, who has spent some 50 years capturing images of pop and rock stars like David Bowie, Ellie Goulding, Janelle Mone and Lou Reed. Between shoots, Mr. Rock, 68, edits his photography books and travels all over the world to attend his exhibition openings. A documentary about his life, SHOT! The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock, will be released on April 7 by Magnolia Pictures. Mr. Rock lives in Livingston, Staten Island, with his wife, Pati, who works in real estate, and their two Maine coon cats, Bellini and Razor.

title: Dan Chaons Latest Takes on Satanism, Suspicious Deaths and a Faltering Family
description: ILL WILLBy Dan Chaon461 pp. Ballantine Books. $28.

title: Home Inspectors on Their Weirdest Discoveries
description: Of all the paper ghosts that Patrick Burns, a Corcoran agent, found in a Brooklyn townhouse last May, the one hanging in the basement rattled him the most.

title: Pete Holmes Opens Old Wounds in HBOs Crashing
description: This is an interview with a comedian who made a self-referential comedy loosely based on his life. Whats the show? Some hints: Its not Seinfeld or Louie. Not Maron either, but good guess. Its not Mulaney. This one is on HBO. Nope, its not Curb Your Enthusiasm.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Niki Caro
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Niki Caro, director of The Zookeepers Wife starring Jessica Chastain, which opens in theaters this month.

title: Profile in Style: Manolo Blahnik
description: The legendary shoe designer shares images of his influences and inspirations.

title: Manolo Blahniks Life in Shoes
description: Roger Vivier may have invented the stiletto in 1954, but Manolo Blahnik gave it legs. His handiwork is easy to spot: the spindly heel that flares subtly at the base, resembling the stem of a champagne flute where it widens to kiss the cup; the elongated pointy toe, with its ever-so-slightly rounded tip, like the smooth beak of a swan.

title: North Carolina School System Pulls Book About a Boy in a Dress
description: The Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools system in North Carolina was going to use a book about a boy who likes to wear dresses as part of a first-grade lesson on what to do when someone is bullied.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Postal Workers, Grandparents and Bedtime Snacks
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: In Major Defeat for Trump, Push to Repeal Health Law Fails
description: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders, facing a revolt among conservatives and moderates in their ranks, pulled legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act from consideration on the House floor Friday in a major defeat for President Trump on the first legislative showdown of his presidency.

title: Headed North, Sandhill Cranes Squeeze In Where They Can
description: Youll hear it before you see it.

title: The Democrats Next Move on Health Care
description: The American Health Care Act, Paul Ryans Obamacare repeal bill, seems to be on thin ice after Mr. Ryan pulled it from a House floor vote on Friday for lack of votes. But the priorities and passions that gave it shape are still very much alive and at work within Republican ranks.

title: A Movie Date With My Younger Self
description: As a longtime film writer, I have considered it a failing that I couldnt answer the simple question Whats your favorite movie? My responses felt like punts, whether I was touting the buoyant energy of A Hard Days Night or the spell that 2001: A Space Odyssey has cast on me since I was young or how movies from Blue Velvet to the Three Colors trilogy to Babe hit me just right upon their releases.

title: For Some, a Win-Win Election in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kongs new leader will be selected on Sunday. Since Britain handed the territory back to China in 1997, the election of the chief executive  which is performed by a special 1,200-member committee stacked in Beijings favor  has generally been a foregone conclusion. But this year Chinas leaders may not be able to dictate the outcome. A faction of powerful local business interests sidelined during the last election, in 2012, will come out on top no matter the result of the vote itself.

title: The G.O.P.s Existential Crisis
description: Give Donald Trump this: His travel ban enraged only half the country. The House Republicans attempt to replace the Affordable Care Act, meanwhile, has alienated everyone, including members of the Republican Party itself.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Clip: The Death of Louis XIV
description: Jean-Pierre Laud, now 72, stars in "Albert Serras The Death of Louis XIV, which opens Friday, March 31.

title: Accountability for Duterte
description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines relishes his image as a defiant crusader, willing to encourage the slaughter of thousands in the name of saving his nation from the scourge of drugs. More than 7,000 suspected drug users and dealers, witnesses and bystanders  including children  have been killed by the police or vigilantes in the Philippines since last July.

title: Smartphones That Get Too Darn Hot
description: Q. I have seen an increasing number of people using their smartphones while in the sauna at my gym. I am concerned that the 125 degree-plus temperature in a room smaller than my walk-in closet will cause the battery in someones smartphone to explode. Could this happen?

title: From Teenage Rebel to Dying King, Jean-Pierre Laud and a Life Lived on Film
description: Something more than an actor or even a movie star, Jean-Pierre Laud is a man who has lived his life on film.

title: Hamdi Ulukaya's Sense of Tribe
description: Chobani Founder and C.E.O. Hamdi Ulukaya talked at The New York Timess New Work Summit about the bond that exists among his companys employees.

title: Ask Well: Red Cabbage vs. Blueberries?
description: Q. How does red cabbage compare to blueberries, nutritionally speaking? It seems to have the same dark blue and purple pigments that signal the presence of valuable micronutrients but is less expensive and available year round.

title: A Wheelchair on Broadway Isnt Exploitation. Its Progress.
description: Theres a wheelchair onstage at the Belasco Theater, and its drawing an abundance of attention. Theres also a wheelchair onstage at a small theater not far away, and its drawing practically no attention at all. The gulf between the two says quite a lot.

title: Tech Roundup: A Senate Vote Is Not the Final Word on Internet Privacy
description: Those rules meant to protect the privacy of your internet activity that you may have heard about? Never mind.

title: Enraged by Donald Trump Jr.s Tweet
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping for Daybeds
description: The mere sight of a daybed  part sofa, part mattress  is enough to evoke images of lazy weekend lounging. A perfect perch for reading, its also comfortable enough for an impromptu nap.

title: What Is Sleep? Asks Reporter on the Border Beat
description: A lot has changed on the homeland security beat since Ron Nixon began covering it in 2015. Indeed, a lot has changed in the last two months.

title: Attack on Police Checkpoint in Bangladesh Kills Only Bomber
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A man detonated explosives at a police checkpoint near the international airport here in Bangladeshs capital on Friday evening, killing only himself, the police said.

title: Cornell Law to Start Program on Roosevelt Island
description: Cornell Law School, one of the top-ranked law schools in the nation, plans to offer a new juris doctorate program at the soon-to-be opened Cornell Tech campus on Roosevelt Island in New York City.

title: This Week in Hate: A Sikh Womans Subway Ride
description: Rajpreet Heir was on the L train, on her way to a friends birthday party in Manhattan, when a man started harassing her. As part of The Times series This Week in Hate, she recounts her story at the site of the incident in this 360 video.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: U.N. Rights Council to Investigate Reports of Atrocities in Myanmar
description: GENEVA  The United Nations top human rights body decided on Friday to send an international fact-finding mission to Myanmar to investigate atrocities that the countrys army is said to have committed against Rohingya Muslims, ratcheting up pressure on the countrys leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to curb the conduct of the powerful military.

title: Paul Farmer: Humans Arent Winning the War on TB
description: For decades there were few developments in the fight against tuberculosis  at least by humans. The bacteria that causes this airborne disease, in contrast, regularly boasts a number of deadly new upgrades, including mutations conferring resistance to almost all antibiotics developed to cure it. It has also made common cause with new allies (AIDS, weak health systems and budget cuts further sapping them) while maintaining its longstanding alliances with war, hunger, overcrowded and poorly ventilated housing, prisons, and workplaces.

title: Semilla, Praised for Its Tasting Menu, Is Closing
description: Semilla, a chefs counter opened by Jos Ramrez-Ruiz and Pamela Yung in 2014 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will serve its final dinners on Saturday. Cooks at the small restaurant, acclaimed for its tasting menu of mainly vegetable and grain dishes, will bake whole roasted sunchokes into sourdough bread, and serve Carolina Gold rice with parsnips and black truffles.

title: The State of Your Block, 2017
description: New York is made up of 66,000 blocks, each a little world unto itself. To know them all is to know the city in its infinite variety.

title: Trump Expected to Pick John Sullivan as No. 2 at State Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  John J. Sullivan, a prominent Republican lawyer who served in the administration of President George W. Bush, is expected to be nominated to serve as the State Departments No. 2 officer, according to a senior White House official who spoke on condition of anonymity in advance of an official announcement.

title: Jon Batiste and Wynton Marsalis Prize John Lewis, and Each Other
description: By the time Jon Batiste arrived at Spotifys studios near Union Square on a recent evening, the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis had commandeered his seat at the piano.

title: When Your Commute Includes Hearing You Dont Belong in This Country
description: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

title: Washington Pizzeria Gunman Pleads Guilty to Weapons Charges
description: WASHINGTON  A 28-year-old North Carolina man pleaded guilty Friday in federal court to firing a military-style assault rifle inside a Washington pizza restaurant as he investigated spurious claims in online articles that the pizzeria was at the center of a child sex-slave ring.

title: Citing Confidentiality, British Court Blocks Reuters Article on Hedge Fund
description: LONDON  A High Court judge has blocked Reuters from publishing an article about the hedge fund manager Brevan Howard Asset Management, citing the confidential nature of information at issue in the story.

title: Which Amenities Raise Rents Most?
description: The number of bedrooms and bathrooms are the biggest factors in an apartments rent, but certain amenities also affect it. A study by RentHop, an apartment search website, found that the features that have the greatest impact on price in the 10 most populated metropolitan areas of the United States are: an elevator, a doorman, a washer and dryer, and a dedicated parking space.

title: In Washingtons Daily Trump Wars, Devin Nunes Becomes a Human Shield
description: WASHINGTON  Even on Fox News, Representative Devin Nunes, the beleaguered Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, could not escape the venom from his left.

title: Jay Z and Weinstein Company to Produce Trayvon Martin Projects
description: The rap star Jay Z and the Weinstein Company will team up to produce a series of television and film projects about the life of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed black teenager who was shot dead in 2012 near his home by a neighborhood watch volunteer, George Zimmerman.

title: For Those Who Have It All, Charitable Wedding Registries
description: Christopher and Deirdre Culver met four years ago in Newport, R.I., aboard his yacht, through mutual friends. Their courtship was rooted in their love of the sea and of sailing. One sign that they made a good couple was the experience they had sailing together on his yacht in a race.

title: On the Attack in London
description: Five people, including the assailant, died in a terrorist attack in central London on Wednesday.

title: 5 Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
description: When visiting Philly, the waterfront working-class neighborhood of Fishtown may not be at the top of your list. Not just because you likely havent heard of it, but because there isnt anywhere to stay. But it now comes highly recommended by locals for its growing food scene and small-town vibes despite steady gentrification. Its home to more than a few hipster and creative types, and on one quiet corner sits a charming restaurant to rival any Brooklyn eatery: Wm. Mulherins Sons, which gets its name from the 19th-century whisky bottling and blending company that once occupied the space. Nearly every ingredient on its menu is made in-house, right down to the flour blends for the homemade pizza crusts. (Bon Apptit named it one of the 50 best restaurants to open in 2016.) And now, you can sleep upstairs  in one of the four chic rooms Wm. Mulherins Sons just opened as a hotel. Theyre uniquely designed (and stocked with things like Kinfolk magazine and Aesop toiletries), and perfectly sized for longer stays (with full kitchens and even washing machines). The rooms are conveniently located above Wm. Mulherins Sons (for nightcaps) and around the corner from the La Colombe flagship (for morning coffee.) The most exciting part of your stay might just be checking in: Like at any old seaside pub, keys are simply doled out by anyone working the bar, so you can grab a pint before heading up to your room. From $275/night, wmmulherinssons.com ALAINNA LEXIE BEDDIE

title: This Meaty Fish Begs to Be Roasted
description: The monkfish ranks among the most fierce-looking of sea creatures, with an ugly mug only a monkfishs mother could love. The horrid face with its wide, round smile reveals two enormous bear-trap-like rows of razor-sharp teeth pointing backward. This presents a clear hazard for unwary small fish that happen to be in proximity when said monkfish has its mouth open. They swim in navely but cant swim out.

title: The Head Honchos Head Honcho
description: White House chief of staff is such a thankless job that Jack Watson, who served in the role under Jimmy Carter, once compared it to being a javelin catcher.

title: Amid Slaughterhouse Crackdown, Indias Lions Sample New Cuisine
description: MUMBAI  When the newly elected government of Indias most populous state began shutting down parts of the buffalo meat industry this week, the effects reverberated far and wide, but most immediately in the lions area at a city zoo.

title: Marine Le Pen of France Meets With Vladimir Putin in Moscow
description: PARIS  Marine Le Pen, the French far rights presidential candidate, has never hidden her admiration for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and on Friday she met with him in the Kremlin.

title: The Great American Novelist Who Spied for the Soviets
description: The Old Man And The C.C.C.P.: The military historian Nicholas Reynolds considers himself a lifelong fan of Ernest Hemingway. I started reading Hemingway when I was in junior high, he told me in a recent email exchange, and even at that precocious age he admired all the things you might expect a future military historian to admire in Hemingways work. The characters he created embodied so many American values we still cherish, Reynolds explains in the introduction to his new Hemingway biography, Writer, Sailor, Soldier, Spy, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No.14. Truth, bravery, independence, grace under pressure, standing up for the underdog.

title: An Obituary Six Years in the Making for Jimmy Breslin
description: People are always dying in The Times who dont seem to die in other papers, and they die at greater length and maybe even with a little more grace, the New York Times columnist James Reston wrote in 1962.

title: Ties to Ferrante?
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Janelle Mone, Gloria Steinem and Cecile Richards Among CFDA Honorees
description: In 2017, it seems that everything is somehow touched by politics. And fashion, even when it is celebrated at a chic penthouse with Champagne and Hudson River views, is no exception.

title: What a Buddhist Monk Taught Xi Jinping
description: ZHENGDING, China  In 1982, two men arrived in this dusty provincial town. One was Shi Youming, a Buddhist monk who was taking up a post in the ruins of one of Zhengdings legendary temples. The other was Xi Jinping, the 29-year-old son of a top Communist Party official putting in a mandatory stint in the provinces as a bureaucrat in the government he would eventually lead.

title: Understanding Race and History Through Photography
description: Sarah Lewis, an assistant professor at Harvard, challenges students to explore how photography, art and design formed concepts of racial identity.

title: Understanding Race and History Through Photography
description: Sarah Lewiss career path started long before she became an assistant professor of art history and African-American studies at Harvard, or held curatorial positions at the Museum of Modern Art and the Tate Modern.

title: As a Paramedic Mourns a Colleague, the Calls Don't Stop
description: Capt. Mark A. Bonilla gets the call. He flips on the lights and siren of his red Emergency Medical Service vehicle and steps on the gas. A life in the balance. Adrenaline.

title: John Mayer Has More to Say: The Outtakes
description: For this Sundays Arts and Leisure section, I profiled John Mayer, the 39-year-old singer, songwriter and guitar virtuoso, who also happens to be a prodigious talker  for better or worse. In 2010, a run of ill-advised interviews changed the course of his career as both a musician and a celebrity.

title: Sarah Dunn on the Anatomy of an Open Marriage
description: Its every married couples fantasy, at least in theory: You get to have sex with anyone you want, no questions asked. Im saying lets both do it, and lets swear to keep our mouths shut about it for the rest of our lives, says the wife in Sarah Dunns new novel, The Arrangement, as she and her husband devise a little six-month-long adultery program.

title: 12 Wine Grapes Worth Discovering
description: In the distant, cobwebbed past of the early 1980s, when I was first learning about wine, the choices were not so different from what they had been 100 years before.

title: The Jihadi Who Turned to Jesus
description: ISTANBUL  When 22 Christian refugees gathered in the basement of an apartment in Istanbul early on a recent Sunday afternoon, it was quickly clear that this was no ordinary prayer meeting. Several of them had Islamic names. There was an Abdelrahman and even a couple of Mohammads. Strangest of all, they jokingly referred to their host  one of the two Mohammads  as an irhabi. A terrorist.

title: Live Vote Count: Republicans Pull Health Care Bill
description: There will be no vote on the proposed legislation.

title: A Rogue Trader Blames the System, but Not All Are Persuaded
description: LONDON  Six years ago, Kweku M. Adoboli was a UBS trader with a rich life in London.

title: The Playlist: Kendrick Lamar Backs Up His Boasts
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

title: The London Attacker: What We Know
description: Khalid Masood is the man identified as the attacker who killed four people near British Parliament on Wednesday. This is what we know about the still-emerging details of his life.

title: What I Love | Lena Hall
description: The Tony Award-winning actress rents a studio apartment in the theater district.

title: Lena Halls 500-Square-Foot Apartment in Midtown
description: The actress Lena Hall has a big, infectious chortle. It would fill a space far larger than the immaculate 500-square-foot alcove studio she rents in the theater district, and a card on a table by the window pays fitting tribute: You have the best laugh in the history of best laughs.

title: Chinas New Limits on Money Outflows Hit a Would-Be Paradise
description: HONG KONG  Chinas intensifying efforts to keep money from leaving the country have cast doubt over big Hollywood deals and other marquee investments.

title: Israeli City Stunned That Anti-Semitic Threats Came From Within
description: ASHKELON, Israel  On the rare occasions that this small Israeli city makes the news, it is usually because it has been struck by militant rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.

title: A New Twist in iHeartMedias Debt Struggles
description: In a restructuring world dominated by oil and gas companies on the one hand and retail on the other, iHeartMedia stands out.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: The Best of Our Lives Column
description: Since 1996, The Times Magazine has published the Lives column, a series of incisive, 800-word essays or as-told-to accounts that highlight small moments in real peoples lives. While a number of well-known writers have contributed to this column  including Nora Ephron, Michael Pollan, Karen Russell and others  some of the best submissions have been from nonprofessional writers, people who felt that they had a really good story to tell. As we close the column this week, weve gathered some of our favorite essays from the archive that illustrate the power of a simple story well told.

title: Why the Payout to Credit Suisses Chief Is Undeserved
description: Tidjane Thiams compensation for 2016 shows Credit Suisses tin ear.

title: Grieving Father of Germanwings Co-Pilot Tries to Clear Sons Name
description: BERLIN  While families and friends gathered in Germany and southern France to mourn the victims of the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, Gnter Lubitz broke his silence on Friday to challenge the authorities conclusion that his son Andreas deliberately crashed the plane into the face of a mountain two years ago.

title: Not Leadership Material? Good. The World Needs Followers.
description: In 1934, a young woman named Sara Pollard applied to Vassar College. In those days, parents were asked to fill out a questionnaire, and Saras father described her, truthfully, as more a follower type than a leader.

title: A Nobel Laureate Takes On Trump in Her Latest Play
description: On the Royal Road: The Burgher King, a new play about President Trump written by the Nobel laureate Elfriede Jelinek, will have its first presentation next week in the United States.

title: Review: Emperor Jones, Fearsome and Fearful in a Roaring Revival
description: The unbounded fury of Emperor Brutus Jones blasts into the room before he does. It is the sound of a powerful man in a dangerous fit of temper. Who dare wake up the emperor? he roars.

title: Live Chat: Health Care Bills Collapse
description: Join Times reporters for coverage and analysis of the effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

title: Review: American Jihad and the Problem With the Internet
description: All the noise about immigration and travel restrictions is missing the point. Terror by radicalized Muslims isnt going to be stopped unless someone unplugs the internet.

title: The Essential Health Benefits Conservatives Are Pushing to Cut
description: A list of the basic benefits insurers must offer to people who buy their own insurance in marketplaces established by the Affordable Care Act.

title: Want Change? Shareholders Have a Tool for That
description: Are you an investor who usually junks the voluminous corporate proxy statements that arrive each spring, declining to take part in director elections and other governance matters because you think your vote wont count?

title: When Others Die, Tontine Investors Win
description: Living a long life is its own reward. But when you invest in a tontine, theres an added benefit: You collect money that would have gone to people who have died.

title: Luxury Buildings Latest Amenity: Co-Working Spaces
description: Maani Safa, the co-founder of Etch, does not lack for places to work. His company, which focuses on digital innovation, strategy and product development, rents a shared work space in TriBeCa and has offices in London and Sydney. He also keeps a home office in his two-bedroom apartment at Abington House, a rental building in West Chelsea owned by Related Companies.

title: A Pitch for Eyeglasses That Sounds Eerily Familiar
description: On March 9, Sarah Lauch received an email from a company called OpticsFast that left her shaking with anger. It read: Good news! I finally found the 3115b glasses for you, that you originally wanted. I know its been a while, I always follow up on my good customers.

title: At a Therapeutic Ranch, No Payday Until Later
description: As I set a spade to dirt, I thought back to the moment I had arrived at this dusty working ranch in southern Utah. I stepped off the plane knowing very little about what lay ahead  only that this rehabilitation program would include long periods of hard labor.

title: Visualizing the Cosmic Streams That Spew Meteor Showers
description: The Earth sails through streams of cosmic debris as it orbits the sun. When specks of dust and ice left behind by comets or asteroids collide with our atmosphere, we experience meteor showers. But what were seeing are only the final moments of a particles path through space. Most flecks have traveled for millions of miles before we see them burn up (if were lucky).

title: Gershon Kekst, Leader in Wall St. Public Relations, Dies at 82
description: Gershon Kekst, a corporate adviser who counseled many of the biggest deal makers during the merger boom of the 1980s and helped form the modern financial public relations industry, died on March 17 in New York. He was 82.

title: The Displaced
description: Nearly 60 million people are currently displaced from their homes by war and persecution. Half are children. This virtual reality film tells the stories of three of them.

title: Providing a Haven for the Homeless
description: Olga Bas, 30, is a youth counselor at the Ali Forney Center in New York.

title: Africa Center Looks to Close Fund-Raising Gap, and Open Its Doors
description: The building that houses the Africa Center, a Harlem institution devoted to African art and policy, has been completed for several years now. But fund-raising obstacles have prevented the centers space itself from opening.

title: Movies Leaving HBO and Hulu by April 1
description: At the end of every month, movies and TV shows expire from various streaming services. Here are the most interesting titles scheduled to leave HBO and Hulu at the end of March:

description: This weeks properties are on the Upper East Side, in the East Village and in Kensington, Brooklyn.

title: A Met Opera Star is Born: This Weeks 8 Best Classical Music Moments
description: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what theyve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

title: U.S. Investigating Mosul Strikes Said to Have Killed Up to 200 Civilians
description: BAGHDAD  The American-led military coalition in Iraq said Friday that it was investigating reports that scores of civilians  perhaps as many as 200, residents said  had been killed in recent American airstrikes in Mosul, the northern Iraqi city at the center of an offensive to drive out the Islamic State.

title: SeaWorld Stake, Long Held by Blackstone, Is Sold to Chinese Firm
description: Over seven years, the Blackstone Group nearly tripled its investment in SeaWorld, the home of Shamu and other killer whales.

title: Ivanka Trumps Clearance
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Penn State President Found Guilty in Sandusky Abuse Case
description: Five years after a child sex abuse scandal rocked Penn State, damaging its reputation, exposing a revered coach as a serial predator and sending him to prison, a jury on Friday convicted the former president of the university of child endangerment for failing to stop the abuse.

title: E.U. Is Turning 60 and Searching for Something to Celebrate
description: LONDON  Sixty years after the treaty that led to its founding, the European Union is under fundamental stress  divided and divergent, anxious that it no longer represents the future but the past, and that it may be incapable of handling the serious challenges of this already-turbulent century.

title: Behind the Rise of the Tampa Bay Rays Fastballs
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  In the last 10 years, no pitching staff in the American League has recorded as many strikeouts as the Tampa Bay Rays. Their pitching coach, for all that time, has been Jim Hickey, who spent two decades as a pitcher and a coach in the minors. When he joined the Houston Astros, in 2004, he saw up close how a rising fastball really looks to a hitter.

title: Eggs for Dinner, and Make It Spicy
description: Eggs have not been part of the regular dinner rotation at my house nearly as often as they should be.

title: Eggs in Spicy Tomato Sauce (Ande Ki Kari)
description: Dress up hard-boiled eggs with bold flavors in this Indian curry sauce.

title: California Upholds Auto Emissions Standards, Setting Up Face-Off With Trump
description: Californias clean-air agency voted on Friday to push ahead with stricter emissions standards for cars and trucks, setting up a potential legal battle with the Trump administration over the states plan to reduce planet-warming gases.

title: Owner of Airbnb Listing in Trump Tower Is Fined $1,000
description: New York City officials issued a summons to the owner of a condominium at Trump Tower that gained notoriety after being rented out on Airbnb, determining that the unit was being illegally advertised for rent.

title: Anti-Immigrant Bias Against Asians and the Irish
description: To the Editor:

title: The Republicans Health Care Defeat
description: To the Editor:

title: On Eve of E.U. Anniversary, Pope Warns of Blocs Fragility
description: ROME  On the eve of celebrations commemorating the 60th anniversary of treaties that led to the creation of the European Union, Pope Francis warned the blocs leaders on Friday that while their countries may be inseparably linked, the project could still fail.

title: Can the Arts Thrive Without Washington? A Kansas Town Says Yes
description: HAYS, Kan.  When taxpayer money for the arts started getting tight in Kansas, Brenda Meder began scrubbing toilets at the gallery she oversees here, rather than paying for custodial services. She cooked the finger food for receptions, instead of using a caterer. And she signed up more dues-paying members of the Hays Arts Council, a 49-year-old organization where she is the executive director and only full-time employee.

title: Boris V. Shekhtman, Who Taught Russian to Journalists and Diplomats, Dies at 77
description: Boris V. Shekhtman, a Soviet migr who taught conversational Russian to a generation of American journalists, diplomats and entrepreneurs  from the grim lingo of Cold War aggression to the beguiling argot of capitalist negotiation  died on March 18 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 77.

title: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
description: Its our first spring weekend! So says the calendar, anyway. Who knows about the weather?

title: London, Donald Trump, Keystone Pipeline: Your Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: In a Call to The Times, Trump Blames Democrats for the Failure of the Health Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Just moments after the Republican plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act was declared dead, President Trump sought to paint the defeat of his first legislative effort as an early-term blip.

title: Court Awards $1 Million for Victims of Congolese Warlord
description: PARIS  The International Criminal Court on Friday found a former militia leader liable for $1 million in reparations to his victims and their relatives in a village in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It ordered that payments be made in small amounts of cash to individuals and used for projects benefiting the wider community.

title: With Classic Watch, TAG Heuer Turns Back Time at Baselworld Fair
description: Two years ago, TAG Heuer grabbed headlines at the giant Baselworld watch fair with a glimpse of the future: a Google-enabled smartwatch, the Connected, that was considered the first big Swiss counterstrike to the Apple Watch.

title: Big Ben Still Tolled
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

title: Waking From Hibernation, the Hard Work of Spring Begins
description: For animals that hibernate, making it to spring is no small feat. Torpor  the state of reduced bodily activity that occurs during hibernation  is not restful. By the time they emerge, hibernating animals are often sleep-deprived: Most expend huge bursts of energy to arouse themselves occasionally in the winter so their body temperatures dont dip too low. This back-and-forth is exhausting, and hibernators do it with little to no food and water. By winters end, some have shed more than half their body weight.

title: Tracing His Roots, Georgetown Employee Learns University Sold His Ancestor
description: As a Georgetown employee, Jeremy Alexander watched as the university grappled with its haunted past: the sale of slaves in 1838 to help rescue it from financial ruin.

title: Don Hunstein, Who Photographed Great Musicians, Dies at 88
description: On a freezing February afternoon in 1963, the photographer Don Hunstein asked Bob Dylan and his girlfriend, Suze Rotolo, to walk along a slush-covered Jones Street in Greenwich Village, near Mr. Dylans small apartment. Mr. Dylan, in a thin jacket, and Ms. Rotolo, bundled in a coat over bulky sweaters, strolled arm in arm past cars and trucks and into music history.

title: The Photographs of Don Hunstein
description: As a staff photographer for Columbia Records, Mr. Hunstein shot Bob Dylan, Billie Holiday and many others.

title: Womens Teams Fight Sheds Light on U.S.A. Hockey Leadership
description: After a 10-hour meeting Monday with U.S.A. Hockey, members of the United States womens national team were confident that an agreement for increased pay and support was near.

title: Russian Agent Killed Lawmaker in Kiev, Ukraine Officials Say
description: The assassin who gunned down a prominent Russian opposition figure on a sidewalk in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev was identified by Ukrainian officials on Friday as a 28-year-old Russian agent.

title: Trumps Trainwreck
description: For seven years  seven years  Republicans thundered about the evils of Obamacare, yearned for the day when they could bury it and vowed to do precisely that once the ball was in their hands.

title: How the Health Care Vote Fell Apart, Step by Step
description: WASHINGTON  After several days of dramatic back and forth between President Trump and Republicans in Congress, House Republicans pulled a bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, delivering the president a staggering defeat in his first high-profile legislative effort.

title: Toronto Schools to Cease Field Trips to U.S.
description: Toronto schools have stopped planning field trips to the United States, citing concerns that some students may be turned away at the border in the wake of President Trumps latest travel ban and the American immigration authorities newly implemented extreme vetting procedures.

title: Bizarre Stunt at Auschwitz: Group Kills a Sheep, Then Strips
description: WARSAW  Nearly a dozen people in their 20s gathered beside the entrance to the Auschwitz memorial on Friday afternoon, slaughtered a sheep, stripped naked and chained themselves together. A fireworks device was set off in the nearby parking lot.

title: On the Rock, Looking Inward and Outward
description: Jeffersonville, Vt.  Just at the edge of sight, a man dangled from a rope, high in the air. For days, storms had dimmed the sky, but the angle of the cliff overhung so much that the drops of water fell to the ground without touching him. It was as if, he later wrote, he climbed under the protection of a stupendous umbrella.

title: The Real Threat to National Security: Deadly Disease
description: While the Trump administration is proposing significantly increased military spending to enhance our national security, it seems to have lost sight of the greatest national security threat of all: our fight against infectious disease.

title: I Loved My Grandmother. But She Was a Nazi.
description: My grandparents were Nazis. It took me until recently to be able to say  or write  this. I used to think of and refer to them as ordinary Germans, as if that was a distinct and morally neutral category. But like many ordinary Germans, they were members of the Nazi Party  they joined in 1937.

title: Amid Trump Inquiry, a Primer on Surveillance Practices and Privacy
description: WASHINGTON  The assertion by the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Devin Nunes, that he saw intelligence reports showing that government surveillance programs incidentally collected communications involving Trump transition team members between November and January, has further muddied an already murky imbroglio.

title: Trumps Choice on Obamacare: Sabotage or Co-opt?
description: President Trump and a Republican-led Congress tried and failed to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Now, they have to decide whether they want to work with it or sabotage it.

title: A.C.P.T. 2017: Friday Night
description: How does it feel to walk into the biggest crossword puzzle tournament in the country? Walk into the Stamford, CT Marriott Hotel with Deb Amlen to find out.

title: Starting for Oregon, Three Freshmen Who Dont Play Like It
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  The Oregon Ducks womens basketball team, which has reached the N.C.A.A. tournaments round of 16 for the first time and faces mighty Maryland on Saturday, appears to contradict the idea that experience is vital to winning games in March.

title: Fact Check: Trumps Misleading Claims on the Health Bill Failure
description: WASHINGTON  Reeling from a major blow to his legislative agenda, President Trump blamed Democrats on Friday after House Republicans rescinded their bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. He insisted it wasnt an immediate priority anyway.

title: Civics Lesson Unfolds at Capitol as Health Care Bill Incinerates
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump had already given his blessing: Pull the bill. Speaker Paul D. Ryan, bound for the basement of the Capitol, was preparing to deliver the news to his conference.

title: The Trump Administration Clears Trumps Washington Hotel
description: Since the election, it has been clear that Donald Trump cannot both be president and maintain a lease on the government-owned Old Post Office building in Washington, where he opened an opulent hotel last year. Now, a federal official who works for the agency that negotiated the lease (and that, conveniently, reports to the president) has come up with a bizarre, tortured and ultimately dishonest rationale for why Mr. Trump can keep it.

title: Meet the Queens of Monday Puzzles
description: Lynn Lempel and Andrea Carla Michaels meet for the first time Friday night at the 2017 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

title: Stolen Bases Continue to Plague Noah Syndergaard and Travis dArnaud
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets starter Noah Syndergaard has made a point of improving the pace of his delivery to home plate. He has had no choice, really, because he allowed a major league-leading 48 stolen bases last season and teams were increasingly looking to run on him.

title: Paul Manafort to Testify Before House Intelligence Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Paul Manafort, who served as President Trumps campaign manager and is under scrutiny for his ties to Russia, will testify before the House Intelligence Committee, the panels chairman said on Friday.

title: Who Stopped the Republican Health Bill?
description: A closer look at members who were against the proposed law.

title: Bernie Wrightson, Artist and a Creator of Swamp Thing, Dies at 68
description: Bernie Wrightson, a widely admired comic book artist who was known for his lush, intricate, otherworldly visions of horror and who was one of the creators of the popular DC Comics character Swamp Thing, died on March 18 in Austin, Tex. He was 68.

title: In Reporters Hometown, Students Look Toward Somewhere Theyre Welcomed
description: One by one, the students in Phillip Wrigleys college advising class at Topeka High School listed their names, the colleges they wanted to apply to and the majors they might like to pursue.

title: Corrections: March 25, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: William Keeler, Cardinal Who Championed Sexual Abuse Victims, Dies at 86
description: Cardinal William H. Keeler, who as archbishop of Baltimore strove to improve relations between the Roman Catholic Church and American Jews, and who championed victims of sexual abuse by priests, died on Thursday in Catonsville, Md. He was 86.

title: Trumps Triumph of Incompetence
description: One of President Trumps rare strengths has been his ability to project competence. The Dow Jones stock index is up an astonishing 2,200 points since his election in part because investors believed Trump could deliver tax reform and infrastructure spending.

title: Echoes of Gunfire Hurt Tender N.R.A. Ears
description: It is a chilling commentary on the nature of gun mayhem in this country that dozens of cities and towns are resorting to new listening technology so the police can track the location of gunfire in a matter of seconds.

title: The TrumpRyanCare Debacle
description: Repealing the Affordable Care Act was meant to be the first demonstration of the power and effectiveness of a unified Republican government. It has turned out to be a display of incompetence and cruelty.

title: Israel May Offer Only a General Commitment to Slow Settlement Building
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administrations negotiations with the Israeli government are expected to yield only a general commitment  and not a specific pledge  to slow the building of Jewish settlements in the West Bank, an administration official briefed on the talks said on Friday.

title: Bracing for the Fallout of the Health Bills Collapse
description: WASHINGTON  Fridays collapse of Republican plans to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act has broad implications not only for the nations health care system, but also for the fate of President Trumps ambitious agenda in his young and chaotic presidency.

title: The Health Care Bill Has Failed. Let the Finger Pointing Begin.
description: The blame game is a time-honored Washington tradition. A look at whos blaming whom for the failure of the House bill, in public and in private.

title: Republicans Land a Punch on Health Care, to Their Own Face
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of the long day, the alliance of conservative ideologues who once shut down the government over President Barack Obamas health care law could not find the will to repeal it.

title: Quotation of the Day: Defeat in Trumps First Legislative Fight Casts Shadow on Agenda
description: Were going to be living with Obamacare for the foreseeable future.

title: The Jewelry Icon: Cabochons and Color
description: Since the early 1960s Bulgari has been experimenting with combinations of precious and semiprecious stones in rounded forms.

title: In Dropping Health Vote, Trump Swallowed Need for a Showdown
description: WASHINGTON  When Speaker Paul D. Ryan arrived at the White House on Friday to inform President Trump that the health care bill he had made his first major legislative push could not pass, Mr. Trump had one reaction: He wanted revenge.

title: Canada Today: Restaurant Resentment and Cardboard Trudeaus
description: Each week, Canada Today mixes the Timess recent Canada-related coverage with back stories and analysis from our reporters along with opinions from our readers.

title: U.N. Takes Step Toward Future Prosecutions Against North Korea
description: The United Nations Human Rights Council adopted a resolution on Friday that authorizes the use of criminal justice experts to devise legal strategies for eventual prosecutions of violations by North Korea.

title: North Carolina Runs Over Butler in Path to Redemption
description: MEMPHIS  Coach Roy Williams recalled feeling so inadequate in that locker room last season. North Carolina had just lost in the national championship game to Villanova on a last-second shot, and Williams was left to rummage through his teams splintered dreams. What could he say? How could he help?

title: Time of Ones Life
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Its such a relief to me that crosswords are a cool thing to do now.

title: Republicans Withdraw Their Health Bill
description: President Trump faced stiff opposition from lawmakers in his own party to the measure he had endorsed, and it was withdrawn.

title: Police Posted Missing Teenagers Data on Social Media. A City Took Note.
description: A new approach by the Metropolitan Police Department in Washington to use social media to raise awareness about teenagers reported missing did indeed gain attention  some of it unintentional.

title: South Carolina Stuns Baylor to Reach the Round of Eight
description: South Carolinas win over second-seeded Duke was not only a surprise to fans. In the postgame revelry, Coach Frank Martin had to ask an assistant whom his team would face next.

title: Two Die in Separate Cases of Falling From Buildings in Brooklyn
description: A 21-year-old man died at an apartment party on early Saturday morning in Brooklyn after falling through a screen window on the buildings fourth floor, the police said.

title: Alone in the Wild for a Year, TV Contestants Learn Their Show Was Canceled
description: The remaining contestants on a reality television series have emerged after surviving 12 months in the Scottish wilderness  fending off hunger, infighting and fatigue  only to learn that the show stopped broadcasting after four episodes, the last of them in August.

title: Arkansas Struggles to Find Enough People to Watch Executions
description: The state of Arkansas, which plans to execute eight inmates over 10 days next month, is struggling to overcome a logistical problem to carry that out: There are not enough people who want to watch them die.

title: John Calipari Has a Winning Return to Memphis as Kentucky Tops U.C.L.A.
description: MEMPHIS  At halftime, Kentucky Coach John Calipari relayed a set of instructions to his players.

title: Dustin Johnson and Phil Mickelson Cruise at Match Play
description: Dustin Johnson and Phil Mickelson showed the simple side to the Dell Technologies Match Play in Austin, Tex. For three straight days in warmth, wind or rain, they built early leads and never let anyone get close to them in advancing out of their groups to the knockout stage.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Adam Driver in Paterson and a Murderous Mother-to-Be in Prevenge
description: Adam Driver gets behind the wheel  and turns his musings into poetry  in Jim Jarmuschs Paterson. And an expectant mother goes on a killing rampage guided by her fetus in Prevenge.

title: U.S. Routs Honduras and Steadies Its World Cup Qualifying Campaign
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  There was never any reason to worry. Nope, never, not at all.

title: Chris Chiozzas Buzzer-Beater Sends Florida Past Wisconsin in Overtime
description: There were five Wisconsin players and one whirring blur of white cleaving all of them  a Florida point guard motoring up the court, veering out of control and finally planting his foot at just the right spot.

title: Seen on the Streets: Fashion Mavericks, a Stylish Couple and Fran Lebowitz
description: Im not really interested in color, said Andre Wagner, a Brooklyn photographer who specializes in street style. Black and white photography just has a harmony that I like.

title: Never Has Politics Felt So Personal to Me
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: Amazons Ambitions Unboxed: Stores for Furniture, Appliances and More
description: SEATTLE  Last Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif., Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, climbed into the cockpit of a 13-foot robot and began flailing his arms as though warming up for a workout, causing the robots enormous appendages to mimic his movements.

title: Animals in the Artist's Studio
description: Artist Kendra Haste was commissioned to create sculptures of the wild animals that once lived in the Royal Menagerie. Get a 360 view of her studio/zoo and the installation at the Tower of London.

title: When David Met Brooke: The Ultimate New York Power Couple
description: At the Museum of Modern Arts annual spring benefit last June, Helen Mirren could be spotted near one of the artists being honored that night, Brice Marden. A few feet away was Marilyn Minter, squiring another honoree, Mark Bradford.

title: Canadians Adopted Refugee Families for a Year. Then Came Month 13.
description: TORONTO  One year after Canada embraced Syrian refugees like no other country, a reckoning was underway.

title: Missing Taiwanese Man May Be in Chinese Custody, Some Fear
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The disappearance of a Taiwanese activist for human rights and democratic causes has raised fears here that he may have been detained by the Chinese authorities.

title: Whats Ann-Margret Doing at 75? Still Playing the Girl Next Door
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  In the new Zach Braff-directed heist comedy Going in Style, out April 7, the performer Ann-Margret stars as Annie, a supermarket employee who flirts, overtly, with a grumpy old man of a customer played by Alan Arkin.

title: Ariel Levy Has Written a Thoroughly Modern Memoir
description: Just before Thanksgiving 2012, Ariel Levy, a staff writer at The New Yorker, flew to Mongolia to report on that countrys mining boom. She was 38 years old and five months pregnant, and on her second night there, she miscarried in her hotel room, delivering her son in a torrent of blood that nearly killed her. Her son would not survive, but Ms. Levy detailed in a heartbreaking essay a year later that would win her a National Magazine Award that after she yanked the placenta from her body, crawled to the phone and called a local doctor, she took the boys photo.

title: The Perverse Thrill of Chaotic Times
description: For all the rational appeal of peace and stability, Americans have a powerful attraction to calamity and disruption. World War II veterans commonly speak of their time in the military, when they felt deeply connected to a meaningful goal, as the best years of their lives. For many baby boomers, the late 1960s, with all its sturm und drang over an unpopular war and antiquated social policies, remains on their personal highlight reels (the free love and drugs may have had something to do with it, too). People who came of age in the pacific 90s just dont speak as reverently of seeing Stone Temple Pilots play Lollapalooza as flower children do of watching Hendrix at Woodstock.

title: Ginger Gibson and Travis Burk: She Was All Business, or So He Thought
description: Virginia Stella Gibson and Travis Andrews Burk were married March 25 at Maison du Lac, an event space in New Orleans. The Very Rev. William A. J. Heine Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: The New Currency Champ Lives South of the Border
description: Can you guess which world currency has gained the most since Donald J. Trumps inauguration as president?

title: E.U. Leaders Sign Rome Declaration and Proclaim a Common Future (Minus Britain)
description: ROME  Proclaiming Europe is our common future, 27 leaders of the European Union signed a statement on Saturday in Rome declaring their commitment to integrating the Continent even as a series of crises has badly weakened the efforts and Britain prepares  to leave the bloc.

title: One Nation, Under Fox: 18 Hours With a Network That Shapes America
description: I know maybe the president is watching.

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: YouTubes Problematic Advertising
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Endless Parties Next Door
description: Q. I live in a rent-stabilized building in Chelsea, Manhattan, next to a  woman who gives  loud parties. She and her guests yell, bang on  walls and slam doors until 5 a.m. The police will not intervene because she will not open the door for them. After I complained, she retaliated by banging on my door, which I considered harassment. Many tenants, and the live-in super, have complained to her and notified the landlord, who said there is nothing he can do. Is this  true? What legal standing do we have?

title: Knicks Joakim Noah Suspended for Failing a Doping Test
description: The Knicks Joakim Noah became one of the rare prominent N.B.A. players to be suspended under the leagues policy on performance-enhancing drugs when the league announced Saturday that he would serve a 20-game penalty.

title: Robin OHara, Producer of Independent Films, Dies at 62
description: Robin OHara, who was a producer of Tom Noonans What Happened Was ..., a co-producer of Harmony Korines Gummo and a producer of other notable independent films, died on March 14 in Manhattan. She was 62.

title: Clint Dempseys Hat Trick Seals a Win and Steadies a World Cup Campaign
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  This whole notion of the United States national team being in crisis has been getting a little tiresome for the players, and as if to underscore his frustration after its 6-0 thrashing of Honduras at Avaya Stadium on Friday night, midfielder Michael Bradley dipped into the past for context.

title: After London Attack, Living Between Cultures
description: Five days ago in London, Iranians were celebrating Nowruz, teaching our English friends to say Happy New Year in Farsi. Two days later, a terrorist named Khalid Masood drove into a crowd of pedestrians on Westminster Bridge, killing two and injuring forty. Now, again, here we are on familiar ground: Someone has killed in the name of Islam.

title: Where Youre Not a Senior Until Youre Eighty
description: SPECIAL POST  If you can read and write, you can solve a crossword puzzle. It doesnt make much of a difference if you are eight or eighty, except as far as your cultural references are concerned. Taking delight in playing with words and language helps.

title: Miners Found a 706-Carat Diamond in Sierra Leone. Who Should Get the Profit?
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Fist-size and lumpy, the rock that a team of miners came upon recently in the diamond fields of Sierra Leone was orange with red speckles that looked like tiny droplets of palm oil.

title: Indonesians Taste for Dog Meat Is Growing, Even as Others Shun It
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Parlin Sitio leaned back from a table of empty dishes at a restaurant in eastern Jakarta with a look of satisfaction. He had just enjoyed an order of rica-rica  dog meat with Indonesian spices.

title: British Party That Backed Brexit Loses Its Only Member of Parliament
description: LONDON  The short and happy life of the United Kingdom Independence Party, or UKIP, may be coming to a close after its only member of Parliament, Douglas Carswell, quit the party on Saturday to become an independent.

title: Renegotiate Nafta? Mexicans Say Get On With It
description: MEXICO CITY  For more than two decades, free trade has been at the heart of Mexicos relationship with America, responsible for pumping a stream of vehicles, audio components and avocados north and cheap corn, cattle and software south.

title: Nebraska May Stanch One Towns Flow of Beer to Its Vulnerable Neighbors
description: WHITECLAY, Neb.  This town is a rural skid row, with only a dozen residents, a street strewn with debris, four ramshackle liquor stores and little else. It seems to exist only to sell beer to people like Tyrell Ringing Shield, a grandmother with silver streaks in her hair.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The last time a Puns and Anagrams puzzle ran in The Times, the editor Will Shortz gave us a handy lesson on the wide variety of cluing that solvers can find in PandAs, as they are affectionately called. Mr. Shortz wrote the piece to clarify that PandAs had a method for cluing beyond just puns and anagrams, and that they are a type of puzzle that stands strongly on its own, as opposed to just being somewhat similar to a cryptic crossword.

title: Trump Becomes Ensnared in Fiery G.O.P. Civil War
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump ignites a lot of fights, but his failure to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the biggest defeat in his short time in the White House, was the result of something else: a long-running Republican civil war that humbled a generation of party leaders before he ever came to Washington.

title: Paul Ryan Emerges From Health Care Defeat Badly Damaged
description: WASHINGTON  For two days in January, all seemed right in the Republican Party.

title: Trumps Biggest Obstacle to Policy Goals? His Own Missteps
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps failure to make good on his signature promise to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act is the most crushing political defeat of his early days in the White House.

title: Shoes, Shirts, You Name It, College Basketball Players Get It. Free.
description: MEMPHIS  One of the perks of playing college basketball for a powerhouse program like North Carolina is all the team-issued gear. Every year, the Tar Heels are outfitted with more shirts, sweats and sneakers than they can possibly wear in a season.

title: U.S.-Led Coalition Confirms Strikes Hit Mosul Site Where Civilians Died
description: WASHINGTON  The American-led military coalition in Iraq said Saturday that an initial review of recent airstrikes in Mosul, the Islamic States last stronghold in Iraq, had confirmed that the strikes hit a site where scores of civilians were killed.

title: Greg Birds Bat Has Powers. His Cat Has Dr. Evil.
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For more than four decades, the Yankees lineup has almost always included a first baseman with left-handed power. Think of Chris Chambliss, Don Mattingly, Tino Martinez, Jason Giambi and Mark Teixeira. Chances are you picture a lot of home runs clearing the inviting right-field wall in the Bronx.

title: Going Under the Knife, With Eyes and Ears Wide Open
description: BENSALEM, Pa.  Do you want to see your tendons?

title: Watching My Surgeon Cut Into My Knee
description: What if the surgeon started slicing into my knee before it was completely numb?

title: Meet the Judges
description: SPECIAL POST  The prospect of running a tournament with more than 600 competitors over the course of an exhausting weekend is a daunting one, but Will Shortz, who has hosted the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament for 40 years, is prepared.

title: Donald, This I Will Tell You
description: WASHINGTON  Dear Donald,

title: U.S. vs. Nordic Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: What Would You Do With an Intruder at the Door?
description: LOS ANGELES  I was working at my desk the other day, overlooking my front yard, when I saw a man walk by the window and around the corner toward the back of the house. He was in his late 20s, wearing a rumpled gray sweatshirt; Id never seen him before.

title: Will the Labor Secretary Help Labor?
description: R. Alexander Acosta had an advantage last week when he appeared before the Senate committee overseeing his nomination by President Trump to be secretary of labor: He was not Andrew Puzder, the unqualified fast-food executive and Mr. Trumps first choice, who had to withdraw in the face of public and senatorial opposition to his appointment.

title: Pumping Life Into the Equal Rights Amendment
description: The progress of womens equality has not exactly been swift in American history. The endorsement of the Equal Rights Amendment on Wednesday by the Nevada Legislature  35 years after the congressional deadline for passage  is being read by supporters as an encouraging sign, however slow-paced.

title: Thanks for Submitting Your Rsum to This Black Hole
description: From: Job Spotter

title: Congresss Duty in the War With ISIS
description: On the verge of driving the Islamic State out of Mosul, once Iraqs second-largest city, the United States and its allies are beginning a push to recapture Raqqa, the Syrian city that is the de facto capital of the self-declared caliphate.

title: Dont Fight Their Lies With Lies of Your Own
description: A student asked me the other day whether I approved of exaggerating for a good cause. The topic had apparently been discussed at an environmental forum, and the question was, essentially, Does saving the climate justify lying? Wouldnt it be a good idea to use an impressive, if not necessarily factually correct, message to counteract the mind-numbing cacophony of the Trump administration, which drowns out more reasoned speech?

title: The Love Letters of Manly Men
description: Flowers, trinkets, borrowed sweaters and other reminders of our romantic past may get tossed out. But love letters, for those lucky enough to receive them, are different. They are more likely tucked in a wallet or safeguarded in a box under the bed.

title: After Great Pain, Where Is God?
description: These days I find Im more alert to the grief and sorrow around me than I once was. In part its a product of my age, of youth giving way. Im guessing my situation is not that different from many of yours.

title: Justice Springs Eternal
description: THIS wasnt how the story was supposed to end. After almost 50 years of relentless prison-building in the United States, of aggressive policing and a war on drugs that goes after our most vulnerable citizens, the movement for a more merciful criminal justice system had begun to seem, if not unstoppable, at least plenty powerful.

title: Break Up the Liberal City
description: THE age of Trump has inspired soul-searching within our overclass  long nights reading Hillbilly Elegy, mostly  but also a wave of cosmopolitan pride. During the presidential campaign, when Trump talked about making America great again, Hillary Clinton countered that America is already great  meaning, of course, dynamic and diverse and tolerant and future-oriented, all the things that Trump seems to dismiss and his voters seem to fear.

title: What You Can Do About Climate Change
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  What can you  just one concerned person  do about global warming?

title: The 2017 A.C.P.T. Rankings After Puzzle 2
description: SPECIAL POST  Were headed into Puzzle 4 as of this writing, but the rankings after Puzzle 2 are available online here.

title: Congolese Militia Beheads Dozens of Police Officers
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  Members of a militia ambushed and then beheaded about 40 police officers on Friday in a central province of the Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said on Saturday.

title: North Koreas Rising Ambition Seen in Bid to Breach Global Banks
description: When hackers associated with North Korea tried to break into Polish banks late last year they left a trail of information about their apparent intentions to steal money from more than 100 organizations around the world, according to security researchers.

title: Uber Suspends Tests of Self-Driving Vehicles After Arizona Crash
description: Uber said on Saturday that it was suspending the testing of its self-driving vehicles, a day after one of the vehicles was involved in a collision in Tempe, Ariz.

title: Out to Fix the Twins, a New Executive Wants More From the Mound
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  The best Derek Falvey can say about himself, as a pitcher, is that he usually put the ball where he wanted. He had a generic assortment of pitches: a curveball, a changeup and a fastball that never reached 90 miles per hour. Sometimes he varied arm angles. He tried anything to survive.

title: Neighbors of Masood: We Are All Very Shocked
description: Neighbors of Khalid Masood, the London attacker, were left stunned by the news that he had lived alongside them in Birmingham, after police officers raided his former home.

title: Health Bills Failure Leaves Supporters in a Political Jam Back Home
description: They went to unusual, even dangerous lengths to support President Trumps unpopular health care bill, facing down protesters at home and begging for special accommodation from House leaders in Washington. John Faso of New York negotiated a side deal for his state in exchange for backing it. Mike Coffman was the lone Colorado lawmaker to endorse the bill, while his Republican neighbors agonized and stalled.

title: Alex Jones Apologizes for Promoting Pizzagate Hoax
description: Alex Jones, a prominent conspiracy theorist and the host of a popular right-wing radio show, has apologized for helping to spread and promote the hoax known as Pizzagate.

title: Andorra Ends 11 Years of Losses, With a Tie
description: Rarely has a scoreless stalemate tasted so sweet. But 11 years of nothing but losing will do that to a team.

title: After an Uncharacteristic Early Stumble, UConn Breezes to Win
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma won his 112th N.C.A.A. tournament game on Saturday, tying Tennessees Pat Summitt for the career record. And his top-seeded team advanced to the Bridgeport Regional final with an 86-71 win over fourth-seeded U.C.L.A., the 110th straight victory for the Huskies, four-time defending national champions.

title: Mixed Results

title: A Risk We Choose: Emergency Workers Mourn One of Their Own

title: Boris Epshteyn, Trump TV Surrogate, Is Leaving White House Job

Pisarello of Copiague, N.Y. The grooms father, who was appointed a deputy commissioner for the day by San Diego County, led the ceremony at Seagrove Park in Del Mar, Calif.

Gruss of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Nicholas Vesey, a priest ordained in the Church of England, performed the ceremony at Aspen Chapel in Aspen, Colo.

description: Danny Manuel Gomez and John Francis McGowan were married March 25 at Bow Bridge in Central Park in Manhattan. Edward J. McGowan, who became a minister through Rose Ministries, and is Mr. McGowans brother, officiated. On April 11, his brother is to lead them in their vows at Aiguadol Beach in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Frank Sheppard, Range Shaw
description: Frank William Sheppard and Range Preston Shaw were married March 25 at their home in Phoenix. Lawrence Winthrop, a judge with Division One of the Arizona Court of Appeals, officiated.

title: Jennifer Yoon, Gustav Cederquist
description: Jennifer Sung-Ae Yoon, the daughter of Dr. Florence L. Yoon and Dr. David K. Yoon of Ormond Beach, Fla., was married March 25 to Gustav Young-Min Cederquist, the son of Dr. Hyunduck N. Cederquist and Dr. Robert Cederquist of Malvern, Pa. The Rev. Timothy Yoon, a Presbyterian minister and the brides paternal grandfather, officiated at the Harvard Club of New York.

Brown of Red Bank, N.J. The grooms father, a Baptist pastor, officiated at the Naples Beach Hotel & Golf Club in Naples, Fla.

title: Drone Strike Kills Planner of 2008 Islamabad Hotel Bombing, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  A Pakistani militant who planned a devastating truck bomb attack on a hotel in Islamabad in 2008  which left two members of the American military and dozens of others dead  was killed in recent days by an American drone strike in Afghanistan, the Pentagon said on Saturday night.

title: Carrie Lam Wins Vote to Become Hong Kongs Next Leader
description: HONG KONG  A committee dominated by supporters of the Chinese government chose Carrie Lam as Hong Kongs next leader on Sunday, opting for Beijings preferred candidate in a move likely to dismay residents who see the citys freedoms as being under threat from China.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: The Bront Sisters and Love in the Mediterranean
description: Travel through Victorian England as the Bront sisters prove themselves in a mans world. Then take a Mediterranean vacation with some passionate couples.

description: 6 Gilman Lane, Cortlandt

title: Inside the Wooden Worlds of Prayer Beads
description: For centuries, experts were mystified by Gothic boxwood miniatures  intricate scenes carved into walnut-size spheres in the 1400s and 1500s. Now, high-resolution scans bring their detail to life. Step inside the beads yourself in this 360 video.

title: Health Care, London, Mosul: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Trump vs. Congress: Now What?
description: On Monday, Jan. 9, less than two weeks before President Trumps inauguration, the House speaker, Paul Ryan, hosted a dinner at his office in the Capitol with members of Trumps inner circle. The guests included the president-elects chief White House strategist, Stephen K. Bannon; his son-in-law and family consigliere, Jared Kushner; his chief of staff, Reince Priebus; his economic adviser, Gary Cohn; his nominee for Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin; his incoming deputy chief of staff, Rick Dearborn; and his legislative-affairs director, Marc Short. The ostensible purpose of the dinner was to discuss the details of Trumps legislative agenda  in particular, the prospects for a sweeping tax-reform measure that Republicans, and especially Ryan, have been coveting for the past decade.

title: What Racial Terms Make You Cringe?
description: This is a version of the weekly Race/Related newsletter. To get it in your inbox, sign up here.

title: China Bars Professor at Australian University From Leaving, Lawyer Says
description: BEIJING  A Chinese-born professor at an Australian university who has often criticized Beijings crackdown on political dissent has been barred from leaving China and is being questioned by state security officers as a suspected threat to national security, his lawyer said on Sunday.

title: In a Twist, Its Saniya Chong Powering UConn Womens Basketball
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Saniya Chong fell hard after a rattling foul late in Connecticuts 86-71 victory over U.C.L.A. on Saturday. She made two free throws, then soon jogged to the sideline. She rinsed a small cut on her lip with a swig of water and spit into a cup, as if the game were being played by rounds instead of quarters.

title: Looking Back on the Crime Scene That Spanned the Entire City
description: There is a planter on the sidewalk in front of a 7-Eleven on Eighth Avenue in Chelsea. It is intended to cheer the place up, unless one knows how it came to be there.

title: When a President Says, Ill Kill You
description: On the streets of Manila, the body count rises daily as journalists document the crusade of President Rodrigo Duterte.

title: Before and After Chuck Berry
description: An audio guide to Chuck Berry's influential hits  from what came before to what came after. Listen to the sound of rock n roll being made.

title: Going to the Big Boards
description: SPECIAL POST  At this writing, the crowded ballroom of the Stamford Marriott is silent as more than 600 competitors race to finish Joel Faglianos Puzzle 7. Its really just a formality, because the solvers who will compete in the Finals has mostly been determined, but it does give all of the competitors one last chance to say they beat the clock.

title: Jeanine Pirro Calls for Paul Ryan to Step Down After Health Bill Failure
description: Jeanine Pirro, a Fox News host, is a longtime friend of President Trump. So when Mr. Trump said on Twitter on Saturday  a day after his crushing defeat in the House on health care  that people should watch her show that night, political observers began guessing what was in store.

title: Angela Merkels Re-election Bid Is Buoyed by Widely Watched State Election
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany received a significant lift to her re-election bid on Sunday when her party finished a clear first in a state election that was widely watched as a test of her strength.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Who Killed the Iceman? Clues Emerge in a Very Cold Case
description: BOLZANO, Italy  When the head of a small Italian museum called Detective Inspector Alexander Horn of the Munich Police, she asked him if he investigated cold cases.

title: Unity, Instead of Fear, After Swastikas Are Carved Into a Church Door
description: Weve done a pretty good job of covering them up, the Rev. Schuyler Vogel said.
