title: Rex Tillersons Praise for Turkey Is Met With a List of Complaints
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson showered praise on Turkeys government on Thursday, despite what some international critics see as a slide toward authoritarianism, and in response he got an earful of grievances from Turkish officials.

title: Faith and Identity Clash in The Profane: An Actors Round Table
description: Sam and Emina are two American kids attending college upstate. They meet. They fall in love. They get engaged.

title: Recycled Rockets Could Drop Costs, Speed Space Travel
description: SpaceX did something on Thursday that really hadnt been done before: launch a cheaper, partially-used rocket into orbit.

title: Little Tropical Fish With a Big, Venomous Bite
description: Its a small fish, only a couple of inches long, and its bright colors make it pop in the Pacific coral reefs it calls home. The first thing that makes this fish peculiar is the striking pair of large lower canines it sports.

title: Ivanka Trump Is a Bad Ambassador for Working Women
description: Ivanka Trump will now have an official job at the White House. Its an unpaid role as an adviser to her father, the president, but it comes with an office, a title and, presumably, an even higher perch from which to fashion herself as a crusader for working women.

title: Arkansas Bans Sex-Selection Abortion
description: The governor of Arkansas has signed a law that requires doctors to investigate the pregnancy history of women seeking abortions and to make sure they are not using the procedure as a way to select the gender of the child. Abortion rights proponents said on Thursday that they planned to challenge the law.

title: Net Neutrality Is Trumps Next Target, Administration Says
description: The Trump administration served notice on Thursday that its next move to deregulate broadband internet service companies would be to jettison the Obama administrations net neutrality rules, which were intended to safeguard free expression online.

title: 3 Are Held on Suspicion of Plot to Attack Rialto Bridge in Venice
description: VENICE  The Italian police announced on Thursday that they had dismantled a suspected jihadist cell whose members had discussed blowing up the Rialto Bridge, one of the top tourist attractions in Venice.

title: Good Girl Prom Dress Fliers Draw Criticism for Florida School
description: A series of fliers posted in a college preparatory school in Florida tried to convey appropriate prom attire for female students.

title: Meet the Introverted Extroverts of Ribeira Sacra
description: For a region as ancient as Ribeira Sacra, it may seem odd that we dont know a lot about the wine.

title: Your Next Lesson: Lambrusco
description: It has been said that sparkling reds are the final frontier for American wine drinkers. Here is your chance to take the plunge. This month, we will explore Lambrusco, the bubbly red wine that has refreshed the people of the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy for generations.

title: Modern Images of an Old German City Destroyed in WWII
description: Andrea Grutzner captured mesmerizing shots using an old-school camera.

title: Why Trump Is Taking On Car Emission Rules
description: President Trump and the E.P.A. are scaling back Obama-era rules for U.S. automakers on greenhouse gas emissions. Heres the breakdown.

title: Review: Live Cargo, Human Trafficking, and Other Woes, in Paradise
description: If youve ever visited a Caribbean island and been discomfited by the social divisions between visitors and the local population, youll relate to much in Logan Sandlers Live Cargo. The movie, shot in the Bahamas, where Mr. Sandler spent some of his teenage years, captures the grittier, lesser-seen corners of a tourist destination.

title: Cincinnati Law Dean Is Put on Leave After Proposing Ways to Cut Budget
description: When Jennifer S. Bard took the reins of the University of Cincinnati College of Law in 2015, her chief mission was to overhaul the schools troubled finances.

title: Randy Weston Brings His African Nubian Suite to the Jazz Standard
description: The pianist Randy Weston has maintained since the 1950s that straight-ahead jazz is a deeply rooted Afrocentric art form as much as a byproduct of American democracy. Today that feels intuitive; a few decades ago, it was the stuff of polemics.

title: Trumps Threats Against Freedom Caucus Cause Few Shivers of Fear
description: WASHINGTON  When Representative Mark Sanford of South Carolina, fresh off helping torpedo his partys bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, showed up at the Berkeley County Republican meeting on Saturday, he was met with applause and praise in one of the most conservative corners of his district.

title: Review: Tony Conrad, Completely in the Present
description: While he conceived and created some of the most prescient, influential and galvanic music of the second half of the 20th century, Tony Conrad would have bristled if you had called him a composer. One of the things the music represented was the absence of the composer, Mr. Conrad says in the new documentary Tony Conrad: Completely in the Present. He considered this to be the case for his early 60s work with John Cale, Marian Zazeela, Angus MacLise and, most crucially, La Monte Young  someone who very much considers himself a composer. Mr. Conrads ideological break with Mr. Young is one of the many fascinating episodes of Mr. Conrads productive life (he died last April at  76) covered in this film directed by Tyler Hubby.

title: Cubas Unfamiliar Modernist Past Arrives in Houston
description: The full cultural effects of Cubas current rapprochement with the United States remain to be seen. But you get a vivid sense of the islands still-unfamiliar modernist past in Adis Utopia: Dreams and Deceptions in Cuban Art Since 1950 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston.

title: ABCs The Toy Box Lets Kids Run the Shark Tank
description: What if kids ruled the Shark Tank? That, more or less, is what happens on The Toy Box, a competition series for toy inventors that begins Friday, April 7, on ABC.

title: Review: Here Alone Will Scare You With Menacing Little Jolts
description: Given the familiarity of its premise  a handful of survivors brave the aftermath of a deadly, rage-inducing virus  Here Alone is unexpectedly engaging. More psychodrama than postapocalyptic adventure, the movie parcels out its scares in small, effective jolts, delivering just enough menace to remind us of the stakes.

title: What It Means When 5 Million Syrians Leave Their Country
description: The scale of Syrias refugee crisis is dizzying.

title: Eight Notes That Have Meant N.C.A.A. Tournament for a Quarter-Century
description: Late in 1992, when he was asked to submit samples for a new theme song for CBSs coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, Bob Christianson did what he usually does. He paced his small basement studio. He washed dishes and scrubbed the floor. He ironed clothes.

title: Times Readers Share Their Zingers About Ronaldos Bust
description: What happens when a bust is, well, a bust? Fans and foes alike of the soccer player Cristiano Ronaldo have set the internet aflame since an alleged likeness of the Real Madrid star, cast in bronze, was unveiled Wednesday at Madeira International Airport (now renamed for Ronaldo) in Portugal.

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: Brooke Shields, Amid the Harings, Learns the Art of Collecting
description: To walk with the actress Brooke Shields through her West Village townhouse is to spend time with someone in the nascent stages of becoming a collector. She does not go to art fairs, and the only live auctions she has attended have been at her daughters school. In a global art market that one estimate recently valued at $45 billion, the most Ms. Shields has spent on a painting is about $7,000.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through April 15. Matthew Marks, 522 West 22nd Street, Manhattan; 212-243-0200, matthewmarks.com.

title: Review: A Descent Into Mental Illness in God Knows Where I Am
description: In 2011, The New Yorker published God Knows Where I Am, an unsettling article by Rachel Aviv recounting the fate of Linda Bishop, a single mother with bipolar disorder and psychosis who fell through the cracks of New Hampshires medical establishment. Now Ms. Aviv is a consulting producer for Jedd and Todd Widers affecting documentary of the same title, which adds vivid colors to the tragic tale.

title: Spring Fever
description: Galas were held last week for the Fashion Institute of Technology, the Venetian Room, Pflag National and Fordham University.

title: Civil Rights Law Shields Police Personnel Files, Court Finds
description: A Manhattan appeals court ruled on Thursday in two separate lawsuits that a long-established but contentious provision of the New York civil rights code prevents the disciplinary records of city police officers from being publicly released.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: Review: The Death of Louis XIV Has a Riveting Performance at Its Heart
description: If the movie industry gave out awards for Most Accurate Title, the Catalan writer and director Albert Serras new film would walk away with one. As it happens, Mr. Serra did receive Frances prestigious Jean Vigo award for The Death of Louis XIV, which stars Jean-Pierre Laud as the French monarch.

title: Toasts to Fashion and Scholars
description: The Fashion Institute of Technology held its annual gala on March 22 at the Marriott Marquis. The Cultural Services of the French Embassy held a costumed benefit on March 23 to renovate its Venetian Room. Pflag National held its annual gala at the Marriott Marquis on March 27. And Fordham University held its annual Fordham Founders awards dinner on March 27 at Cipriani Wall Street.

title: Review: Before Eraserhead There Was David Lynch: The Art Life
description: The Twin Peaks television revival is finally arriving in May, but David Lynch fans have had a long spell of contenting themselves with leftovers. (The directors last feature was Inland Empire in 2006.) The documentary David Lynch: The Art Life benefits from confining itself to a less-examined period.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: Aipads Photography Show Grows Up
description: Some art fairs evolve; others have growth spurts. This year the Photography Show has moved to Pier 94 on the Hudson from the Park Avenue Armory, its home for the last decade, and more than doubled in size. Steroids may have been involved.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: Review: Carrie Pilby, Saved by Bel Powley, Superhero
description: In 2015, Bel Powley stole Sundance with her performance in The Diary of a Teenage Girl. Carrie Pilby poses a tougher test. Might she single-handedly redeem 90 minutes of contrived nonsense?

title: Viewers, the Dance Floor Is Yours (but Duck the Steinway!)
description: On view for one week only at the Museum of Modern Art, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker: Work/Travail/Arbeid is among the most substantive and challenging exhibitions of the year. But is it an exhibition at all? Ms. De Keersmaeker, a renowned Belgian choreographer, emerged in the 1980s with exacting, cerebral dances, performed with her company, Rosas, and often featuring live music by the Ictus Ensemble. For this new project, she and her longtime dance troupe and musical partners adapt her rigorous choreography from stage to gallery  and present dance as a museum show like any other. But also: a museum show unlike any other.

title: Cubs, on Top, Look to Stay There in a Season Not Unlike the Last
description: Unable to win a World Series in 108 seasons, the Chicago Cubs found themselves in an odd place last spring: They were favorites to do just that. And they met those expectations in grand style, leading the majors in victories on their way to glory.

title: Astros Are Still Waiting to Win a World Series Game. That May End.
description: The Houston Astros hired Jeff Luhnow to run their baseball operations after the 2011 season, the same winter the Chicago Cubs hired Theo Epstein to run theirs. Both men had earned championship rings already  Luhnow for growing the St. Louis Cardinals farm system, Epstein for building the Boston Red Sox. Then Epstein won another title last fall.

title: Noreen Fraser, Who Led a Public Fight Against Cancer, Dies at 63
description: Noreen Fraser, a television producer who used her broadcasting skills to raise money and public awareness in a national campaign against breast cancer, died on Monday at her home in Brentwood, Calif., more than 15 years after she learned she had the disease. She was 63.

title: Review: The Boss Baby Puts Alec Baldwin in Diapers, Sort Of
description: The animated feature The Boss Baby has some hilarious moments. If, that is, youre a grown-up.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: New Firms Catching Up to Banks in Foreclosure Rankings
description: The number of home foreclosures is down sharply from the depths of the financial crisis, even as many of the mortgage firms involved remain the same, including Fannie Mae, Wells Fargo, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Canada in April
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site.

title: Review: The Blackcoats Daughter Is Bewitching and Bloody
description: Playing out in gloomy interiors and frigid exteriors, The Blackcoats Daughter is a stealth weapon. Slow and seductive and deliberately vague, this deeply unsettling tale of lost parents and troubled daughters exudes atmosphere while hoarding facts. Yet the movie is so perfectly acted and gorgeously filmed (the cinematographer is Julie Kirkwood) that we dont mind its coyness; the twanging notes of trepidation make us almost grateful for the leisurely build.

title: Review: All This Panic, a Cinematic Confidant of Teenage Girls
description: Having grown up clicking and posing, the teenage girls in All This Panic are as comfortable in front of a camera as professional actors. And thats good news for this limber, light-footed documentary, which becomes a cinematic confidant for their fears and confessions, dreams and insecurities as they dance on the boundary between high school and adulthood.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Review: 13 Reasons Why She Killed Herself, Drawn Out on Netflix
description: A note to adults in the audience: 13 Reasons Why is not Netflixs next Stranger Things.

title: Uber Executive Invokes Fifth Amendment, Seeking to Avoid Potential Charges
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An Uber executive accused of stealing driverless car technology from his former employers at Google is exercising his Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination, according to his lawyers.

title: Review: Five Came Back, and Inspired the Likes of Spielberg
description: Recounting the stories of five Hollywood directors who served in World War II with cameras in tow, the 2014 book Five Came Back, by the journalist Mark Harris, is an extraordinarily detailed account of how the men brought the war home for viewers. Still, it has a problem endemic to film books: It lacks clips.

title: Review: A Warrior, Leaning on Shakespeare, in Cry Havoc!
description: To save himself from a miserable home life, Stephan Wolfert joined the Army. And to save himself from the Army, Mr. Wolfert became an actor. He has merged these experiences in Cry Havoc! at the New Ohio Theater, a full-bore autobiographical solo with a meddling co-writer named William Shakespeare.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: One Pianists Variations on Tales From the Crypt
description: A searching artist who likes to play old and new music against (or, more accurately, for) each other, the pianist David Greilsammer arrives in New York on Wednesday, April 5, for the latest installment in the Crypt Sessions, a way-downstairs, intimate series at the Church of the Intercession in Washington Heights.

title: Review: Pathos Times Two: A Double Dose of Inge, in Close Quarters
description: Hal and Marie are young, gorgeous, vital. Theyre also inopportune outsiders, wreaking havoc on seemingly tranquil communities.

title: Mariana Valencias Album Moves Toward Biography
description: The choreographer Mariana Valencia has been thinking about her personal history  or, as she calls it, herstory. In her new work, Album  a compilation of dance, monologue and song  she approaches making performance as assembling notes for a future biographer. Dance is often romanticized for its ephemerality, but Ms. Valencia, shaping her own narrative, intends to leave a record.

title: North by Northwest as It Was Meant to Be Seen: Big
description: Pity the modern viewer who has watched North by Northwest only on a tablet-size screen. The film, Alfred Hitchcocks mistaken-identity thriller from 1959, is one of those movies that really need to be seen large  especially for that brilliantly filmed scene that pits Cary Grant against a crop-dusting airplane.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: No Inner City in Brownsville, Brooklyn, Just Overlooked Strengths
description: One recent morning, Nadia Lopez, a Brooklyn middle-school principal who became an internet celebrity two years ago  and as a result has been a guest of Ellen DeGeneres, Barack Obama and Drew Gilpin Faust, the president of Harvard, as well as an author  received a flood of text messages from family and friends who were outraged by an article in The Daily News titled Brownsville Is Brooklyns Worst Neighborhood for Children. For seven years, Ms. Lopez has run Mott Hall Bridges Academy in Brownsville to great acclaim, having gained national attention when the blog Humans of New York profiled a student who talked about what a profound influence she was.

title: Review: In Ghost in the Shell, a Cyborg With Soul
description: Like the greatest screen goddesses, Scarlett Johansson rises above it all. In the thrill-free science-fiction thriller Ghost in the Shell, her character comes at you in pieces, emerging first during the opening credits in the form of a metallic skeleton. Its a good look  it evokes the original Terminator  but soon the skeleton is being dipped like a chip in whitish goo. This technological soup gives the metallic frame a humanoid cladding, making it more reassuringly and pleasantly familiar, from bosomy top to round bottom. It looks like a giant dream Barbie, hairless pubis and all.

title: At Nonesuch Records, Star Treatment for a Boss Who Plays
description: For the last six months, Robert Hurwitz has been going through the daily journals he kept during more than 30 years at the helm of Nonesuch Records. In thousands of pages, he documented working with the musicians who have made Nonesuch perhaps the most eclectic label in the business: the composers Steve Reich and John Adams, jazz auteurs like Brad Mehldau, the arena-filling rock duo the Black Keys, and esteemed songwriters like Randy Newman and Stephin Merritt.

title: How Gymnastics Culture Breeds Sexual Abuse
description: Jamie Dantzscher told the members of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday that, starting when she was 12 years old, a man who was supposed to be looking out for her well-being did just the opposite: He sexually abused her. She was an elite gymnast. He was the team doctor.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: The Turkey Vulture Is So Clever, and Stinky
description: On a day far more like February than March, I watched a turkey vulture struggle against a raging headwind along a southern Brooklyn street. I could see its destination: an unfortunate rabbit, flattened in the middle of the road. With a frothy Jamaica Bay for a background, the vulture extended its feet with the peculiar, almost respectful grace of a carrion eater, and had committed to landing when a speeding patrol car changed its plans.

title: This Weeks Movies: March 31, 2017
description: The New York Times film critics review Ghost in the Shell, Karl Marx City and The Zookeeper's Wife."

title: New ISIS Tactic: Gather Mosuls Civilians, Then Lure an Airstrike
description: WASHINGTON  A United States military spokesman said Thursday that Islamic State fighters had been herding local Iraqi residents into buildings in western Mosul, calculating that rising civilian casualties would restrain the United States from using airstrikes to help retake that half of the city.

title: McDonalds to Use Fresh Beef for Quarter Pounder Burgers
description: McDonalds announced on Thursday that it would use fresh beef instead of frozen patties in Quarter Pounder burgers in most of its restaurants by mid-2018, the latest step in the companys efforts to overhaul its menu and image.

title: Trump, Tillerson, Venezuela: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Money for Failing State Schools Has Finally Been Released
description: A tangled court battle that pitted New Yorks budget authority against its Education Department took another turn on Wednesday when the state released a long-delayed infusion of cash to some of its lowest-performing schools.

title: A Strong Start for an Epics Finale
description: Secret Realities: The suspense novel Mississippi Blood, new at No.1 on the hardcover fiction list, concludes Greg Iless mammoth Natchez Burning trilogy, about race, murder and a fraught father-son relationship spanning half a century in the Deep South. Before the trilogy started with Natchez Burning in 2014, Iles had written a number of previous best sellers featuring its protagonist, the lawyer Penn Cage, and early drafts of Natchez Burning treated that book as another straightforward thriller along the same lines. But after a serious car accident in 2011  Iles lost a leg and spent months recuperating  he returned to the book with a new sense of purpose and an ambition reflected in the trilogys ultimate size: more than 2,300 pages published over the course of three years. (At that rate, Robert Caro could have wrapped up his Lyndon Johnson biography decades ago and moved on to a multivolume study of Gerald Ford.)

title: Giuliani Was Hired to Negotiate Turks Iran Sanctions Case, Letters Suggest
description: The lawyer for Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader jailed in New York on charges of violating United States sanctions on Iran, sent a letter to a judge on Thursday that suggested that Rudolph W. Giuliani had been retained to negotiate a resolution of the case with government officials at higher levels than the federal prosecutor overseeing the matter.

title: SpaceX Launches a Satellite With a Partly Used Rocket
description: SpaceX launched a commercial satellite into space on Thursday with the boost of a partly used rocket, a feat that may open an era of cheaper space travel.

title: For-Profit Law School in Arizona Is Put on Probation
description: Arizona Summit Law school, a troubled for-profit institution owned by the InfiLaw System, has been placed on probation by its accrediting body, the American Bar Association.

title: Corrections: March 31, 2017
description: NEW YORK

title: Kansas Governor Vetoes Medicaid Expansion, Setting Stage for Showdown
description: Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas vetoed a bill on Thursday that would have expanded Medicaid in his state, setting up a potential showdown next week with a Legislature that, while heavily Republican, has come to favor extending the largely free health coverage to as many as 180,000 additional poor adults.

title: Deane Hinton, Envoy Who Denounced Salvadoran Death Squads, Dies at 94
description: Deane R. Hinton, an American career diplomat who was rebuffed by the Reagan administration over his accusations of human rights abuses by Salvadoran security forces and right-wing death squads, died on Tuesday at his home in San Jose, Costa Rica. He was 94.

title: Oculus Founder, at Center of Legal Battle Over VR, Departs Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Palmer Luckey, a founder of the virtual-reality technology company Oculus, has left Facebook three years after the social network acquired his company for close to $3 billion.

title: Iraqi and Syrian Civilians in the Crossfire
description: The Pentagon insists that there has been no major change in its rules for airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and that a surge in civilian casualties is a result of increased military operations in western Mosul, said to be the most intense urban combat since World War II.

title: Judge Signals He Will Approve Trump University Settlement Despite a Challenge
description: SAN DIEGO  After years of pursuing fraud claims against Donald J. Trump, lawyers representing former students of his defunct for-profit education venture, Trump University, appeared in federal court on Thursday to try to fend off one last challenge: an objection to the $25 million settlement that would bring the case to a close.

title: For the Atlanta Braves, a Housewarming Present for the Future
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  From their golf cart last week, in a plaza beyond center field at the Atlanta Braves spring training complex, John Hart and John Coppolella could watch two minor league exhibition games at once. To one side was a left-handed pitching prospect named Sean Newcomb. To the other, a promising right-hander named Touki Toussaint.

title: Prosecutors Want Cosby Spanish Fly Comments as Evidence at Trial
description: Bill Cosby may have been working for laughs when he told Larry King in 1991 the old story of boys dropping a purported aphrodisiac they called Spanish fly into a girls drink. The girl would drink it and, Mr. Cosby said, Hello America!

title: Brian Oldfield, Brash Shot-Putting Superstar, Dies at 71
description: Brian Oldfield, a brash shot-putter who became a superstar in an often-overlooked sport by mastering a technique that let him throw the 16-pound metal ball farther than anyone in his day, died on Sunday at home in Elgin, Ill. He was 71.

title: Artistry Is Easy to Overlook Amid Figure Skatings Aerial Exploits
description: HELSINKI, Finland  Nathan Chen, the new quad king, lost his edge on a mere triple jump in his short program at the world championships on Thursday, which seemed a timely reminder that quadruple jumps are not the sun, the moon and the stars in mens figure skating.

title: Senate Narrowly Passes Rollback of Obama-Era Auto-I.R.A. Rule
description: WASHINGTON  By a single vote, the Senate gave final approval on Thursday to a measure to block cities and counties from organizing retirement savings accounts for workers who have no access to employer-sponsored plans. The vote reverses a Labor Department rule that allows local governments to automatically enroll private-sector workers in retirement plans unless they opt out.

title: Bread Crumbs Scattered on the Sidewalk
description: Walking home on the Upper East Side one day, I saw an older woman standing in front of a small apartment building. She was throwing bread crumbs to little birds that were hopping around slowly and pecking at them.

title: Its a Piece of Baseball History. But for Which Club?
description: Q. I read that a section of a wall from Washington Park  the stadium for the Brooklyn Dodgers before they began playing in Ebbets Field in 1913  still stands at Third Avenue and First Street in Gowanus. Is this true?

title: A Mammoth Step in the Pursuit of Illicit Ivory Sales
description: The windows of the gallery and the floors of its aisles are lined with animals, in herds and singly. Lions. Giraffes. Monkeys. And elephants, bulls, cows and calves. Most were cast from poured metal.

title: Volkswagen to Pay 10 States Over Environmental Claims
description: DETROIT  Volkswagen took another step Thursday to move past its emissions-cheating scandal by agreeing to pay $157 million to 10 states to settle environmental lawsuits.

title: Betting on Potential, Yankees Will Start Aaron Judge and Luis Severino
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  It passed for news Thursday when Manager Joe Girardi named Aaron Judge as the Yankees opening day right fielder and Luis Severino as the fourth starter in the rotation.

title: Rival Campaigns for N.J. Governors Race Volley Accusations
description: A rival Democratic campaign filed a formal complaint Thursday to New Jerseys Election Law Enforcement Commission, alleging campaign finance violations against Philip D. Murphy, the highest-polling Democrat for governor.

title: North Carolinas Bait-and-Switch on Transgender Restroom Law
description: Facing a deadline to do away with a law that turned North Carolina into a national pariah by denying the right of transgender people to use public restrooms of their choice, state lawmakers rashly settled on a terrible compromise.

title: Student Loan Forgiveness Program Approval Letters May Be Invalid, Education Dept. Says
description: More than 550,000 people have signed up for a federal program that promises to repay their remaining student loans after they work 10 years in a public service job.

title: Weather on the 1s? Stormy, as Familiar Faces Depart From NY1
description: For many New Yorkers, the cable news channel NY1 has been a steady, scrappy and sometimes quirky companion for a quarter century with its no-nonsense coverage of exclusively local news and issues, 24 hours a day.

title: SpaceX Makes a First With Second-Hand Rocket
description: SpaceX launched a pre-flown rocket into space on Thursday. If the company can repeat it, this method could slash the price of space travel in the future.

title: Eduardo Cunha, Who Led Impeachment Drive Against Rival in Brazil, Gets a 15-Year Jail Term
description: CONCEIO DO CAPIM, Brazil  Eduardo Cunha, the conservative Brazilian political leader who led the push in 2016 to oust Dilma Rousseff, Brazils former president, was sentenced on Thursday to more than 15 years in prison.

title: Quotation of the Day: Venezuela Muzzles Legislature, Moving Closer to One-Man Rule
description: They have kidnapped the Constitution, they have kidnapped our rights, they have kidnapped our liberty.

title: Michael Flynn Offers to Testify Before Congress in Exchange for Immunity
description: WASHINGTON  Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, has offered to be interviewed by House and Senate investigators who are examining the Trump campaigns ties to Russia in exchange for immunity from prosecution, according to his lawyer and a congressional official.

title: Trump Critics on Climate Policy Hope Executives Can Sway Him
description: Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electrics chief executive, says climate change is real, a position at odds with the Trump administration.

title: Health Subsidies for Low Earners Will Continue Through 2017, G.O.P. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Senior House Republicans said Thursday that they expected the federal government to continue paying billions of dollars in subsidies to health insurance companies to keep low-income people covered under the Affordable Care Act for the rest of this year  and perhaps for 2018 as well.

title: Donald Harvey, Who Killed Dozens of Hospital Patients, Dies at 64
description: Donald Harvey, a health care worker called the Angel of Death by the news media after he killed dozens of hospital patients under his care in the 1970s and 80s, died on Thursday after he was attacked in his prison cell in Ohio. He was 64.

title: They Finally Got Paid. Now Theyre Ready to Play.
description: PLYMOUTH, Mich.  The United States womens hockey team is going from one tough battle off the ice to a big challenge on it.

title: Marco Rubio Says His Campaign Was a Target of Russian Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio said Thursday during a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing on Russia that his own presidential campaign had been a target of apparent Russian cyberattacks, and a cybersecurity expert testified that Mr. Rubio might have been the victim of a Russian online smear campaign.

title: Number of Women Coaching in College Has Plummeted in Title IX Era
description: DALLAS  Fridays opening game in the womens Final Four here will feature two of the most prominent female coaches in college basketball.

title: In Albany, Glimpses of Budget as Federal Cuts and Deadlines Loom
description: As New Yorks lawmakers faced down a midnight Friday deadline for the state budget, the mood seemed sedate if uncertain, following a well-worn trajectory of tantalizing hints about possible agreements  an Uber expansion upstate, a new court system for juvenile offenders and billions for new water systems, among others  coupled with constant reminders that nothing was actually finalized.

title: Wild Thing
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  A pangram, for those of you just joining us, is when a puzzle uses each of the letters of the alphabet at least once. Sometimes it just happens when a constructor is making a puzzle, and sometimes its a constructors way of showing that he or she can do some heavy cruciverbal lifting. Either way, its nice but its not necessarily what solvers look for when they sit down to solve a puzzle.

title: Two Democratic Senators Back Gorsuch, but Cant Sway Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON  Two Democratic senators from solidly Republican states announced their support on Thursday for President Trumps Supreme Court pick, Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, giving the nominee a measure of bipartisan sheen but doing little to dissuade leading Democrats from planning to block him.

title: Boom Times for the New Dystopians
description: When Omar El Akkad was writing his debut novel, American War, about a futuristic not-so-United States that has been devastated by civil war, drone killings, suicide bombings and the ravages of climate change, he didnt have to invent much. The ruined landscape and societal collapse he envisioned was based partly on scenes he had witnessed as a war correspondent in Afghanistan.

title: The Accident No One Talked About
description: I found the drivers name from a police report that had been filed in Florida 17 years before. The report was torn and creased and incorrect.

title: Andrew McCarthys Newest Role: Young Adult Novelist
description: A man approached me in the Lexington Candy Shop, a luncheonette on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that has not changed much since it opened in 1925. This was the time we had set for an interview, but I took the man for just another middle-aged New York dad until I registered the melancholy blue-gray eyes and sweetly electric smile that won over a generation (mine) of young women.

title: Soda or Bear Claw? Panera to Post Added Sugar in Drinks It Sells
description: Panera Bread appears to be the first major restaurant chain to offer its customers information about the amount of added sugar in the beverages it sells.

title: In Anatomy of an Afghan Bombing, Clues of a Tangled War
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  For days in his hospital bed, Dr. Humayoon Azizi, the governor of the southern Afghan province of Kandahar, hallucinated.

title: Michael Flynn, Israel, SpaceX: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Turkeys Wars: Quelling Kurdish Uprisings, and Suffering From Terror Attacks
description: In Kurdish areas of Turkey, fear and destruction have returned as facts of life after government offensives leveled parts of rebellious cities. And a barrage of terrorist attacks by the Islamic State and Kurdish groups is changing peoples sense of personal safety. This is the fourth part in the State of Emergency series, in which our correspondent takes us behind the scenes of todays Turkey, a nation in crisis.

title: Whats on TV Friday: 13 Reasons Why and Five Came Back
description: Its a starry night on Netflix, with 13 Reasons Why, a passion project of Selena Gomez and her mother, and Five Came Back, in which Hollywood directors reminisce about the World War II service of their idols.

title: Word + Quiz: yeoman
description: 1. a person who owns and cultivates his own land

title: The Week in Pictures: March 31, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: YouTube Stars
description: Do you know who the girl in this picture is? She just signed a deal with Nickelodeon, after becoming a star on YouTube.

title: The Week in Pictures: March 31, 2017
description: Photos by The New York Times and by photographers from around the world.

title: Right and Left: Partisan Writing You Shouldnt Miss
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Trumps Chumps
description: You voted for a man who boasted of sexual assault, a man whose university defrauded thousands of people, a billionaire who thought the minimum wage was too high. You switched from Barack Obama in 2012 to Donald Trump in 2016  one in four white working-class voters  because you thought he was on your side.

title: The Strange Persistence of Guilt
description: In 1981 the philosopher Alasdair MacIntyre opened his book After Virtue with a passage that is now famous. Imagine if we lost the theoretical coherence of science. Imagine if we still used scientific words like neutrino and atomic weight, but had no overall framework to explain how they fit together.

title: The Complex Cost of Brexit Gets Clearer
description: Almost nine months passed between that day in June when the British stunned the world by voting to quit the European Union and this Wednesday, when Prime Minister Theresa May delivered the letter formally starting the two-year disengagement  more like disentanglement  process.

title: Climate Progress, With or Without Trump
description: President Trumps unfortunate and misguided rollback of environmental protections has led to a depressing and widespread belief that the United States can no longer meet its commitment under the Paris climate change agreement. But heres the good news: Its wrong.

title: How the Freedom Caucus Is Undermining the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  Governing is not easy. We learned this the hard way as Speaker Paul Ryan stood before House Republicans last week and told us he was withdrawing the Obamacare replacement plan. Despite campaign promises to repeal and replace by the president and most Republicans, the votes were not there to pass the American Health Care Act. And just like that, the effort was dead.

title: Coal Country Is a State of Mind
description: West Virginia went overwhelmingly for Donald Trump in November  in fact, he beat Hillary Clinton by almost a three-to-one majority. And it may seem obvious why: The state is the heart of coal country, and Mr. Trump promised to bring coal jobs back by eliminating Obama-era environmental regulations. So at first glance the 2016 election looks like a political realignment reflecting differences in regional interests.

title: How Scared Should People on the Border Be?
description: BROWNSVILLE, TEX.  The news here on the border with Mexico travels fast.

title: Questions for: Pillars of the West Shaken by Brexit, but Theyre Not Crumbling Yet
description: Article: Pillars of the West Shaken by Brexit, but Theyre Not Crumbling Yet

title: Donald Trumps Parrot
description: A parrot flies out the window in Soviet Russia. The owner rushes to the Moscow offices of the K.G.B., where he tells an agent: I just want to make clear that any views my parrot expresses are exclusively its own.

title: James Corden Has a New Way to Think About Climate Change
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Tel Aviv Restaurant With Local Ingredients, Global Influences
description: Everything served at Dok, from the ros wine to the ice cream, is made from ingredients grown in Israel. O.K., almost everything: Sugar and wheat flour are exceptions. But Asaf Doktor, the chef who owns the Tel Aviv restaurant with his brother, Yotam, is working on it.

title: Should You Always Have the Right to Wear What You Want?
description: Have you, or anyone you know, ever been punished or reprimanded because of what you wore in public? What happened, and how did you feel about it?

title: Judge John Hodgman on Peanut Butter Straight From the Jar
description: Olivia writes: I leave a jar of peanut butter at my office and often eat a spoonful (or several) when I am too lazy to pack lunch. My fianc badgers me, saying that it is not sufficient in nutrients or volume. I eat a well-rounded diet otherwise. Please order him to stop making fun of my lunch choices.

title: Philipp Meyer: By the Book
description: The author of the novel The Son, now a series on AMC, is creatively inspired by poetry: What I am looking for in a poem is a sense for sound and compression, for the density of meaning that all good poetry has and that all good fiction should strive for.

title: How to Run for Local Office
description: Never miss the ham breakfast or the chili supper, says Nicole Galloway, the state auditor of Missouri, a position she was appointed to after serving as treasurer of Boone County. Months before you file your candidacy with the local elections office, get out and meet as many voters, elected officials and party representatives as you can. Tell them about your vision, but dont just talk at them. Spend a lot of time listening, Galloway says.

title: 8. I Love Wine!
description: This poem is one section of a long sequence, The Baudelaire Variations, named after the 19th-century French Symbolist poet who famously wrote: You must always be drunk. ... But on what? Wine, poetry or virtue, as you wish. But be drunk. Simonds seems to have taken his advice, becoming drunk on her capacity to make poetry through metaphor. Drunk as well on a temporary freedom from domestic responsibility, she addresses throughout the long poem a companion of indeterminate gender, Felix, whose name in Latin means happy. The whole sequence becomes a gleeful, antic, tragic allegory for our distance from the boxed wine paradise of our dreams. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

title: Moving Checklist
description: TWO MONTHS

title: In Polands Crooked Forest, a Mystery With No Straight Answer
description: In Polands Krzywy Las, or Crooked Forest, the pine trees look like potbellied stick figures. On some 400 trees, the trunks buckle out 90 degrees, creating bark-covered bellies that drag just above the earth, oddly, all pointing in the same direction  north.

title: Friday Mailbag: Reforming the Use of Reform
description: With repeal of the Affordable Care Act on the back burner, Republicans have moved forward with plans for a sizable tax cut, and so, too, did The New York Timess coverage.

title: The Roots of the Battle Over Neil Gorsuch: They Started It
description: WASHINGTON  There was no filibuster for Clarence Thomas, whose Supreme Court confirmation hearings provoked a national uproar over sex, race and the behavior of powerful men.

title: How the Courts Got Between Our Sheets
description: SEX AND THE CONSTITUTION Sex, Religion, and Law From Americas Origins to the Twenty-First Century By Geoffrey R. Stone Illustrated. 668 pp. Liveright Publishing. $35.

title: In the Long Run
description: What makes a story worthy of an entire book? This question arises frequently when I work with students who are writing memoirs, often after theyve produced 20 pages of riveting prose about the most dramatic thing that ever happened to them only to find theyre out of things to say. When writing about yourself, its difficult enough to ease up on the pedal of self-flattery in the interests of truth. But to confront your storys limitations head-on and admit its better suited to 20 pages than 220 pages can be a painful reckoning  though, as I tell my students, not nearly as painful as trying to spread a ho-hum back story into a thin layer across a whole book. As Stephen King said in his exemplary literary craft guide, On Writing, The most important things to remember about back story are that (a) everyone has a history and (b) most of it isnt very interesting.

title: Missing Girls in Washington DC Widen Citys Racial Divide
description: WASHINGTON  The black and brown faces stare out from the Metropolitan Police Departments official Twitter feed, each girl under a red banner with block letters declaring Critical Missing. Their names speak of unseen corners of the nations capital, a world far removed from lobbyists power lunches and legislative deal making.

title: How to Avoid Stress When Youre Moving
description: One night last month, while I was in the midst of moving out of the house where I had lived for nearly a decade, I found myself trying to make dinner with two pans, one fork and one knife  the only things I had not yet packed that were useful.

title: Behind the Cover: 4.2.17
description: For this weeks cover, the photographer Christopher Anderson wanted to create a portrait of Trump that had never been seen before. My hope was to make an image that feels intimate and unlike the caricatures we normally see of him, good or bad, Anderson said. One that somehow communicated the experience I had of meeting him.

title: The 3.19.17 Issue
description: RE: THE NEW PARTY OF NO

title: Sheryl Crow Checks the Mirror, and Plays What She Sees
description: Sometimes the comfort zone is where a musician belongs. Thats the charm of Be Myself, Sheryl Crows pointedly titled new album, which gleefully and unabashedly returns to the sound of her hit albums from the 1990s. This record, of all the records Ive made, was just sheer joy, Ms. Crow said in an interview at the Bowery Hotel.

title: India, Long at Odds With Pakistan, May Be Rethinking Nuclear First Strikes
description: India may be reinterpreting its nuclear weapons doctrine, circumstantial evidence suggests, with potentially significant ramifications for the already tenuous nuclear balance in South Asia.

title: Rotten Dirty Traitor Falls Into the Juventus-Napoli Divide
description: If Gonzalo Higuan had any doubts about what lies in wait for him in Naples, the banner that appeared on the Ponte Maddalena Cerasuolo in northern Naples on Thursday morning would have swept them away. First, the banner accused him of being an actor, and then a slave to the system. The real venom, though, was in the final three words: Marcio sporco traditore.

title: Puzzle in Poland: Who Bent the Trees?
description: A dirt road in Poland leads to a patch of pine trees with unusually crooked trunks. Why? Its kind of a mystery. See for yourself in this 360 video, and consider some theories.

title: A Chinese-Backed Dam Project Leaves Myanmar in a Bind
description: AUNG MYIN THA, Myanmar  For six years, Daw Kaw Bu has waited to return to the village she was forced to leave to make way for a dam that has yet to be built.

title: Teaching With: Crossing Cultures: Black K-Pop Fans in America
description: Crossing Cultures: Black K-Pop Fans in America is the first Daily 360 were featuring in our weekly Film Club. Every day The Times publishes a new 360 video, an immersive video that puts you at the center of the scene, allowing you to look left, right, up, down and behind you.

title: On Brexit, Its Divorce First, Trade Talks Later, E.U. Tells U.K.
description: BRUSSELS  Britain must agree to pay its bills and to protect millions of Europeans living in Britain before reaching a new trading relationship with the European Union, Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, said on Friday.

title: Michael Flynn, Brexit, Ghost in the Shell: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Face of Miscarriage
description: The first time Id miscarried I was a 24-year-old newlywed and, because of a scheduling mix-up, Id had to wait two days for a D & C. While I mourned the loss, I found it macabre and scary to be carrying death. Afterward, I was sad but mostly relieved. Since then Id had several very early onset miscarriages between two live births, but nothing so traumatic.

title: Is It Harder to Lose Weight When Youre Older?
description: Q. Is it more difficult for an older person to lose weight?

description: THE WOMEN IN THE CASTLE By Jessica Shattuck 356 pp. Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99.

title: She Loves the Met. He Loves LeBron James.
description: Sally Wang has a theory as to why she did not date many Asian men before meeting Jason Liang in February 2015.

description: Updated, 9:56 a.m.

description: Listen to The Daily: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Morning Agenda: Uber Executive Invokes Fifth Amendment
description: The legal fight between Uber and Google keeps getting more interesting.

title: How Reagan and the New Right Resuscitated the G.O.P.
description: REAGAN RISING The Decisive Years, 1976-1980 By Craig Shirley 409 pp. Broadside Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $29.99.

title: Jessie Woolley-Wilson on Creating Benevolent Friction at Work
description: This interview with Jessie Woolley-Wilson, C.E.O. of DreamBox Learning, a provider of online math education software for children, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Piano Man of Many Faces, and Some Stranger Stories
description: When Midtown Manhattan goes dark after hours, Chicken Delicious edges onto his piano stool at Mimis, tinkling some notes to start. He opens to the crowd with his soft Southern accent: Good evening, everyone. My name is Chicken Delicious. I come from Mississippi. I live on the kindness of strangers. This is a reference to his tip jar.

title: Ephemeral New York
description: The photographer Devin Yalkin says he wants people to hear his images, as if they have the ability to capture the low-fi, temporal hum of city life  here now, gone in an instant, leaving only a grainy black-and-white memory as evidence. Or put another way: Mr. Yalkins images represent the hum in his head as he vaporizes the scene in front of his camera.

title: The Legacy of Les Misrables: Charting the Life of a Classic
description: THE NOVEL OF THE CENTURYThe Extraordinary Adventure of Les Misrables By David Bellos 307 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.

title: Also Made in Mexico: Lifesaving Medical Devices
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  The North American Free Trade Agreement has transformed this sprawling border town from gritty party spot to something entirely different: a world capital of medical devices.

title: Under a Flashlight, a Eureka Moment About Frogs
description: It was around 4 a.m. And for Jesse Delia, a graduate student conducting fieldwork in Panama, it had been a long night. His project wasnt going well, and he was ready to head home. On his way back from the stream where he had been working, he stopped by a spot to have another look at a mating pair of frogs he had seen earlier. It didnt relate to his project, but he wanted to see what they were up to.

title: Joss Whedon Poised to Direct a Batgirl Movie
description: Joss Whedon made his name by creating the television series Buffy the Vampire Slayer, centered on a strong female lead, and he has tried his hand at directing Shakespeare. Now, he is looking at tackling the story of a female superhero: Batgirl.

title: Why Israel Is Nothing Like Apartheid South Africa
description: JERUSALEM  Among critics of Israel, it has become ever more common to accuse the Jewish state of imitating apartheid South Africa. This month, an obscure United Nations agency, the Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, whose membership comprises 18 Arab states, caused an uproar when it issued a report accusing Israel of applying the same racism in its conflict with Palestinians that made South Africa an international pariah. The United Nations secretary general swiftly repudiated the report, and it was removed from the agencys website.

title: Headphones Wont Solve the Problem of a Chatty Colleague
description: I share an office with another woman, whom I cant stand. She comes in late and complains about how tired she is, overshares her personal relationship issues and tells sexual jokes that make me uncomfortable. Worst of all, she gossips about other people in the office, which I find terribly unprofessional. Some of these issues extend to a chatty culture among others who work on this floor.

title: Mayor Backs Plan to Close Rikers and Open Jails Elsewhere
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed on Friday to close the troubled jail complex on Rikers Island, which has spawned federal investigations, brought waves of protests and became a byword for brutality, in a move he said was intended to end an era of mass incarceration in New York City.

title: Park Geun-hyes Life in Jail: Cheap Meals and a Mattress on the Floor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As president of South Korea, Park Geun-hye never appeared in public until stylists had arranged her hair in the trademark updo of her mother, a popular first lady who was killed by an assassin in 1974.

title: Improvisation Is the Heart of Cuban Animation
description: Cuba may still be under embargo with little access to the internet, but that technology deficit hasnt stopped some of the countrys artists from venturing into computer animation.

title: A Quick Guide to Backing Up Your Critical Data
description: Its World Backup Day, which is another way of saying its a good time to safeguard your digital photos, videos, documents and emails by creating second copies, or backups, of them and storing them somewhere secure.

title: Trump Calls Congressional Inquiry a Witch Hunt
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump said on Friday that Michael T. Flynn, the national security adviser who resigned last month over his contacts with Russian officials, should ask for immunity from prosecution in the congressional investigation into the presidential campaigns ties to Moscow. Mr. Trump called the inquiry a politically driven witch hunt by the news media and Democrats.

title: Patrik Elias, Cornerstone of the Devils Championship Era, Is Retiring
description: In the midst of recovering from knee surgery, Devils forward Patrik Elias took a break in December to travel with his wife and two daughters to his native Czech Republic. The consensus among relatives and friends was that Elias, even at 40, would be just fine if he played again.

title: Firing of South Africas Finance Minister Widens a Political Rift
description: JOHANNESBURG  The two rival factions inside South Africas governing African National Congress attacked each other publicly on Friday after President Jacob Zuma abruptly fired a well-respected finance minister who was considered a bulwark against government corruption.

title: California Today: Has Silicon Valley Hit a Plateau?
description: Good morning.

title: 2 Brilliant Managers Vie for a Place in History
description: CASEY STENGEL Baseballs Greatest Character By Marty Appel Illustrated. 410 pp. Doubleday. $27.95.

title: A Former Fashion Editors Glamorous Walk Through Life
description: THE PRICE OF ILLUSION A Memoir By Joan Juliet Buck Illustrated. 404 pp. Atria Books. $30.

title: The Life of a Small-Time Landlord
description: Landlords loom large in New York City, where two-thirds of residents are renters. We often think of a landlord as a faceless institution that raises the rent as coolly as it dispatches the super when the faucet leaks. The industry is dominated by giants like the LeFraks, the Dursts and the Rudins.

title: 15 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: He Works for the President
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: U.K. Art World Weighs Brexit as Depressing Moment or Golden Opportunity
description: LONDON  Its the most depressing moment in our troubled recent history, said the internationally acclaimed sculptor Anish Kapoor, describing Britains formal notice on Wednesday that it would leave the European Union.

title: Giving Like a Rockefeller, Even if Youre Not Super-Rich
description: David Rockefeller, who died last week at 101, was a giant among American philanthropists. He continued the tradition of giving that ran from his grandfather, John D., the founder of Standard Oil; through his father, John Jr.; and his oldest brother, John III.

title: I.R.S. Extension Adds Time to File, but You Still Have to Pay
description: The April 18 deadline for filing federal income tax returns is fast approaching. Taxpayers who think that they will not complete their returns on time may want to consider filing extensions.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Dancing, Testosterone and Positive Thoughts
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: First They Came ...

title: They Do Declare: Rubbing Up Against Privilege and Tradition in the New South
description: EVENINGLAND Stories By Michael Knight 277 pp. Atlantic Monthly Press. $25.

title: A Debut Novel Explores Intimacies on a Remote Northern Island
description: SHOT-BLUE By Jesse Ruddock 216 pp. Coach House Books. Paper, $17.95.

title: Jason Segel on Making Sci-Fi and Growing Oranges (Really)
description: Sometimes Jason Segel wants to make you laugh, as he did on the CBS sitcom How I Met Your Mother and in movies like Forgetting Sarah Marshall, the semi-autobiographical breakup comedy in which he wrote himself an unflattering nude scene. And sometimes hes trying to make you think, as in The End of the Tour, in which he played the author David Foster Wallace.

title: Man Collects $763,000 He Thought Was a Scam
description: Imagine finding more than $700,000 under your couch cushions. That, essentially, is what happened to a man in South Carolina who received a phone call from the state treasurer, Curtis Loftis, informing him that he was entitled to more than $763,000 in unclaimed cash.

title: A Message From the End of the World
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Here in Chile, in the far south of the Southern Hemisphere, it has been the summer of our discontent. Never have so many natural catastrophes in a row hit this country at the end of the world. For once, it is not the earthquakes that have assailed us since time immemorial or the tsunamis that often follow, devastating land and coast, mountainscapes and ocean. This time, our unprecedented woes have all been man-made.

title: Of Tweets And Trade
description: Is anything ever going to happen on trade, Trumps signature issue other than immigration? As Matt Yglesias notes, so far almost nothing has. Bloomberg tells us that companies are back to the usual business of moving jobs to Mexico, after a brief hiatus  unclear whether there was any real pause, or just a pause in announcements, but in any case CEOs seem to have decided that NAFTA isnt under much threat.

title: Do Millennial Men Want Stay-at-Home Wives?
description: Millennials, generally defined as people born between 1982 and 2000, were supposed to be the generation that forged what has been called a new national consensus in favor of gender equality. Indeed, in February the prominent Columbia professor Jeffrey Sachs labeled the 2016 election, where an extremely qualified female candidate lost to a man with a history of disrespecting women, a blip on the road to the egalitarian society that will be achieved once millennial voters outnumber their conservative elders.

title: Yannick Nzet-Sguin Will Shake Things Up at the Met Opera
description: It was no soprano who let out the high-pitched Johohohoe! on Thursday afternoon as the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra rehearsed Wagners Der Fliegende Hollnder. It was the conductor Yannick Nzet-Sguin, leading his first rehearsal since being tapped to become the Mets next music director.

title: Israel Says It Will Rein In Footprint of West Bank Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  A day after approving the construction of a new settlement in the West Bank for the first time in more than 20 years, Israel announced a new, if ambiguous, settlement policy on Friday out of consideration for the positions of President Trump and, it said, to enable progress in the peace process with Palestinians.

title: The Good Old Days of Supreme Court Nominations? They Dont Exist.
description: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times.

title: Atlanta Interstate Collapse Sends Citys Commute into Chaos
description: ATLANTA  Schools were closed, businesses were encouraging employees to work from home, and traffic was extensively rerouted on Friday, a day after a section of Interstate 85, one of the main highways in the Atlanta area, collapsed from a fire.

title: How Podcasters Heben Nigatu and Tracy Clayton Spend Their Sunday
description: Heben Nigatu and Tracy Clayton, hosts of the BuzzFeed podcast Another Round, seem to have a knack for getting their guests, which have included Hillary Clinton and Lin Manuel Miranda, to open up. They have discussed race relations and anger issues with the comedian Margaret Cho and rom-com favorites with the writer Ta-Nehisi Coates (his is The 40-Year-Old Virgin). Booze is a constant in-studio companion  at the end of each episode, Ms. Nigatu and Ms. Clayton each buy a round for something they appreciate. On April 7, they will put on a live show at the Bell House, in Brooklyn, as part of the New York City Podcast Festival. Ms. Nigatu, 26, lives in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Ms. Clayton, 34, lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn. They spend Sundays together as often as they can, shopping and people watching. TAMMY La GORCE

title: The New York Times vs. the Great Firewall of China
description: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this article, Craig S. Smith, a former Times Shanghai bureau chief and China managing director who is now a staff writer-at-large, reflects on the ups and downs of delivering New York Times content to the Chinese world.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: The Walking Dead: Will the Season Finale Make Everyone Mad Again?
description: Another 15 weeks of zombie mayhem, sociopolitical metaphors and undiluted Daryl funk have come and gone. Which is to say: The Walking Dead is about to wrap up its seventh season.

title: Bringing Industrial Artistry to His Work
description: Gordon Sweat, 62, is a machinist at Moog Inc. in Elma, N.Y.

title: A Pioneering German Feminist Looks Back in Anguish
description: COLOGNE, Germany  When Alice Schwarzer was starting out as a womens activist, she was at the side of people like Simone de Beauvoir, the French writer and feminist. The heady days of political struggle begun in 1968 led both women, and many contemporaries, to believe their many battles could be swiftly won.

title: Just Foolin Around: 7 Books From Comics and Humorists
description: The perfect April Fools Day pranks are all a little ingenious, a little cruel and a bit too revealing. These books capture the same spirit of mischief with collections that straddle the line between memoir and late-night sketch, veracity and embellished storytelling. Whether youre abstaining or just looking for a more passive brand of humor, these titles offer the same feeling of satisfaction that comes with outsmarting those closest to you. No scheming required.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Brooklyn certainly looks different from the way it did a century and a half ago, but this weekend, in Prospect Park, certain things will feel much the same. On Saturday at 11 a.m., the Brooklyn Atlantics  historic re-enactors  plan to play a baseball game there, according to 1860s rules. Bad weather may interfere, but old-fashioned fun will happen rain or shine: a 10 a.m. Saturday parade, featuring young ballplayers; a fair with refreshments; and, both days, Spring Sprouts, at the Lefferts Historic House, where children can help sow flax as well as plant seeds to take home. Weekend activities will also comprise carousel rides, ice-skating, nature exploration, bird-watching and feeding animals at the Prospect Park Zoos barn. LAUREL GRAEBER

title: Ive Got Thick Skin: We Talk to the Pro-Trump Mayor Who Was Running From Us
description: After spending Friday searching for him, we met with Mayor Roger Claar of Bolingbrook, Ill., at City Hall. He had been a bit difficult for us to locate since a fund-raiser he helped organize for Donald J. Trump became an issue in the villages mayoral race.

title: Tech Roundup: How Trump Plans to Dump Net Neutrality
description: A slew of technology regulations were enacted under President Barack Obama, including online privacy protections and the classification of broadband as a utility-like service.

title: Tracking the Yachts and Jets of the Mega-Rich
description: The hunt for connections between President Trump and a Russian billionaire has led to a little-known corner of the internet: websites that track the private yachts and jets of the rich.

title: Trump Is Right: Give Michael Flynn Immunity
description: Michael T. Flynn, the retired general who served a brief month as President Trumps national security adviser, wants to make a deal. He is seeking immunity from prosecution in exchange for testifying on the Trump campaigns possible coordination with Russia. Instead of categorically rejecting Mr. Flynns offer, as the Senate Intelligence Committee appears to have done today, at least for the moment, both houses of Congress and federal prosecutors should carefully review Flynns proffered testimony and the details of the immunity deal and then make a decision.

title: Bike Lanes Are for Immigrants? A Queens Officials View Draws Fire
description: The latest meeting of a community board in Queens had barely begun when one member, Ann Pfoser Darby, stood up.

title: Indian State Is Expanding Penalty for Killing a Cow to Life in Prison
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian state of Gujarat is tightening the punishment for the slaughter of cows, considered sacred in Hinduism, to a maximum sentence of life imprisonment.

title: Trump University Suit Settlement Approved by Judge
description: A federal judge on Friday gave final approval to a $25 million agreement to settle fraud claims arising from Donald J. Trumps for-profit education venture, Trump University, rejecting a last-minute objection to the deal.

title: Finding a Personal Web Portal
description: Q. What is a good alternative home page for My Yahoo? I like the idea of organizing my news feeds and reading a sentence or two of each post at a glance, but the alternatives that I have seen are bulky, awkward and limited.

title: What Should I Ask Hillary Clinton?
description: On Thursday afternoon Ill be interviewing Hillary Clinton on stage at Tina Browns Women in the World Summit in New York City. You can watch on my Facebook page, facebook.com/kristof , where I hopeto broadcast it on Facebook Live. I think itll be her first real journalistic interview since the election.

title: FIFA Shares Results of Investigation and Tries to Turn the Page
description: Nearly two years after a sweeping corruption case first felled top leaders of FIFA, the Swiss-based governing body for international soccer announced on Friday that it had cataloged its officials wrongdoing and delivered the results of a 22-month internal investigation to government authorities.

title: Dandelion Crayon Gets an Early Retirement From Crayola
description: After 27 years, the crayon color dandelion is taking a retirement, making way for an upstart in the blue family, officials with the crayon company Crayola said on Friday.

title: Tillerson Delivers NATO Allies a Familiar Message: Pay Up
description: BRUSSELS  Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson joined on Friday a growing list of Trump administration officials to visit the hub of North Atlantic solidarity and scold the United States European allies, saying they do not spend enough on their collective defense.

title: Roasted Carrot Salad
description: Pomegranate molasses adds a sweet and unexpected tang to this colorful carrot salad.

title: Carrots, Striking and Sweet, Have Arrived
description: A few years ago, carrots were like celery and onions, part of many a dish but rarely the star. Maybe you would see them as a side dish, buttered and glazed, or pured into a soup.

title: Ice-T Hasnt Totally Lost His Taste for Rage
description: Ice-T claims that original copies of the album featuring Cop Killer are so rare, even he doesnt have one. The only way you can get it now is on YouTube, he said. Theyre on Amazon, and theyre pretty expensive, too. (Interested collectors would be advised to check out eBay.)

title: Caution Signals Are Blinking for the Trump Bull Market
description: Despite an eight-day losing streak that ended on Tuesday, the stock market has generally been buoyant in the opening weeks of the Trump administration. The bullish mood could be a self-fulfilling prophecy and lead to continuing gains for a while.

description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Car Bomb in Pakistan Kills Over 20 Near a Shiite Hall
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful car bomb near a Shiite place of worship in northwestern Pakistan killed at least 22 people and wounded at least 90 others on Friday, breaking a brief lull in militant violence in the restive region, officials said.

title: U.N. Envoy Draws From Playbook of an Aide Steeped in Conservative Ideology
description: UNITED NATIONS  The American ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki R. Haley, has candidly described herself as a newcomer to the world of international diplomacy.

title: After Health Bills Defeat, What Trump Can Learn From L.B.J.
description: Last month, President Trump demonstrated how not to bring a health care bill before Congress. Fifty-two years ago, President Lyndon B. Johnson  a parliamentary wizard with more than three decades of Capitol Hill experience  established a model for how to do it with his landmark program for Medicare.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Viggo Mortensen
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the actor Viggo Mortensen.

title: Supermodels Apartment for Sale
description: Tyra Banks is selling her duplex at the Riverhouse in Battery Park City. The price is $17.5 million.

title: Tyra Bankss Mansion in the Sky Is on the Market
description: The supermodel and TV personality Tyra Banks has decided to sell her Battery Park City home, a mansion-size duplex facing the Hudson River, complete with dressing room and hair salon, a personal gym and separate staff and guest quarters.

title: The Most Viewed Listings of March
description: The most visited listings on The Timess Find a Home site last month included a $50 million penthouse in a Zaha Hadid-designed building along the High Line in Chelsea and a charming red-brick townhouse in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Unmasking the Fearsome Face of a Tyrannosaur
description: With its dagger teeth and formidable frame, the Tyrannosaurus rex was one of the most frightening beasts to ever terrorize the land. Yet despite all its fame, the dinosaurs looks remain a bit of a mystery.

title: Moby Microbe
description: Scientists have captured video of a one-celled microorganism using a complex biological harpoon gun to shoot and then tow away its prey.

title: First Clear View of a One-Celled Harpooner in Action
description: Humans did not invent the harpoon gun. Some sea snails and jellyfish shoot darts at prey. And one single-celled predator even fires a projectile with a line attached so it can tow its prize away.

title: Why the Urge to Merge Could Return to Wall Street
description: Nothing appears to be off the table for the Trump administration as it seeks to pare back the regulations imposed on Wall Street and banks after the financial crisis.

title: Penis Seat Causes Double Takes on Mexico City Subway
description: A seat in a subway car in Mexico Citys metro system caused a stir earlier this year. There were awkward glances. Visible discomfort. Baffled looks. Some laughs. And of course, the inevitable pictures from passengers camera phones.

title: Broadway Musicians in a Hells Kitchen Studio
description: For most couples, moving in together doesnt mean living apart. But for the Broadway musicians Deborah Avery and Michael Borth, who had love as well as the vagaries of the New York rental market to consider, a Hells Kitchen studio made perfect sense  even though they have yet to be in the same city together for more than three weeks at a time.

title: A Brooklyn Condo Sells for a Record $15 Million

description: IQUITOS, Peru  The Venezuelan government asked the Supreme Court early Saturday to revisit its decision to seize power from the national legislature, as criticism mounted that the country was tilting toward dictatorship.

title: Review: Joffrey Ballet Returns With a Muddled Romeo
description: After watching back-to-back programs by the Joffrey Ballet, I have many questions, but first things first: Why would a company that relocated to Chicago from New York in 1995 because of financial difficulties open its first New York season in more than 20 years with a subpar version of Romeo & Juliet?

title: In a Shift, Trump Will Move Egypts Rights Record to the Sidelines
description: WASHINGTON  The White House signaled on Friday that it would no longer allow human rights issues to become a public point of conflict with Egypt, another striking shift away from years of American foreign policy by presidents of both parties.
